text:
Introduction
In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. May Allah bless our Master Muhammad, his family, and his companions and grant them peace.
The servant in need of his Lord's mercy, Ali bin Abdul Rahman bin Hudhayl, may Allah grant him success, said:
Praise be to Allah, who bestowed faith upon us, made livestock subservient to us as stated in the decisive Quran, and created the horse as an 'Arab' to combat the worship of idols. Blessings and peace be upon our Master and Lord Muhammad and his family as long as day and night alternate, and may Allah be pleased with his successors Abu Bakr, Umar, Ali, and Uthman.
To proceed: Allah has decreed supported victory, eternal glory, and immortal praise for the Great, High, Majestic, and Exalted Station, the station of our Master, the protection of our religion and our world, the Supporter of the Faith, the Pillar of the Believers, the Vicegerent of the Lord of the Worlds, the Imam and Caliph, the Magnanimous King, whose command is high, whose rank is elevated among the ranks of Sultans, the Generous Provider, the Virtuous, the Righteous and Pious, Possessor of Firm Religion and Sound Intellect, the Most Effective Mujahid (Striver), the Most Pleasing Leader, the Happiest and Most Manifest, the Most Noble and Pure, the one by whom this age boasts over other ages, whose rank has been raised above all ranks, whose lineage is from the Noble Masters and Righteous Ansar (Helpers), of Famous Virtues and High Ranks, the Emir of the Muslims, Al-Musta'in Billah (He who seeks help from Allah), Abu Abdullah Muhammad, son of our Master the Unique and Magnanimous, the Most Noble and Glorious, the Grave and Famous Great One, of Noble Feats and High Pride, the Emir of the Muslims, Al-Musta'in Billah, the Mujahid in the path of Allah, the Sanctified and Late Abu al-Hajjaj Yusuf, son of our Master the Imam and Greatest Caliph, the Sanctuary, the extended Shadow of Allah over His servants, His drawn sword in the path of Jihad, and Allah's curtain draped over His lands, the Guardian of the Ummah (Nation), the Rain of Mercy, Possessor of Accepted Jihad and Famous Campaigns, of Good Conduct, of Pure Inner Self, nay, of Righteous Inner Self, the Great Sultan, the Glorified, the Emir of the Muslims, the Mujahid in the path of the Lord of the Worlds, Al-Ghani Billah (He who is rich by Allah), the Victorious by the aid of Allah, the Sanctified and Late Abu Abdullah Muhammad, son of our Master the Emir of the Muslims and Vicegerent of the Lord of the Worlds, the Great Mujahid Sultan, of Noble Virtues and Praiseworthy Deeds, the Suppressor of Infidels and Conqueror of Regions, the Great and Magnificent, the Late Sanctified and Blessed Abu al-Hajjaj Yusuf, son of our Master the Emir of the Muslims, the Mujahid in the path of the Lord of the Worlds, the Pride of Kings and Sultans, the Strengthener of Islam and its people, singled out for happiness in all his affairs, the Magnanimous and Great, the Brave and Long-suffering, the Enduring and Virtuous, the Sanctified and Late Blessed Abu al-Walid Ismail bin Nasr; may Allah connect their good fortunes, guard their existence, and facilitate their goals and purposes in every endeavor.
And regarding our Master—may Allah grant him victory—the King of the World upon whom consensus and agreement have settled, and harmony has been achieved, and whose beautiful conduct is spoken of by companions, such that the Levant and Iraq yearn for him; Yemen is encompassed by his authority, victory smiles from his spearhead, success ties his banner, and praise weaves his cloak. Thus, Allah—Glory be to Him—made Jihad his emblem, and following the path of guidance his nature. Through him, the island of Andalusia returned to a sanctuary safe from the incitements of sedition and protected from the hardships of grudges. By the blessing of this Magnanimous Hero, the religion of Islam became clear in this Andalusian region, its corners populated, its blessings abundant, its growth guaranteed, its joys preserved, and its harms blocked. Praise be to Allah who honored his state above all states and made the kings of the earth his followers and servants.
Indeed, one of the greatest benefits in value, most noble meanings in mention, and most successful endeavors in command, is to raise a noble art of knowledge to the station of a majestic king; that is what obligated this servant to compile this book, summarize it, refine it, and scrutinize it. It includes combat and fighting, horses and weapons, what qualities are chosen in them, and what marks are disliked and blamed, and everything related to the condition of the mount, including instruction on riding and achieving the objective.
I gathered this book from a collection of works and selected it from various classifications, such as the book 'Yaqzat al-Na'is li-Tadrib al-Mujahid al-Faris' (The Awakening of the Sleepy for the Training of the Knightly Mujahid), the book 'Tahdhib al-Im'an fi al-Shaja'ah wa al-Shuj'an' (Refinement of Deep Thought regarding Bravery and the Brave), the book 'Rahat al-Qulub wa al-Arwah fi al-Khayl wa al-Silah' (Comfort of Hearts and Spirits regarding Horses and Weapons), the book of 'Al-Dimyati on Horses', the book 'Risalat al-Faras' (Epistle of the Horse), and the book 'Taba'i' al-Haywan' (Natures of Animals) by Aristotle; in addition to other works which were not written down here due to the scarcity of what was quoted from them, or parts that were not attributed due to their small size.
It came, by the praise of Allah Almighty, sufficient in its art, and healing in its style and meaning, a reminder for those concerned with Jihad, and an insight for the masters of jousting and combat. I named it 'Hilyat al-Fursan wa Shi'ar al-Shuj'an' (The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave), and I divided it into twenty chapters:

Chapter One
The Creation of Horses, the First to Tame Them, and Their Spread in the Land
Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: 'When Allah Almighty intended to create the horse, He said to the South Wind: "I am creating a creature from you, and I will make it a glory for My allies, a humiliation for My enemies, and a protection for the people of My obedience." The Wind said: "Create." So He grasped a handful from it and created a horse. He said to it: "I have named you a Horse (Faras), created you as an Arab, tied goodness to your forelock, and made spoils of war gathered upon your back. Glory is with you wherever you are. I have preferred you over other beasts, made you a master over them, inclined your owner affectionately toward you, and made you fly without wings; you are for pursuit and for escape. I will place upon your back men who glorify Me, magnify Me, and declare My Oneness; you glorify when they glorify, magnify when they magnify, and declare greatness when they declare greatness." He said: "There is no glorification, magnification, or declaration of oneness that its owner utters and the horse hears, but that it responds with the like."
Then he said: "When the angels heard the description of the horse and saw its creation, they said: 'O Lord! We are Your angels; we glorify You, magnify You, and declare Your Oneness, so what is for us?' So Allah created piebald horses for the angels, having necks like the necks of Bactrian camels, with which He reinforces whomever He wills of His prophets and messengers. He sent the horse to the earth, and when its feet settled upon it, it neighed. He said: 'Blessed are you as a creature! By your neighing, I shall humiliate the polytheists, strike terror into their hearts, fill their ears, and humble their necks.' Then, when He presented to Adam all things He had created and he named them by their names, He said to him: 'Choose from My creation what you wish.' So he chose the horse. Allah said to him: 'You have chosen your glory and the glory of your children, lasting as long as they last, and remaining as long as they remain; My blessing is upon you and upon them, I have not created a creature more beloved to Me than them.' Then He marked it with a blaze (star) and white legs, and that has been so ever since."
The author of the book 'Al-Hayawan' said: "It is in the nature of the horse to be vain in its walk; it loves its groom and admires its rider. It does not like children. It is jealous, and it recognizes calamity." Al-Asma'i mentioned that a demented man came to Abu Amr bin Al-Ala and said: "O Abu Amr, why were horses (Khayl) named 'Khayl'?" Abu Amr paused, having no answer, and said: "I do not know!" The man said: "But I know!" Abu Amr said: "Teach us so we may know!" He said: "Because of their vanity (Ikhtiyal) in walking." Abu Amr said to his companions after the man turned away: "Write down wisdom and narrate it even from a madman."

text:
Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, said: David, the Prophet of Allah and His vicegerent on His earth, loved horses intensely. He would not hear of a horse mentioned for its nobility, beauty, or speed but that he would send for it, until he gathered a thousand horses. At that time, there were no others on earth. When Allah took David's soul, Solomon inherited him and sat in his father's seat. He said: "David did not leave me any wealth more beloved to me than these horses." So he trained and groomed them. One day he called for them and said: "Display them to me so I may know them by their markings, names, and lineages." He began inspecting them until he prayed the Noon (Zuhr) prayer. The time for the Afternoon (Asr) prayer passed while he was displaying them—there was nothing among them but magnificent racers—and they distracted him from the prayer until the sun set and was hidden behind the veil. Then he realized and remembered the prayer. He sought forgiveness from Allah Almighty and said: "There is no good in wealth that distracts from the remembrance of Allah and from prayer! Bring them back to me!" Nine hundred had been displayed, and one hundred remained. They brought back the nine hundred, and he began striking their shanks and necks in sorrow for missing the Asr prayer time. One hundred horses remained which had not been displayed to him; he said: "This hundred is more beloved to me than the nine hundred that tempted me away from my prayer." So he kept them. Allah Almighty said: {And to David We gave Solomon. An excellent servant, indeed he was one repeatedly turning back [to Allah]. When there were displayed before him in the afternoon the poised [standing] steeds. He said, 'Indeed, I gave preference to the love of good [things] over the remembrance of my Lord until the sun disappeared into the curtain [of darkness].' 'Return them to me,' and set about stroking [their] legs and necks.} The hundred that did not distract him from the remembrance of Allah, he left them alone, and he remained admiring them until he passed away. Horses to this day are the descendants of that remaining hundred.
Ibn al-Kalbi said: It is said that Allah Almighty brought out for him one hundred horses from the sea that had wings, and those horses were called 'Al-Khayr' (The Good). Solomon, peace be upon him, used to bet on them and race them; nothing was more amazing to him than them.
It was narrated that Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, said: The first of those horses to spread among the Arabs was when a group of the Azd tribe from the people of Oman came to Solomon son of David, peace be upon him, after his marriage to Bilqis, the Queen of Sheba. They asked him about what they needed regarding their religion and worldly affairs, until they accomplished what they wanted and intended to leave. They said: "O Prophet of Allah! Our land is far, and we have run out of provisions, so order provisions for us that will reach us to our land." Solomon gave them a horse from David's horses and said: "This is your provision! When you camp, mount a man on it and give him a spear, then gather firewood and kindle your fire, for you will not gather your firewood and kindle your fire before he comes to you with game." The group began not stopping at any campsite without mounting a man on their horse with a spear in hand, gathering firewood, and kindling their fire; they would wait only a little while until their companion came to them with game such as gazelles, wild donkeys, and wild goats, bringing them what sufficed them and more. The Azdites said: "This horse of ours has no name but 'Zad al-Rakib' (The Rider's Provision)." That was the first horse to spread among the Arabs from those horses. So the origin of the stallions of the Arabs is from its offspring.
Others claimed that when Solomon son of David, peace be upon him, wiped their necks and shanks, three horses flew away from him when he was killing their fathers. One horse landed in Rabi'ah, one horse in Khushayn, and one horse in Bahra'. They bred them with their horses, which were slower mixed-breeds (Hujun). When those horses produced offspring, they flew back to the sea, and the horses reproduced from one another.
Al-Waqidi narrated that the first to ride horses was Ishmael son of Abraham, peace be upon them. He said: Horses were wild animals that could not be ridden until they were made subservient to Ishmael. He was the first to rope them, ride them, and breed them.
From Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: Horses were wild beasts like other wild beasts. When Allah Almighty permitted Abraham and Ishmael, peace be upon them, to raise the foundations of the House (Kaaba), Allah Almighty said: "I am giving you a treasure I have stored for you." Then Allah Almighty revealed to Ishmael to go out and call for that. Ishmael went out to Ajyad, which was a place near him, not knowing what the supplication or the treasure was. Allah Almighty inspired him with the supplication, and there remained no horse on the face of the earth in the land of the Arabs but that it answered him and allowed him to take it by its forelock, and Allah humbled it for him. Ibn Abbas said: "So ride them and tie them, for they are blessed, and they are the inheritance of your father Ishmael."
Section: On the Ways of Keeping Them

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
Abu Hurairah narrated that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Horses are of three types: for one man they are a reward, for another a covering (shelter), and for another a burden (sin). As for the one for whom they are a reward, he is a man who keeps them for the sake of Allah. If he comes across a river and waters them from it, for every drop that enters their bellies he has a reward. If he comes across a meadow and they graze in it, for everything that enters their bellies he has a reward, and for every step they take he has a reward." He even mentioned the reward for their dung and urine. "As for the one for whom they are a covering, he is a man who keeps them for beauty and dignity, yet does not forget Allah's right regarding their backs or their necks. As for the one upon whom they are a burden, he is a man who keeps them out of arrogance, vanity, and showing off to people, and does not fulfill the right of their backs or bellies."
Khabbab narrated that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Horses are three: a horse for the Most Merciful, a horse for Man, and a horse for Satan. As for the horse of the Most Merciful, it is what is kept for Allah in the path of Allah, and upon which the enemies of Allah are fought. As for the horse of Man, it is what is used for breeding and needs. As for the horse of Satan, it is what is wagered and gambled upon."
Anas bin Malik said: "When Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf settled down and the war ended, we went out until we came to Wasit." He mentioned meeting Al-Hajjaj and Al-Hajjaj displaying his horses to him. He [Anas] said, may Allah be pleased with him: "Horses are three steeds: A horse its owner keeps intending to strive upon it; so in his care for it, feeding it, and training it—I think he said: and sweeping its stall—there is a reward in his scale on the Day of Resurrection. And a horse whose owners benefit from its offspring, seeking the countenance of Allah; their care for it, feeding it, training it, and sweeping its dung is a reward in their scale on the Day of Resurrection, and its owners are aided regarding it. And a horse for Satan; its owners care for it—and he mentioned other things—it is a burden in their scale on the Day of Resurrection."
The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Stick to female horses, for their backs are a fortress, and their bellies are a treasure."
It was said to a wise man: "Which wealth is most abundant?" He said: "A mare, followed by a mare, with a mare in her belly."
Adi bin al-Fadl said: A man asked the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, "Which wealth is best?" He said: "A pollinated row of palm trees, or a prolific filly." 'Sikkah Ma'burah' means a row of palm trees, and 'Mahrah Ma'murah' means one with many offspring.
They claimed that the house of the Commander of the Faithful Ali, which was in Kufa, belonged to Urwah bin al-Ja'd. He sold it for a female horse and gained much wealth from that horse. Mention of Urwah will come later.
Umar bin Abi Anas said: Sa'd said: "O Messenger of Allah! I have horses." The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Keep them, breed the stallions with them, and keep the females among them; you will attain the high degrees of Paradise." Sa'd used to do that.
Khalid bin Safwan used to say regarding keeping animals: "As for horses, they are for terror and awe; as for workhorses (Baradhin), they are for beauty and ease; as for mules, they are for distant travel; as for camels, they are for carrying loads; and as for donkeys, they are for creeping along and light provision."

Chapter Two
Virtues of Horses and What Has Been Said Regarding Keeping Them
Allah Almighty swore by horses in His Great Book due to their excellence in His sight. He, Glory be to Him, said: {By the racers, panting,} up to His saying {Indeed mankind, to his Lord, is ungrateful.} The commentators said: The 'racers' (Al-Aadiyat) are horses; 'panting' (Dhabha) is the sound of their breathing when they run. {Striking sparks of fire} (Al-Muriyat Qadha): meaning they strike fire with their hooves. {And scouring to the dust} (Fa-atharna bihi Naq'a): Naq' is dust, and it is said soil. {Arriving thereby in the center collectively} (Fa-wasatna bihi Jam'a): meaning they centered themselves in a gathering of people they raided. {Indeed mankind, to his Lord, is ungrateful} (La-kanud): meaning unthankful.
He also named them 'Good' (Khayr) in His Book through the tongue of His Prophet Solomon son of David: {Indeed, I gave preference to the love of the Good [horses] over the remembrance of my Lord.}
The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, preferred them over men in the distribution of shares; he assigned two shares for the horse and one share for the man.
Many hadiths have come from him, peace be upon him, regarding their virtue. From Abdullah bin Umar, the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Goodness is tied to the forelocks of horses until the Day of Resurrection." This hadith was narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Al-Nasa'i.
Muslim also narrated from Urwah that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Goodness is tied to the forelocks of horses until the Day of Resurrection." It was said: "O Messenger of Allah! And what is that?" He said: "Reward and spoils of war." The mentioned Urwah is Ibn Abi al-Ja'd al-Bariqi. The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, had given him a dinar to buy a sheep for him. He bought two sheep with it, sold one for a dinar, and came to him with a dinar and a sheep. The Prophet prayed for blessing for him, so even if he bought dust, he would make a profit from it. Shabib bin Gharqadah said: "I saw ninety horses in the house of Urwah bin Abi al-Ja'd due to his desire for keeping horses."
Muhammad bin al-Muntashir said: "He had a horse he took for twenty thousand."

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
From Jarir bin Abdullah, he said: I saw the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, twisting the forelock of his horse with his two fingers and saying: "Goodness is tied to the forelocks of horses until the Day of Resurrection." They said: In his twisting, peace be upon him, of his horse's forelock, there is merit in a man serving his beast prepared for Jihad, and it is evidence that Jihad remains established until the Day of Resurrection, and implied is the permanence of Islam and the Mujahideen defending it until the Day of Resurrection.
From Abu Kabshah, he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Horses, goodness is tied to their forelocks until the Day of Resurrection, and their owners are aided regarding them; the one who spends on them is like the one stretching out his hand with charity." In another wording: "Horses, in their forelocks is goodness until the Day of Resurrection, and their owners are aided regarding them; so wipe their forelocks and pray to Allah for blessing for them."
From Sawada bin al-Rabi' al-Jarmi, he said: I came to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and he ordered a herd for me and said to me: "Stick to horses, for indeed goodness is tied to the forelocks of horses until the Day of Resurrection."
From Asma bint Yazid, the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Horses, goodness is tied to their forelocks forever until the Day of Resurrection. Whoever keeps them as preparation for the path of Allah, then their satiety and their hunger, their quenching and their thirst, and their dung and their urine are success in his scales on the Day of Resurrection. And whoever keeps them for showing off and reputation, and out of vanity and arrogance, then their satiety and hunger, their quenching and thirst, and their dung and urine are loss in his scales on the Day of Resurrection." The forelock is the hair flowing over the forehead, and it may be a metonym for the self (soul); it is said: So-and-so has a blessed forelock, meaning self.
From Anas bin Malik, he said: There was nothing more beloved to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, after women, than horses.
From Zaid bin Thabit, he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, saying: "Whoever keeps a horse in the path of Allah, it will be his shield from the Fire."
From Abu Hurairah, from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, he said: "Whoever keeps a horse in the path of Allah out of faith in Allah and belief in Allah's promise, its satiety, its quenching, and its dung will be good deeds in his scale on the Day of Resurrection."
Ibn Sa'd narrated in 'Al-Tabaqat' saying: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "The one who spends on horses is like one stretching his hand with charity not withdrawing it; and their urine and dung are with Allah on the Day of Resurrection like pure musk."
Abdul Rahman bin Ziyad recounted that when the Muslims settled in Egypt, they had a rolling area for horses. Hudayj bin Sawmi passed by Abu Dharr, may Allah be pleased with him, while he was letting his horse, Al-Ajdal, roll. He said: "What is this horse, O Abu Dharr?" He said: "This is a horse of mine which I deem to be answered (in prayer)." He said: "Do horses pray and get answered?" He said: "Yes! There is no night but that the horse prays to its Lord in it, saying: 'O Allah, You have made me subservient to the son of Adam, and placed my provision in his hand, so make me more beloved to him than his family and his wealth. O Allah, provide for him through me and provide for me at his hands.'"
Abu al-Hasan al-Iskandar narrated that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Jesus, son of Mary, met Iblis (Satan), may Allah curse him, and said: 'O Iblis! I am asking you about something, will you be truthful to me regarding it?' He said: 'O Spirit of Allah! Ask me whatever appears to you.' He said: 'I ask you by the Living who does not die! What is it that wastes your body and breaks your back?' He said: 'The neighing of a horse in the path of Allah, and in a village of villages or a fortress of fortresses; and I do not enter a house in which there is a horse for the path of Allah.'"
From Ata' al-Khurasani, he said: Allah rewards the servant for his love of horses even if he does not keep them.
The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever intends to keep a horse in the path of Allah with a sincere intention is given the reward of a martyr."
From Ubada bin al-Samit, he heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "Indeed, a horse may run in its tether while its owner is asleep in his bed, and no sin remains for him but that it falls away."
From him, peace be upon him, that he said: "Whoever keeps a horse in the path of Allah has the like of the reward of the fasting person who does not break fast, and the standing person (in prayer) who does not slacken; and the one stretching his hand with charity is likewise regarding what he spends on his horse."
From him, peace be upon him, that he said: "Whoever has many bad deeds and few good deeds, let him keep a horse in the path of Allah. Whoever keeps one in the path of Allah is like the one who aided Moses and Aaron, and fought Pharaoh and Haman."
From Qais bin Babah, he said: I heard Salman, may Allah be pleased with him, say: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: "There is no Muslim but that it is a duty upon him to keep a horse in the path of Allah if he is able to do so."

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
The Arabs in the Pre-Islamic period (Jahiliyyah) did not count wealth except as horses and camels, and horses had a merit over camels in their view. They did not equate anything else with them, nor did they see strength, glory, and protection in anything else, because with them they defended what else they owned, protected their sanctuaries, guarded their territory and heartland, raided their enemies, sought their revenge, and attained spoils. Thus, their love for them and their great standing among them was according to their need for them and their indispensability, and what they recognized of their blessing and good fortune; until Allah Almighty sent His Prophet Muhammad, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and honored his nation with the religion He guided them to, and bestowed upon them through him. He chose for His Prophet, peace be upon him, the preparation and keeping of horses for striving against His enemy; so He, Glory be to Him, said: {And prepare against them whatever you are able of power and of steeds of war by which you may terrify the enemy of Allah and your enemy and others besides them whom you do not know [but] whom Allah knows.} regarding the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, concerning this verse: {and others besides them whom you do not know [but] whom Allah knows}, he said: "The Jinn; and Satan will not create illusions for a person in whose house is a noble horse."
So the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, acquired horses, kept them, loved them, and encouraged the Muslims to keep them, informing them of the reward and recompense involved. They hastened to do so and increased their eagerness for them and in keeping them, desiring the reward and seeking blessing and goodness in this world and the Hereafter, in acquiring, breeding, and caring for them. They competed for them and paid high prices, due to the types of blessings and collections of goodness Allah placed in them.
It is said: Among the virtues of horses is that they are the most patient of animals and the most intense in strength, and the lightest of all beasts in provision regarding feed and drink when matters are tight in that regard, as a little suffices them in detachments, deserts, and travels. Then we compared them in strength: we found the strongest of beasts and most capable of heavy loads to be the camel. We found the strong, full-grown camel carries at most a thousand pounds (ratl); if it carries this amount, it does not rise except with effort and trickery, and we saw that it does not run with its load. Likewise, all other beasts described with strength do not run with their loads. We found that wild animals described with intense running, if they carried a heavy load, would not perform a tenth of their running. So we understood that the horse carries its rider, his gear, weapons, armor, provisions, fodder, and a flag if it is in its owner's hand on a windy day, approximately a thousand pounds, and runs with it for a whole day, hardly tiring, nor emptying due to hunger or thirst. Thus, we knew that no beast is stronger, more patient, better, more excellent, nobler, or more powerful than horses.
Allah Almighty revealed two verses in the Great Quran regarding keeping them and spending on them: His saying Almighty: {Who is it that would loan Allah a goodly loan so He may multiply it for him many times over}, and His saying Glory be to Him: {Those who spend their wealth by night and by day, secretly and publicly - they will have their reward with their Lord. And no fear will there be concerning them, nor will they grieve.}
Abu Umama, Abu Darda, Makhul, Al-Awza'i, and Rabah bin Yazid said: "They are those who keep horses in the path of Allah." From Ibn Abbas: {Those who spend their wealth by night and by day, secretly and publicly}: he said: "It was revealed regarding fodder for horses."
It was narrated that Abu Dharr pointed to some horses in the open ground and said: "The owners of these are the ones who spend their wealth by night and by day, secretly and publicly." Abu Hurairah used to recite this verse if he passed by a fat horse, and if he passed by a lean horse, he would remain silent.

Chapter Three
Preserving Horses, Protecting Them, and Recommendations Regarding Them
Know that past nations never ceased to increase their care for horses, honoring them, trusting in them, relying on them in their wars, and boasting of keeping them. Although the Arabs exceeded them in their merit and advantage, surpassing the nations, such that in the Pre-Islamic period nor in Islam did they protect any of their wealth like their protection of horses, nor honor it like their honoring of them, due to the boasting, pride, competition, multiplication, strength, defense, glory, and elevation they found in them.

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
Our Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was among the most desirous of Arabs for horses and the most protective of them, and the most honoring and admiring of them, to the extent that he would find comfort in their neighing, prefer them over men in the shares he allotted to them and wagered on them, and forbade breeding their noble ones with a donkey or a mixed-breed whose origin did not resemble theirs, out of jealousy for them and fear of corrupting their lineage. The Prophet, peace be upon him, had recommended them and was admonished for being occupied at one time with inspecting them.
It came from Ismail bin Rafi': "The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, woke up one day and went to his horse, wiping its neck and face with the edge of his cloak or the sleeve of his shirt. It was said to him: 'O Messenger of Allah! We see you doing today what we have not seen you do before?' He said: 'I spent the night with Gabriel admonishing me regarding the management of horses.'"
From Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: "She went out one morning while the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was wiping his horse with his garment. She said: 'O Messenger of Allah! With your garment?' He said: 'How would you know? Perhaps Gabriel admonished me regarding it last night.' She said: 'Then assign me its fodder.' He said to her: 'You want to take all the reward! He informed me that my Lord writes a good deed for me for every grain.'"
It was said: "While the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was at the night of Tabuk, he stood by his horse, Al-Zarib, fed it barley, and began wiping its back with his cloak. It was said: 'O Messenger of Allah! You wipe its back with your cloak?' He said: 'Yes, and how would you know? Perhaps Gabriel ordered me to do that, especially since I spent the night with the angels admonishing me regarding grooming horses and wiping them. He said: My friend Gabriel informed me that he writes a good deed for me for every grain I give it, and that my Lord removes a bad deed from me because of it. No Muslim man keeps a horse in the path of Allah and gives it full fodder seeking strength for it, but that Allah writes a good deed for him for every grain and removes a bad deed from him because of it.'"
From Muhammad bin Uqbah from his father from his grandfather, he said: We came to Tamim al-Dari while he was handling his horse's fodder with his own hand. We said to him: "O Abu Ruqayyah! Do you not have anyone to suffice you in this?" He said: "Yes, but I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: 'Whoever keeps a horse in the path of Allah and handles its fodder with his hand, will have a good deed for every grain.'"
From Umar bin Abdul Aziz, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: It is established from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, that he said: "Whoever has an Arab horse and honors it, Allah honors him; and whoever humiliates it, Allah humiliates him."
From Mujahid, he said: "The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, saw a person hit his horse and said: 'This (hand) with that (horse)? Let the Fire touch it.' He was spoken to about it, and he said: 'No, unless he is fighting in the path of Allah.' The man began to charge with it saying: 'Bear witness! Bear witness!'"
The Arabs, due to the value of horses to them and their cherishing of them, would retaliate against anyone who slapped a horse and would shame them for it, seeking revenge for it as they would for themselves. They would not slap it like the slap of a camel. Hammad al-Rawiyah mentioned this from Simak bin Harb. Al-Jarrah al-Hamdani said regarding that:
"And a noble mare, the offender is slapped for slapping her... As if she were the shadow of a garment amidst spears."
Umar bin Abdul Aziz, may Allah be pleased with him, forbade galloping horses except for a right cause.
From Al-Wadin bin Ata, he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Do not lead horses by their forelocks, for you will humiliate them." He, peace be upon him, also said: "Keep horses, wipe their forelocks and rumps—or he said: their croups—and place garlands on them, but do not garland them with bowstrings."
They used to garland horses with bowstrings so that the evil eye would not afflict them, so he, peace be upon him, forbade them from that and informed them that strings do not avert anything of Allah's decree. It was also said he forbade them from that out of fear the horses might choke. It was also said strings refer to vengeances (Dhuhul), meaning blood: i.e., do not seek upon them the vengeances you sought in the Pre-Islamic period. The first opinion is more correct.
From Anas bin Malik from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, he said: "Do not cut the tails of horses, nor shear their manes and forelocks; their warmth is in their manes, and their tails are their fly-swatters." He, peace be upon him, said: "Do not make the backs of your animals into pulpits, for Allah Almighty only made them subservient to you to carry you to a land you would not have reached except with great difficulty, and He made the earth for you, so fulfill your needs upon it."
Makhul said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Honor horses and cover them (keep them warm)." He, peace be upon him, forbade the castration of horses.

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
From Thawr bin Zaid, he said: When the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, raided Tabuk, he acquired a horse from Judham. He mounted a man from the Ansar on it and ordered him, when he dismounted, to dismount near him, out of longing for it and desire for its neighing. When the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, arrived, he met the Ansari and said: "What did the horse do?" He said: "We castrated it." He said: "You have mutilated it, you have mutilated it, you have mutilated it! Their manes are their warmth, their tails are their fly-swatters; seek their offspring, and boast with their neighing against the polytheists."
From Ali, may Allah be pleased with him: "A mule was gifted to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, so he rode it. I said: 'If we were to breed donkeys with horses, we would have the likes of this!' He, peace be upon him, said: 'Only those who do not know do that.'"
From Abu Umama, he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Admonish horses (train/discipline them), for they accept admonition." Meaning, discipline them and train them for war and riding, for they become disciplined and accept the admonition.
It is told of Luqman the Wise that he said to his son: "O my son! If you travel, do not sleep on your beast, for sleeping on it hastens sores on its back. If you alight in land with vegetation, give it its share of the pasture; and begin with watering and feeding it before yourself."
Thus, honoring horses, protecting them, caring for them, competing for them, preserving them, inspecting their conditions, and attending to what improves their management is obligatory. It is upon the noble man to attempt the affairs of his horse with his own hand; no shame attaches to him by attending to its matter; rather, blame attaches to him for neglecting its affair, and he deserves censure for keeping away from it out of pride and relying on others for it. The knight should not neglect inspecting his horse, its place, its tether, its rolling area, and all its conditions regarding its management, feed, and water. Let his greatest care be looking at its legs in all conditions, feeling them with his hand. If he sees a spasm in a nerve, a sign of swelling or fullness, a mark of blood, or the slightest ailment, let him hasten to treat it and handle it gently at its onset. He should not tire it while it has it, nor run it that day, for ailments may appear slight and hardly visible, but if he rides it, they may become major, or a destructive cause may arise from them. Treating it at its beginning is closer (to success) and its matter is easier.
Let him be extremely cautious of giving it water and feeding it barley immediately after exhaustion and fatigue. Let him wait until it calms down, its sweat dries, and it rests completely. Likewise, he should be cautious of feeding much barley with long rest, idleness, and lack of movement and activity. Also, he should be cautious of mixing wet grass with dry in its fodder as much as he can. Necessity has its own rules where one looks for the most suitable of what is available. Measure (analogy) and you will be correct by the power of Allah.

Chapter Four
What the Arabs Name of the Horse's Body Parts and the Number of Bird Names Included Therein
Its top is its *Sarat* (back/upper part). In its *Sarat* is its *Qarah* (spine/backbone), consisting of *Sanasin* (vertebral processes), singular *Sinsinah*, which is the head of the rib at the vertebrae. In its *Sarat* are its *Hajabatan* (points of the hips), which are its *Harqafatan*; the *Harqafah* is the upper head of the hip, which protrudes if the animal is emaciated. In its *Sarat* is its *Qatah* (croup/rump), and the *Qatah* is the seat of the *Ridif* (pillion rider); the *Ridif* is the rider behind the knight, also called *Radif*. In its *Sarat* are its *Mawqifan* (flanks/standings), and the *Mawqifan* are the top of its flanks between the *Hajabatan* and the rear rib. In its *Sarat* is its *Kathibah* (withers/base of neck), and the *Kathibah* is the place of the middle of the saddle at its front. In its *Sarat* is its *Mansij* (withers), and the *Mansij* is the place of the pommel (*Qarbus*), which is where the branches of the shoulders meet the front of the withers (*Kahil*), hence it is called *Mansij*. In the *Sarat* is the *Udhrah*, which is the hair of the *Kathibah*, and it is the end of the *Urf* (mane). In the *Sarat* is the *Urf* (mane), which is the hair of its neck between its *Udhrah* and its *Nasiyah* (forelock).
From its *Sarat* is its *Nasiyah* (forelock) connected to the mane; the *Nasiyah* is the hair flowing over its eyes and face up to the tip of its mane from the front. The *Urf* is the name of the hair specifically; and the *Ma'rafah* is the place where the mane grows. Flanking the *Ma'rafah* are two veins called the *Ilbawan*, singular *Ilba*. In its *Sarat* is its *Ra's* (head) and *Hamah* (crown/skull). As for its *Hamah*, it is the 'Mother of the Brain' (*Umm al-Dimagh*) and what encircles its head by its ears. The *Hamah* is called Mother of the Brain because it encompasses it like a mother encompasses her child. In it is the *Qamahduwah* (occiput), which is the back of the neck, and it is the protruding bone from the back of the head. The *Qafa* (nape) of the horse is the seat of its headstall from the growth of its mane. The *Simam* of the horse are the reeds of its nose cartilage containing the cartilage (*Ghadarif* or *Gharadif* - inverted). Some Arabs say: they are its *Sumum*. It is also said they are two veins in its nose. In any case, *Simam* is a name for the honeycomb-like structures of the cartilage.

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
As for the *Nawahiq* of the horse, they are two veins in its nose. Abu Zaid al-Ansari said: Its *Nawahiq* are the bridge of its nose. Ibn Qutaybah said: They are two protruding bones in its face lower than its eyes. Abu Ubaidah agreed with him on that, and it is the correct view. The *Lihyan* are the two jawbones under the cheeks; and their tapered end under the mouth are the *Sabiyan*. The *Madighan* (chewing muscles) are the upper parts of the jawbones where movement occurs during chewing, near the ears. The *Lahzimatan* are the gathering of flesh between the chewing muscles and the ears. The *Fakkan* (jaws) are the meeting point of the two jawbones with the temples. As for its lips, they are its *Jahfalatan*. As for its *Mankhiran*, they are the exit of breath (nostrils). As for its *Nukhirah*, it is what is above its nostril from the tapered part of its muzzle and the soft part of its nose. As for its cheeks (*Khaddah*), they are the sides of its face.
In its *Sarat* (back) is its *Sisa'*, and the *Sisa'* is the place of the middle of the saddle. The *Sahwah* is the middle of the back to the *Qatah* (croup). In its neck is its *Labbah* (throat/upper chest), *Salifah* (sides of the neck), and *Jiran* (throat/underside of neck). As for its *Labbah*, it is the place of the breastplate. As for its *Salifatan*, they are the sides of the neck. The hole in the skull where the neck is attached is called the *Fahqah*, which is the vertebra whose end is in the head. The *Fahqah* is the end attached to the skull, and it is somewhat round like the knob of a Kohl container. In it is a hole which is the exit of the spinal cord from the brain. The brain is called *Al-Salil*. As for its *Jiran*, it is the skin between the chin and the slaughter point (*Madhbah*). The combination of the windpipe (*Hulqum*), esophagus (*Mari'*), and jugular veins (*Awdaj*) is called the *Baldham*. The esophagus is the entrance for food and drink, and the windpipe is the exit for breath and sound. The *Urshan* are two muscles from the heads of the shoulders to the mane, and they are the pillars of the neck. In the neck is the *Dasi'*, which is where the camel regurgitates its cud; it is the insertion of the neck into the shoulders. In the neck is its *Qasarah*, which is what is close to the withers (*Kahil*). In the neck is the *Salifah*, which is the place of the necklace; the *Salifah* is one thing, encompassing the neck from every side near the slaughter point. The *Hadi* is the neck in its entirety, named so because it precedes the rest of the body. In the neck are the *Wadajan* (jugular veins), which are two veins flanking the neck right and left; the jugulars are also called *Shawarib*. The *Asalah* of the neck is the place of the necklace on it.

Section
Its *Bark* is its chest, and its *Ju'ju'* is its *Zawr*. The chest is what is wide from the meeting of the upper arms and the base of the neck. The *Zawr* is what is between the upper arms to the place of the girth. The *Jawz* of the horse is the seat of the rider on its back and what aligns with it of its body; the *Jawz* of anything is its middle. The entire seat of the rider is called the *Sahwah* (as mentioned before). The location of the saddle panels on the *Sahwah* is called the *Ma'addan*. What the girth encloses is the *Mahzim*. Below the *Mahzim* to the flanks are the *Markalan*, which are the place of the rider's heels, named *Markalan* (kicking places) for that reason. They are the *Jawanih*. The *Farisatan* are the return of the elbows from the *Daff*, and the *Daff* is the side. The return of the elbows is the contraction of the heart. Then the *Dulu'* (ribs), which are twenty-four ribs. In the ribs are the *Qusrayan*, which are the two ribs in the sides, the lowest and deepest of the ribs. One is the end of the right side, and the other is the end of the left side; they call them the ribs of the *Khalaf*. Next to them are the *Shakilatan* (flanks), which is what connects the thighs to the flanks. The *Qusrayan* are called the *Wahinat*. The two ribs next to the *Wahinat* are called the *Da'iatan*. The middle ribs, four on each side, are called the *Haraj*, which are the vaulted ones; they are the longest and most complete ribs, and towards them the cavity expands.

Section
The areas of its belly are called *Rabad* (abdomen). In the *Rabad* of its belly are its *Manqab*, *Surrah* (navel), *Qunb* (sheath), *Rufghan*, *Shakilah*, *Taftafatan*, *Haliban*, and *Sifaq*. As for the *Rabad* of the belly, it is the soft parts of the belly. As for its *Manqab*, it is where the vet punctures near the navel. As for its *Qunb*, it is the sheath of its penis. As for its *Rufghan*, it is what is between the testicles and the thighs. As for its *Shakilah*, it is between its thighs and its belly (flank); it is the part that is judged for fatness in sheep and cows. As for its *Taftafatan*, it is what is between the side and the hip bone. As for the *Haliban*, they are two veins flanking the navel. As for the *Sifaq*, it is what is between the skin and the intestines (*A'faj*). The belly of the horse contains intestines and coils; it has no rumen (*Karish*). The *Haqwan* (loins) are what the *Qusrayan* enclose, and from which the *Hajabatan* (hip bones) recede. In the *Qunb* of the horse is a *Nadiyy*, a *Fayshalah*, and an *Ihlil*. As for the *Nadiyy*, it is the entire penis, also called *Ghurmul*. As for the *Fayshalah*, it is the glans (head) of the penis, as it is in humans.

As for the *Ihlil* (urethra/canal), the horse has two: the opening between the testicles where the penis retracts is an *Ihlil*, and the opening at the head of the penis which is the exit for urine is an *Ihlil*. Every male animal shares this (second) *Ihlil*, while only four-legged males share the first one. The sound of the penis in its sheath during the horse's movement is called *Al-Khadi'ah*; it is also said *Khadi'ah* is the sound of the horse's belly. The skin of the testicle is called *Al-Safn* (scrotum). In the *Safn* are the *Baydatan* (testicles). In the body of the horse is the *Quhquh*, which is the meeting of the hips from the inside, and its interior is the *Khawran*, and its exterior is the *Dubur* (anus), which is what is between the *Quhquh* and the *Us'us*. The *Us'us* (coccyx) is the end of the spine and the root of the tail. The top of the *Us'us* is called the *Ajb*, and its bottom is the root of the tail. The thick part of the base of the tail is its *Ukwah*. Next to the *Ukwah* is the *Asib*, and they are the bone of the tail. The tapered part of the tail is called *Sha'ilah* (of the tail). The *Sabib* is the *Hulb* of the tail, which is its hair; this is what Abu Zaid al-Ansari said, but what is known among linguists is that *Sabib* is the hair of the forelock and mane, and the tail hair is *Hulb*.

Section
Connected to the front of the horse are its *Yadahu* (two hands/forelegs). In its forelegs are its *Katifahu* (shoulders). In its shoulders are their *Ayrahuma*, *Ghurdufahuma*, *Akhramahuma*, and *Sadqahuma*. As for the *Katif* (shoulder), it is known; it is the wide bone at the top of the shoulder joint (*Mankib*). As for their *Ayrahuma*, it is the ridge rising from the shoulder bone, protruding in the middle of the shoulder. As for their *Akhramahuma*, it is the end of their *Ayr* where they end at the *Sadqan*. As for the *Sadqan*, they are two depressions at the head of the shoulders. In the *Ghurdufan* of the shoulders at their tops are the *Naghdhan*, which are the *Ra'inatan*, consisting of much flesh at the bottom of the *Ghurdufan*. As for the two pieces of flesh at their tops, they are the *Farisatan*. The *Ghurduf* is what is at the edge of the shoulder connected to the shoulder but not of it; as if it is bone but not bone; it is also called *Ghudruf* (cartilage). In its forelegs are its *Mankibah* (shoulders joints), and its *Mankibah* are what joins the bottom of the withers (*Kahil*) from the front of the breastbone (*Qass*) at the top of the *Zawr*. The *Kahil* is what appears of the *Zawr*, and the *Zawr* is what is hidden of the *Kahil*. In its forelegs are its *Adudah* (upper arms). In its upper arms are the *Qabihan* and the *Wabilatan*. As for the *Qabihan*, they are the heads of the upper arms meeting the forearms. As for the *Wabilatan*, they are the heads of the upper arms near the shoulders; they are two large bones with *Mushash* (spongy bone/flesh). In its forelegs are its *Dhira'ahu* (forearms). In the forearms are the *Mirfaqan* (elbows), which are the *Ibratan* (needles). As for the *Radf* of its knees, it is what is between the cannon bone (*Kura'*) and the forearm, small gathered bones at the head of the forearm. The *Ibrah* (needle) of the forearm is the tapered end that rubs against the end of the *Farisah* of the shoulder and the middle of the chest bones just above the girth. The *Daghisah* (patella/knee cap) is a small bone, nearly round, above the knee; it moves (yadis) meaning it goes back and forth. Then the *Wazifan* (cannon bones). In its cannon bones are its *Qaynahu*. The *Wazif* is what is under the knees to the pasterns (*Arsagh*). As for the *Qaynan*, they are the ulna/shin of the cannon bones. In the *Wazif* is the *Ujayah*, which is a long sinew in the cannon bone ending at the *Rusgh* (pastern). As for the *Abjal*, it is a vein hidden in the forearm to the throat (*Nahr*); it is called *Nahir* in the throat and *Abjal* in the forearm. The *Rusgh* is the end of the *Ujayah*. In the foreleg are the *Raqmatan*, which are two rings in the bellies of the forearms appearing like cauterization marks. In it are the *Thunnatan*, which are the hair above the *Umm al-Qirdan*. In the foreleg is the *Ash'ar*, plural *Asha'ir*, which are the ends of the hair at the hoof. In the forelegs are the *Fusus*, which are the joints of its knees and pasterns. In them are the *Sulamiyat*, which are the bones of the pasterns. The *Shawa* refers to the limbs (legs). The top parts of the horse are called its *Sama'* (Sky), and its lower parts its *Ard* (Earth). Then the *Hafir* (hoof). In the hoof are its *Dakhis*, *Nusur*, *Hawami*, *Hawashir*, *Dawabir*, *Sunbuk*, and *Insiyyu*. As for the *Hafir*, it is a collective name, like the *Zilf* (cloven hoof) of a sheep. As for its *Dakhis*, it is a bone inside the hoof like its lining. As for its *Nusur*, they are what are in the bottom of the hoof like the lines of the palm. As for the *Dabirah* of the hoof, it is its rear, which wears down and touches the ground. As for the *Sunbuk*, it is the front of the hoof (toe). As for the *Hawami*, they are what flank the *Sunbuk* on its right and left. As for the *Hawshab*, it is the pastern bone entering the hoof like an arrowhead. As for its *Insiyyu*, it is the inner side of the hooves of its forelegs and hindlegs facing each other. As for its *Wahshi*, it is the outer side of the hooves of its forelegs and hindlegs.

Section
Connected to the rear of the horse are its legs (*Rijlahu*), and in them are its *Warikahu* (hips). In the hips are their *Harqafatahum*a, *Hariqatahuma*, *Nuqratahuma*, and *Qawwaratuhuma*.

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
As for its hips (*Warikahu*), they are the two upper bones in the rump (*Ajuz*), and below them is the *Quhquh*, and between that is the *Khawran*, which is the *Dubur* (anus). As for their *Harqafatan*, they are the two protruding bones where the hips are suspended. The *Ja'iratan* are the ones flanking the tail on the right and left; they are the place of the *Raqmatan* in the donkey. In the thighs of the horse are the *Hamatan*, *Kadhatan*, and *Hadiban*. The *Hadiban* are below the tail, two lumps of flesh on the outside of the thighs. The *Kadhatan* align with them on the inside of the thigh next to the flank (*Shakilah*). The *Hamatan* are at the ends of the thighs next to the shanks (*Saqayn*), and above them are the *Rablatan*. The *Ghuraban* are two bones in the middle of the hips. The *Nuqratan* are two nerves at the head of the thigh. The *Nasa* (sciatic nerve) is a vein in the inside of the entire leg. The *Ra's al-Nasa* is at the top of the *Sala*, which is a depression called the *Qalt*. Then the thigh (*Fakhidh*) has *Khasa'il* (singular *Khasilah*), which is gathered flesh. For every *Khasilah* there is a *Gharr*; the *Gharr* is a groove between the two muscles as if it separates them. In the leg are the *Thafintan* (stifles), which are the joint of the thighs into the shanks; they are two nerves appearing like two bones. Then the *Saqan* (shanks). In the shanks are the *Naqwan*, which are the two bones containing the marrow; the name of the marrow is *Naqi*. In them are the *Hamatan*, which are two lumps of flesh on the outside of the shanks. In them are the *Urquban* (hocks), which are the two joints connecting to the cannon bones (*Wazifatan*). Between the shank and the cannon bone are the *Ka'ban* (ankles), which are two bones at the end of the shank and the end of the cannon bone (*Kura'*). Then the *Wazifan* (cannon bones), which are the place of the *Shikal* (hobble) on the animal's leg. In the *Wazif* is its *Ujayah*, which is a nerve supporting the entire leg, and the *Rusgh* (pastern), which is the joint between the shank and the cannon bone. There are two cannon bones, two pasterns, and two *Ujayas*.

Section
Parts of the horse are named after birds: The *Hamah* (Owl/Head), *Nasr* (Vulture/Frog of hoof), *Na'amah* (Ostrich/Brain membrane), *Farkh* (Chick/Brain), *Surad* (Shrike/Vein under tongue), *Usfur* (Sparrow/Forelock base), *Dik* (Rooster/Bone behind ear), *Salsal* (Dove/White spot), *Dajajah* (Hen/Chest flesh), *Nahid* (Young Eagle/Shoulder flesh), *Ghurr* (Coot/Thigh muscle), *Sumana* (Quail), *Ghurab* (Crow/Hip bone), *Khuttaf* (Swallow), *Samamah* (Swift), *Saqr* (Falcon), *Qatah* (Sandgrouse/Rump), *Hurr* (Falcon/Ear spot), *Hida'ah* (Kite), and *Kharab* (Male Bustard).
Al-Asma'i narrated that Harun al-Rashid had a black horse named *Al-Rabidh*, and he was delighted with it one day. He said: "O Asma'i! Take the forelock of *Al-Rabidh* and describe it from its *Qawnas* (top of head) to its *Sunbuk* (hoof toe), for it is said it contains twenty bird names." I said: "Yes, O Commander of the Faithful! And I will recite for you a poem gathering them by Abu Hazrah." He said: "Recite it to us, may God bless your father!" So I recited:
'Lean like the wolf, perfect is he... Between his *Hamah* (head) and the *Nasr* (hoof frog)
His *Na'amah* (brain membrane) is wide and his *Farkh* (brain) abundant... And the two *Surads* (tongue veins) are established in the throat
He exceeds with the *Usfur* (forelock base) in a flowing forelock... A high *Ham* (head) with a firm root
His *Salsal* (white spot) is adorned by the two *Diks* (bones behind ears)... And his *Dajajah* (chest flesh) protrudes from the chest
The two *Nahids* (shoulder muscles) command his sturdy build... As if they were set upon a fracture
With sweeping sides, healed... Between his nature (*Shimah*) and the *Ghurr* (thigh muscle)
His *Sumana* (quail/part) and his hoof are described... And his skin and hair roots
The *Ghurab* (hip bone) rose to its two locations together... So I distinguished between them by measure
And his *Khuttaf* (swallow) hid beneath his upper arm... And his *Samamah* (swift) distanced itself from the *Saqr* (falcon)
And his *Qatah* (rump) advanced ahead... So it distanced its location from the *Hurr*
And rising above its strength, below its *Hida'ah* (kite)... Are two *Kharabs* (bustards) with a span between them
He leaves the stony ground when he runs, split... By twins like brown branding irons
Mounted in pure limbs, lanky... Efficient in leaping, strongly bound.'
