text:
The *Hamah*: The top of the head, which is the mother of the brain; it is one of the names of birds, and has been mentioned previously. The *Nasr*: It is what rises from the bottom of the hoof and from its top, resembling date pits and pebbles; it is one of the names of birds (Vulture), and has been mentioned previously. The *Na'amah*: The skin of the horse's head that covers the brain; it is one of the names of birds (Ostrich). The *Farkh*: It is the brain; it is one of the names of birds (Chick). The *Suradan*: Two veins at the base of the tongue flanking the underside of the tongue, containing saliva and the breath of the lungs; they are one of the names of birds (Shrike). There is also a *Surad* in the back, which is whiteness in the place of the saddle resulting from a sore. The *Usfur*: The base where the forelock grows. The *Usfur* is also a protruding bone in each forehead side. The *Usfur* is also a type of blaze (*Ghurrah*), which is one that flows down and thins without crossing to the eyes and is not round like a *Qurhah* (star); it is one of the names of birds (Sparrow). The *Dik*: It is the protruding bone behind the ear, which is called the *Khushsha'*. The *Salsal*: Whiteness at the tip of the forelock, and it is said: rather it is the base of the forelock. The *Dajajah*: The flesh on its chest (*Zawr*) in front of it. The *Dik* (Rooster), *Salsal* (Dove), and *Dajajah* (Hen) are names of birds. The *Nahidan*: Singular *Nahid*, which is the flesh of the shoulders; it is said: it is the flesh next to the upper arms from their tops. The *Nahid* is the chick of the eagle; it is one of the names of birds. The *Ghurr*: In the horse, it is the muscle of the shank; and in birds, it is what is also called *Rakhama* (Vulture/Coot). It has been mentioned previously. The *Sumana* (Quail) is one of the names of birds; Ibn Abd Rabbih said: It is a place on the horse I do not recall. The *Ghurab*: The head of the hip; the *Salawan* are called the *Ghuraban*, which flank the root of the tail. It is said: They are the meeting point of the tops of the hips; it is one of the names of birds (Crow), and has been mentioned previously. The *Khuttaf*: One of the names of birds (Swallow); it is where the rider's heel reaches if he moves his legs. These two places are also called the *Markalan*. The *Samamah*: A whorl on the neck of the horse; it is one of the names of birds (Swift). The *Saqr*: I reckon it is a whorl on the head, but I am not certain of it; it is one of the names of birds (Falcon). The *Qatah*: The seat of the pillion rider; it is one of the names of birds (Sandgrouse), and has been mentioned previously. The *Hurr*: Of birds, it is said to be the male pigeon/falcon; in the horse: blackness on the outside of its ears. The *Hida'ah*: Of birds (Kite); its origin is with a Hamza, but it was lightened for necessity; it is the side of the horse's neck (*Salifah*). The *Kharab*: It is what you see like a depression in the hip of the horse; of birds, it is the male Bustard.

Chapter Five
On the Desirable Qualities in the Body Parts of the Horse and What Animal Attributes It Is Good for Them to Resemble

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
Beauty in all parts of the horse is linked to quality and is an indication of nobility (*Itq*) and strength; the combination of these is generosity (*Karam*). Rarely do they all gather in a single horse, but its share of generosity is according to what it possesses of them.
Among the admired qualities of the parts is the length of the head profile (*Nasl*); its length is the distance between its forelock and its lip. Also, the width (*Harat*) of its jaw-splits (*Shidqan*); the *Shidqan* are the slit in the mouth to the ends of its jawbones, and *Harat* is the length of their slit, to enable it to expel breath. Also, the thinness of its lips (*Jahafil*) and their smoothness; the *Jahafil* are what it grasps fodder with, singular *Jahfalah*. Also, the length of its tongue for abundance of saliva; abundant saliva is desirable for comfort. Also, the thinness of its nose tip (*Arnabah*); the *Arnabah* is between its nostrils; this is for beauty and indicates nobility. Also, the width (*Ruhb*) of its nostrils, their thinness, the length of their slit, the length of their tops, and the width (*Harat*) of their bottoms; width is for quick relief (breathing), and thinness is for beauty. Also, the fineness of its muzzle (*Mustat'am*); the *Mustat'am* is between its noseband area (*Marsin*) to the tip of its lip; this is for beauty. Also, the closeness of the two jaw tips (*Sabiyyan*), which are the meeting of their ends from below; this is for beauty. Also, the fineness and delicacy of its noseband area (*Marsin*), which is the place of the halter on its nose; this is for beauty. Also, the straightness of its nose bridge, which is between its *Khulayqa* (where the forehead meets the nose bridge from the front); this is for beauty. Also, the thinness of the sides of its nose and their smoothness; the sides are what descend from the nose bridge on both sides; this is for beauty and evidence of nobility. Also, the thinness of its *Nawahiq* (veins/sides of nose) and that they do not spread across its face; their thinness means lack of flesh and adherence of skin to them; this is for beauty and indicates nobility. Also, the bareness of its *Sumum*; the *Sumum* is what is thin of hard flesh on the sides of the nose bridge from their tops to the *Nawahiq*, which are the tear ducts; this is for beauty and indicates nobility. Also, the elongation (*Isalah*) of its cheeks, their smoothness, and their width; *Isalah* means their length; this is for beauty and indicates nobility. Also, the width of its *Shajr* (space between jaws); the *Shajr* is what is between its jawbones from their bottoms; this is for the width of its airway. Also, the thinness of its eyelids, which cover the eyes from top and bottom; this is for beauty and indicates nobility. Also, the width (*Najal*) of its eyes, their clarity, and intense blackness; *Muqlatan* are the eyes, *Najal* is their width; this is for beauty. Also, the distance of its gaze and its sharpness; this is for true resolve. Also, the blackness of its eye sockets (*Waqbah*), and the distance of its eyes from its ears; the *Waqbah* are the depressions above its eyes. The thinness of its eyebrow indicates its nobility. Also, the width of its forehead, its bareness, and the adherence of its skin to it; the forehead is what is below its ears and above its eyes on its skull. Also, the length of its ears and their firmness (*Jalad*), meaning the fineness of their folding; this is for beauty. Also, the thinness of the ears, their softness, and their tapering (*Tatreeq*); *Tatreeq* is pointing, which is the thinness of their tips; this is for beauty and indicates nobility. Also, in the ears, their intensity (alertness); this is for truth and resolve. Also, the smoothness of its forelock, its length, intense blackness, and softness. Also, the softness of the *Shakir* (hair around the forelock) and its settling in its roots; *Shakir* is the short hair surrounding the forelock, which indicates nobility. Abu Ubaidah said: It is the clearest witness in the horse to its nobility; if roughness is found in it, it is not free from mixed breeding (*Hujnah*). Also, the length of its neck between its forelock and its *Udhrah* (withers hair); the *Udhrah* is the mane hair on its withers; this is for its beauty and strength, and the horse's aid by it in running. I mean the *Unuq* (neck), which is feminine (grammatically). Abu Ubaidah said: The male is more in need of neck length than the female. Abu Ubaidah only said that because the male's neck is thick, so its length completes its nobility and beauty, whereas the female's neck is thin, so its length weakens it and takes away its beauty. Ibn Qutaybah said: "Length and softness are desirable in the neck, while shortness and stiffness are disliked." It is mentioned regarding the definition of desirable length that Sulayman bin Rabi'ah distinguished between thoroughbreds and mixed breeds by the necks; he called for a basin of water placed on the ground, then horses were brought to it one by one. Whichever bent its hoof (*Sunbuk*) then drank, he deemed a mixed breed, and whichever drank without bending its hoof, he deemed a thoroughbred. Also, the thinness of its throat (*Madhbah*), which is where the neck ends near the head; this is for beauty.

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text: Also, the fineness of its *Salifah* (sides of the neck); the *Salifah* is what thins from the top of its neck to its occiput (*Qadhal*) behind its *Khushashawayn*; the *Khushashawan* are the two protruding bones behind its ears; this is for beauty and indication of nobility. Also, the height of its *Ilbawan* (neck tendons) and the strength of their insertion into the withers; the *Ilbawan* are two nerves under the *Urshan* (manes base). This is stronger for connecting the neck to the withers. The elevation (*Ifra'*) of the *Ilbawan* is their height, which is more beautiful to look at in their slope. Also, the width of its neck at its base, and the loose movement of its *Jiran* (throat); this comes from the height of the *Ilbawan* and the descent of the *Jiran*; this is for the strength of the neck. The *Jiran* is what separates its esophagus and windpipe from the skin of the inside of its neck; this allows a wider exit for its breath. Also, the rising of its *Hadi* (neck/chest front), and its *Hadi* is its neck; this is for strength and beauty. Also, the height (*Ifra'*) of its shoulders at its withers and their concealment in it from their tops; their *Ifra'* is their elevation in its withers. Also, the bareness of its *Akhraman* (shoulder points) and their sharpness; the *Akhraman* are the heads of the shoulders from the side of the upper arms; their bareness is lack of flesh, and their sharpness is their pointedness. If they are like this, the distance between its shoulders widens, its breast becomes spacious, as well as between its ribs for the exit of breath, and the joint of the upper arms into the shoulders becomes strong. Also, the protrusion of its *Ma'addan* (flesh behind shoulders) and abundance of their flesh; the *Ma'addan* is the thick flesh gathered in its sides behind its shoulders, which is the place of the saddle panels. This is desirable for their strength and the expansion of the ribs beneath them for its breathing at the place of the *Rablatan*, because they are the limit of panting; if their place is narrow and they swell, they compress the heart and smother it, causing distress. Abu Ubaidah said all of this. Also, the shortness of its back; the limit of the back is from the end of its withers at the bottom to between the *Qusrayan* of its spine. Also, the straightness of its spine (*Sulb*); its straightness is its evenness and the width of its vertebrae (*Fiqar*); *Fiqar* is plural of *Faqrah*, which are the beads of the back, also called *Mahal*; this is desired for strength and beauty. Also, the smoothness (*Lahb*) of its back muscles (*Matnayn*); *Lahb* is the leanness of flesh; a horse is *Malhub*. Abu Ubaidah said: It may be *Akhta* (muscular), which is strong; *Khaza* is the elevation of the flesh of the back muscles over the spine and its firmness. Others said: The *Malhub* tolerates panting better than the *Akhta*. Also, that it be wide-bellied (*Rahib al-Jawf*). Also, the vaulting (*Ijfar*) of its sides; *Ijfar* is the curvature of their ribs from the top, their width and length; width and length (*Subugh*) of ribs are desirable. Also, the spaciousness of its hide (*Ihab*), meaning its skin. Also, the indentation of its *Mawqifan* (flanks); the *Mawqifan* are what enter from the middle of the flank to the end of the *Atrah* (hip edge); this is for strength. Also, the strength of its *Haqw* (loin); the *Haqw* is the joint of its spine into its rump, encompassing what appears and what is hidden. Its width, abundance of flesh, levelness of flesh with the back, and closeness to its *Atrah* are also desirable. Also, the elevation of its *Qatah* (croup) and abundance of its flesh; the *Qatah* is the seat of the pillion rider behind the horseman; this is for the strength of the connection of its rump to its spine. Also, the elevation of its *Hajabatan* (hip bones), their sharpness, and the distance between them; the *Hajabatan* are its *Harqafatan*. Also, the width of its hips (*Warikan*), abundance of their flesh, their length, and the adherence of skin to them. Abu Ubaidah said: Having a slight slope (*Safh*) in them is truer for running; *Safh* implies width in a slope, taken from the slope of a mountain. He said: Squaring is better for them in appearance. The width of the hips is better for them than length. Also, the strength of its *Ajuz* (rump) and its thickness without excessive height or depression; this is for strength. Abu Ubaidah said: Its best state is the medium between depression and protrusion. Also, the fullness (*Istifar*) of its *Barkah* (chest) in its throat area. The *Barkah* is from where the *Fahdatan* (breast muscles) join at their tops to what is below the upper arms, to the folds of the forearms on their inside. Also, the protrusion of its *Ju'ju'* (breastbone); the *Ju'ju'* is the meeting of its *Fahdatan* at their bottoms; the *Fahdatan* are the two protruding muscles in its chest. Also, the width of its *Baldah*; the *Baldah* is the end of the *Fahdatan* from their bottoms to its upper arms. Also, the flabbiness (*Rahal*) of its chest, *Barkah*, *Ju'ju'*, *Fahdatan*, and *Baldah* (meaning loose skin/capacity); this makes the chest stronger and shoulders more open. Also, the shortness of its upper arms (*Adudan*), so that its shoulders protrude and its elbows tuck in; for if they are short, they push the shoulder joint into them followed by the forearm, so they tuck in; if they are long, they raise the head of the forearm so its elbows stick out, which causes its forelegs to separate more. The upper arms are the two bones between its shoulder and forearms.

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text: Also, the descent of its *Qass* (sternum); the *Qass* is what is between the *Ruhabah* (xiphoid cartilage) to the end of the bottom of the *Fahdatan* and the end of the *Falak* (curve) of the chest (*Zawr*), where the *Jawanih* end and the ribs separate; this provides longer ribs and more complete capacity. Also, the length of its forearms (*Dhira'an*) and their thickness (*Abalah*); the forearms are between the upper arms and knees. Also, the looseness of its *Mardaghah* and the greatness of its *Nahid*; the *Mardaghah* is the flesh at the base of the upper arms from behind, next to the *Farisah*; the *Nahid* is the muscle of the upper arm bulging above it; the larger, stronger, and thicker it is, the better. Also, the abundance of folds between the upper arms and *Fahdatan*, and the inside of the forearm and armpits from the skin; this allows more extension for its forelegs when running. Also, the fineness of its *Zawr* (chest) from the place of the elbows and its bareness (leanness). Also, the greatness of the bone of the forearms, the thickness of their cords (*Hibal*), and the visibility of their grooves (*Ghurur*); the cords are the visible nerves on them, and the grooves are between the cords, which are the paths separating the muscle bundles. Also, the fineness of its knees, the intensity of their *Sumum* (pores/hardness), the tightness (*Ikrab*) of their bind (*Asr*), and the closeness between them; this is for strength and less fatigue, because they are the joint between the forearm and cannon bone; if they are (tight), their fatigue is slower. Also, the shortness of the cannon bones (*Wazif*) of its forelegs, their width, the curvature of their *Qaynan* (shin bones), the adherence of their skin to them, lack of filling (edema/fat), and the spread of their nerves, their width and thickness. Also, the fineness of its *Jubbah* (fetlock joint) and its leanness (*Tamahhus*); the *Jubbah* is the meeting of the cannon bones and the top of the pastern bone (*Hawshab*). Also, the smallness of the *Ujayah* (ergot/ligament), lack of flesh, concealment of nerve in it, and smallness of its *Qama'ah*; the *Ujayah* is the rear of the fetlock where the nerves of the forelegs separate; in it is the growth of the *Thunnah* (fetlock hair), and the *Qama'ah* is the tip of the *Ujayah* inside the *Thunnah* which does not grow hair. Also, the tightness (*Ikrab*) of its pasterns (*Rusgh*), their thickness (*Abalah*), and having some thickness/curvature (*Ghalab*); the pastern is between the fetlock and the coronet (*Ash'ar*); its *Ikrab* is the strength of its bind; *Abalah* is thickness; *Ghalab* is convexity with thickness. Also, the width of the bottom of the *Hawshab* (pastern bone) from the place of *Umm al-Qirdan*; the *Hawshab* is the bone of the pastern, and *Umm al-Qirdan* is the depression inside it; this is for strength. Also, the largeness of its hoof, the wideness of its *Hawami* (walls), and sharpness of its toe (*Sunbuk*). Also, the distance of the heel (*Alyah*) of its hoof from the ground; the *Alyah* is the flesh at the top of the walls from the rear of the coronet; this is desirable for endurance against striking the ground and carrying the weight above, combining strength with beauty. Also, abundance of flesh on their *Kadhata* (thigh insides) and width of their *Fa'il* (femoral groove); the *Fa'ilan* are the whorls of the thighs below the *Kadhatan*. Also, the greatness of the *Rablatan* (thigh muscles); the *Rablatan* are the meeting of the inside of the thighs at the top consisting of flesh; this is desirable for the complete strength of the thighs, upon which it relies in running. Also, the insertion (*Tawlij*) of its stifles (*Thafinatan*), which is the joining of one to another and adherence of skin on their heads; the *Thafinatan* are the insertion of the thighs into the top of the shanks. Abu Ubaidah said: This is desirable because if they are inserted, it gathers its legs better in movement, strengthens them for the weight above, and makes it more enduring for long galloping; this is due to their gathering and entering under the weight of its body. Their inversion and protrusion are disliked due to weakness, for if the legs' stifles are inverted, their lifting widens and the area under the body becomes empty due to their opening, causing faster fatigue and weaker legs. Also, the shortness of its shanks (*Saqayn*) and their width; curvature (*Tahnib*) in them is desirable, as is the greatness of their *Hamatan* (muscle lumps) and their protrusion; the *Hamah* is the gathered flesh protruding in the middle of the outside of the shanks; and the bareness of their insides from flesh, which is the visibility of their *Nasa* (sciatic nerve); the *Nasa* is a vein inside the shank between the *Hamatan* and ankles. All of this is desirable for the intense contraction of the legs in running, strong kicking (*Dharh*) with them, and speed of leaping (*Dabr*). Also, the smallness of its ankles (*Ka'ban*), their firmness (*Sama'*), adherence of skin to them, and bareness of their *Manjiman*; the ankles are between the cannon bones and shanks; *Sama'* is their hardness and compactness; the *Manjiman* are two protruding bones inside the ankles. This is because the ankle is a joint needing strength due to the prolonged striking of the ground with the leg and intense gripping; if not so, it will not leap well. Also, the sharpness of its hocks (*Urquban*), their alignment with the nerve of the rear of its legs, and strong adherence of skin to them; this is desirable for strength and leg contraction.

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
Also, the length of its cannon bones (*Wazifayn*) and their width when viewed from the side, their sharpness and thinness when viewed from the front, and their straightness when viewed from behind. All of this is desirable for strength and endurance in running, allowing the hind legs to catch up with the forelegs. What is desirable in the forelegs regarding the description of pasterns and hooves is also desirable in the hind legs, except that the uprightness of the pasterns in the hind legs is forgivable, whereas it is not so in the forelegs.

Section
It is desirable for the horse to resemble certain animals in some of its anatomy. These include the gazelle, the dog, the wild donkey, the bull, the ostrich, the camel, the hare, the wolf, and the fox. From the gazelle, it is desirable for the horse to have: length of the rear cannon bones, sharpness of the hocks, greatness of the thighs and abundance of their flesh, greatness of the hips, strength of the back muscles and spine, vaulted sides, shortness of upper arms, width of eyes, and tucked-up flanks. From the dog, it is desirable to have: wide jaw-split, long tongue, abundant saliva, descending sternum, long ribs, long forearms, and tucked-up belly. It is recounted that Muslim bin Amr sent a cousin of his to Syria and Egypt to buy horses for him. He said: "I have no knowledge of horses," but he was a hunter. Muslim asked: "Are you not an owner of dogs?" He said: "Yes!" Muslim said: "Then observe everything you admire in a patient dog and seek it in the horse." He said: So he returned with horses the likes of which were not found among the Arabs. From the wild donkey, it is desirable to have: thick flesh, dry joints, lean nerves, firm pasterns and their leanness, and wide back (*Sahwah*). From the bull, it is desirable to have: wide forehead with little flesh, loose throat skin, long forearms, and wide shoulders. From the ostrich, it is desirable to have: long cannon bones, short shanks, and bare *Aybas* (parts of legs). From the camel: long forearms and thick cannon bones. From the hare: small ankles. From the wolf: long/curved *Nasa* (sciatic nerve). From the fox: its *Taqrib* (a type of gait/canter). The first to compare horses to the gazelle, wolf, and ostrich was Imru' al-Qais bin Hujr, who said describing his horse:
"And I set out early while the birds are in their nests... On a short-haired steed, a shackle for wild beasts, huge.
A charger, a fleer, an advancer, a retreater, all at once... Like a boulder of rock brought down by the torrent from on high.
A dark bay, the saddle pad slips from the middle of his back... Just as the smooth stone lets the rain slide off.
Pouring (sweat/speed) when the swimming horses in fatigue... Stir up dust in the hard, kicked-up ground.
Boiling on the heels, as if his murmuring... When his heat boils up, is the boiling of a cauldron.
The light boy flies from his back... And he throws off the clothes of the heavy, rough rider.
Swift like the child's spinning top, spun... By the palms of his hands with a connected string.
He has the flanks of a gazelle, the legs of an ostrich... The gallop of a wolf, and the canter of a fox kit."
He repeated this comparison in another poem ending in 'Ba', saying:
"And I set out early while the birds are in their nests... And the dew water flows in every channel.
On a short-haired steed, a shackle for wild beasts, trimmed (lean)... By the chase of the valley, every distant limit.
Boiling despite fatigue, as if his back... With leanness and galloping is a high observation post.
Competing with the *Khanuf* (hyena/wolf) whose resolve is independent... You see his figure as if it were a wooden rack.
He has the flanks of a gazelle and the legs of an ostrich... And the back of a wild donkey standing on a lookout."
The poets adopted this comparison from Imru' al-Qais and followed it.

Chapter Six
Colors of Horses and Mention of Markings (Shiyat), Blazes (Ghurar), Leg White (Tahjil), and Whorls (Dawa'ir)
The root colors are four: White, Black, Red, and Yellow. In reality, the roots are White and Black, because Redness and Yellowness return to them and originate from them.

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
Mention of White: Pure white is *Ashhab Qirtasi* (Paper White). If mixed with yellowness, it is *Ashhab Sawsani* (Lily White). If mixed with redness, it is *Sinabi*. If mixed with blackness, it is *Hadidi* (Iron Grey). If whiteness dominates, it is *Kafuri* (Camphor White), also called *Ashhab Wadih* (Clear Grey/White). If it is white with spots of a different color, it is *Muwall'a*. If the spots are small, it is *Abqa'*. If the speckles are more numerous, it is *Mufallas* (Scale-like). If they increase further, it is *Mudannar* (Coin-like). If the spots are scattered on it, it is *Sham*, and the horse is *Ashyam*. If the dots are small and numerous, it is *Arqat*. If they are even smaller and more numerous, it is *Anmar* (Leopard-like). If they are extremely small, it is *Anmash* and *Abrash* (Flea-bitten). If they resemble stripes, it is *Mujazza'*. If the stripes are small, it is *Mughrab*.
Black: Pure black is *Adham*. If it is pitch black, it is *Ghayhabi*. If its blackness is intense to the point of striking green, it is *Akhdar* (Green/Black); this is *Dayzaj* in Persian speech. If it is between black and green, it is *Ahwa*. If redness mixes with its blackness, it is *Adbas*. If slight redness or yellowness mixes with it, it is *Ahamm*. If its blackness strikes towards whiteness approaching the color of ash, it is *Awraq*, similar to *Akhab*. Less than that in blackness is *Arbad*.
Redness: Pure red, if its mane and tail are black, is *Ward* (Bay), the female is *Wardah*, plural *Wirad*. If its redness is within blackness, it is *Kumait* (Dark Bay/Chestnut); the female uses the male form, and it is a diminutive form; one does not say *Kamt* or *Kumtah*. If its redness intensifies within blackness, it is *Kumait Mudamma* (Bloody Kumait). If the redness of the *Ward* yellows slightly without blackness, and its mane and tail are towards white, it is *Ashqar* (Chestnut/Sorrel). If its Kumait color is between black and white, it is *Ward Aghbas*, which is *Samand* in Persian. If its redness is coupled with blackness, it is *Asda'* (Rusty), taken from iron rust. If the blackness exceeds the redness slightly, it is *Ju'wah*, and the horse is *Aj'a*.
Yellowness: Pure yellow, if it is the color of gold, is *Asfar Faqi'* (Bright Yellow/Palomino/Dun). If its mane and tail are towards white, it is *Asfar Fadih*, which is mostly described as weak. If its mane and tail are black, it is *Asfar Mutarraf*. *Tatrif* (tipping) is blackness of the ears excluding the rest of the body of any color. If the yellow horse has black legs, it is *Armad* (Ashy). If it has a black stripe on its back, it is *Sahabi*, and that stripe is the *Sahabah* (cloud). If the legs of the yellow horse have black lines, it is *Muwasha*. If it has no marking or white (*Wadah*) of any color, it is *Musmat* (Solid) and *Bahim*. *Balaq* (Piebald/Skewbald) in horses is a weakness and a reduction in strength. Muhammad bin Salam said: No piebald male (*Ablaq*) or female (*Balqa'*) horse has ever won a race.

Section: On Markings (Shiyat)
The root of *Shiyah* is a sign/mark, derived from *Washy* (embroidery/coloring). Then every color differing from the main color of the animal became a *Shiyah*. From this is the Almighty's saying: {La shiyata fiha} (No blemish/marking in it), meaning no color differing from the rest of it. Horse markings are from this. Most horse markings are white, resembling blazes (*Ghurar*). Just as a *Ghurrah* is only white, so is the *Shiyah*. If the horse's ears alone are white, or have white dots but not completely white, it is *Dhur'ah*, and the horse is *Adhra'*, provided the horse is not Grey (*Ashhab*). In a Grey horse, it does not have a specific name unless it is black, which is *Tatrif*, and the horse is *Mutarraf al-Udhunayn* (Black-tipped ears). If the horse's head is white, it is *Asqa'*. If its nape is white, it is *Aqnaf*. If white mixes with its forelock hair, it is *As'af*. If its entire forelock is white, it is *Asbagh*. If its entire head is white, it is *Aghsha* and *Arkham*. If the head and neck are white, it is *Adra'*. If the back is white by nature, it is *Arhal*. If the whiteness of its back is from scars of sores, it is *Musarrad*, and that whiteness is *Surad* (plural), singular *Suradah*. If the belly is white, it is *Anbat*. If the sides are white, it is *Akhasaf* (Right or Left). If the rump is white, it is *Azar*. If there is white in the width of its tail, it is *Ash'al* of the tail. If some of its tail hair is white and some another color, it is *Mukhassal* of the tail, and *Mukhassal* of the mane if that is in the mane.

Section: On Blazes (Ghurar)

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
*Ghurrah* (Blaze): A general name for every whiteness on the face of a horse. Its limit in size is to be larger than a Dirham. If the whiteness on the face is the size of a Dirham or less, it is a *Qurhah* (Star), and the horse is *Aqrah*. The Arabs consider a *Qurhah* a bad omen if it is not accompanied by whiteness in another part of the limbs. If there is the slightest whiteness with the *Qurhah*, it exits the realm of dislike and becomes praiseworthy, as the poet said:
'Smooth-cheeked, noble, with no defect... Dark bay like the color of pure wine, *Arjal* (white-footed) and *Aqrah* (star-faced).'
He praised him for the *Qurhah* because he was also *Arjal*. If the whiteness in the face exceeds the size of a Dirham, it is *Ghurrah*. Its name is *Najm* (Star), which is the first rank of *Ghurar*. If it spreads over the forehead and fills it, it is *Shadikhah*, and the horse is *Ashdakh*. If it is round in its place and has another color in the middle, it is *Halqah* (Ring), and the horse is *Muhallaq*. If the spot inside the whiteness touches one of the sides of the whiteness, it is *Hilal* (Crescent), and the horse is *Muhallal*. If the blaze flows down and thins without crossing to the eyes, it is *Usfur* (Sparrow), and the horse is *Mu'asfar*. If it descends to the nose bone but does not reach the lip (*Jahfalah*), it is *Shimrakh* (Strip), and the horse is *Agharr Shimrakhi*. If the blaze fills the forehead but does not reach the eyes, it is *Shadikhah*, as mentioned before. If it covers the entire face but looks through black (eyes), it is *Mubarqa'ah* (Veil), and the horse is *Agharr Mubarqa'*. If it reaches the eyes such that the eyelids become white, that is *Ighrab*, and the horse is *Mughrab*. If it flows into one cheek but not the other, it is *Latimah*, and the horse is *Latim* (of the Right or Left). If one eye is blue and the other black (*Kahla*), it is *Akhyaf*; this is mostly found in the *Latim* horse, which is thus *Latim Akhyaf*. If the blue eye has no whiteness around it, but the whiteness is around the black eye, that is *Khawas*, and the horse is *Latim, Akhyaf, Akhwas*. Whiteness on the upper lip is called *Ratham*, and the horse is *Artham*; if it has a blaze connected to it, it is *Agharr Artham*. Whiteness on the lower lip is called *Lamaz*, and the horse is *Almaz*. If both lips are white, they say: *Artham, Almaz*. If both lips are black with a contrasting color, that is *Dagham*, and the horse is *Adgham*.

Section: On Leg Whiteness (Tahjil)

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
*Tahjil* is a marking (*Shiyah*) by derivation, as we mentioned previously. It was specifically given this name taken from *Hajl* (anklet), which is specific to the leg. So everything next to it or near it was named by it, by way of naming a thing by what neighbors it. If the whiteness of *Tahjil* reaches the knee of the foreleg and the hock of the hind leg, the horse is *Muhabbab*, and the name of that whiteness is *Jubbah*; the origin of *Jubbah* is the name for the joint of the cannon bone and the forearm. If the whiteness exceeds to the upper arms and thighs, it is *Ablaq Musarwal* (Piebald wearing trousers). If the whiteness is on a foreleg but not the hind legs, it is *A'sam*. If it is on one of them, it is *A'sam* of the Right or Left. If the whiteness is on the forelegs up to the elbows but not the hind legs, it is *Aqfaz*. If the whiteness is on the hind legs but not the forelegs, it is *Muhajjal*, and a horse is not called *Muhajjal* for any whiteness unless it includes the hind legs, due to the derivation mentioned. If there is whiteness on the forelegs along with that, it is called *Tahjil* due to association. If the whiteness is on the cannon bones of the forelegs excluding the limbs and pasterns, that is *Waqf*, and the horse is *Muwaqqaf*; this is specific to forelegs. If the like is on the hind legs or one hind leg, it is *Takhdim*, and the horse is *Mukhaddam*; this is also specific to the hind leg. If the whiteness is on the pasterns of the hind legs only, it is *Mukhalkhal*, also called *Mukhaddam*. If the whiteness is on the pasterns of the forelegs only, that is *Qayd* and the horse is *Muqayyad*. If the white pastern connects to the hoof, it is *Mukhaddab* (Dyed) of such-and-such foreleg or hind leg, or *Mukhaddab al-Arba'* (Dyed of the four) if on all legs. Any leg that is white is *Muhajjal*, and any leg without whiteness is *Mutlaq* (Free). One says *Muhajjal al-Ayamin* (White on right legs) and *Mutlaq al-Ayasir* (Free on left legs) or vice versa. If whiteness is on three legs and one is not white, it is *Muhajjal al-Thalath* (White of three), *Mutlaq* of such hand or leg. If whiteness is on a hand and leg of one side without the other side, it is *Mumsik al-Ayamin* (Holding the Rights) and *Mutlaq al-Ayasir*, or vice versa. The *Mumsikat* are those with white, and *Mutlaqat* are those without. If whiteness is on one hind leg, it is *Arjal*. Being *Arjal* alone is disliked by Arabs, but if accompanied by others, it is forgiven. If whiteness is on a hand and a leg diagonally, such as the right hand and left leg being white or vice versa, that is *Shikal*, and it is disliked. The horse is *Mushkal*. In the Hadith from Abu Hurairah: "The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, disliked *Shikal* in horses." Some people define *Shikal* as whiteness on one side without the other, like the right hand and right leg being white. This is what is called *Imsak*, as mentioned. Ibn Qutaybah said: "Some define Shikal as whiteness in three legs," but the derivation does not support that. The best is what we presented. If the tips of the hoof alone are white, it is *Aksa'*. If that is on a hand or leg, or two hands or two legs, it is *Aksa'* of such hand, leg, two hands, or two legs. If the fetlock hairs (*Thunan*) are all white but do not connect to leg whiteness, its case is like *Kasa'* in singular, dual, and plural. If the rear of the pasterns of hind or forelegs are white, and the white connects to the heel (*Alyah*) of the hand or leg, that is *Ni'al* (Sandals), and the horse is *Mun'al*, or *Mun'al* of a hand or leg, etc. *Sha'al* in the tail is whiteness in its width; if entirely white, it is *Asbagh* of the tail. This was mentioned in Markings.

Section: On Whorls (Dawa'ir)

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
These are the swirls of hair (*Nakhkhalah*) found on horses. Among them is the circle of *Al-Muhayya*, which is attached to the bottom of the forelock. Among them is the circle of *Al-Latah*, which is in the middle of the forehead. If there are two circles, they say *Faras Natih*. Among them is the circle of *Al-Lahiz*, which is on the jawbone (*Lahzimah*). Among them is the circle of *Al-Mu'awwidh*, which is at the beginning of the neck/necklace area. Among them is the circle of *Al-Samamah*, which is on the side of the neck (*Salifah*). Among them is the circle of *Al-Baniqayn*, which are the two circles on the horse's throat (*Nahr*). Among them is the circle of *Al-Nahir*, which is on the throat underside (*Jiran*). Among them is the circle of *Al-Qali'*, which is under the saddle pad; the name of that place is *Malbad al-Faras*. Among them is the circle of *Al-Haqa'ah*, which is on the width of its chest (*Zawr*); if the *Haqa'ah* is on both sides, it is *Al-Nafidhah* (Penetrating); the *Nafidhah* is the circle of the girth. Among them is the circle of *Al-Nakhis*, which is under the *Ja'iratan* (flanks near tail) towards the *Fa'ilan* (thigh grooves). They [Arabs] praise among the mentioned circles: *Al-Mu'awwidh* and *Al-Samamah*, and they dislike *Al-Natih*, *Al-Lahiz*, *Al-Qali'*, and *Al-Nakhis*. They used to praise the *Haqa'ah* because the most enduring horse is the *Mahqu'* (one with the Haqa'ah mark), until an Arab man wanted to buy a *Mahqu'* horse and its owner refused, but when he recited this verse, they disliked it. The verse says:
'If the *Mahqu'* sweats with the man... His wife becomes aroused and her lust intensifies.'

Chapter Seven
What is Praised in Horses, the Description of the Excellent Ones, and the Names of the Noble and Generous Among Them
Abu Qatada narrated from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, that he said: "The best of horses is the black (*Adham*), with a star (*Aqrah*), white on three legs (*Muhajjal Thalath*), free on the right foreleg (*Mutlaq al-Yamin*); if not black, then a dark bay (*Kumait*) with these markings."
Abu Wahb al-Jushami said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Stick to every dark bay (*Kumait*) with a blaze and white legs, or black (*Adham*) with a blaze and white legs."
From Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "The blessing of horses is in their sorrels (*Shuqr*)."
From Nafi' bin Jubayr from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, he said: "Blessing in horses is in every dark-greenish black (*Ahwa Ahamm*)."
From Amr bin al-Harith, he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "If the horses of the Arabs were gathered in one plain and then released, the winner would be a chestnut/sorrel (*Ashqar*)."
Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, asked the Abs tribe: "Which horses did you find most patient (enduring) in your wars?" They said: "The *Kumait* (Dark Bay)."
Sulayman bin Abdul Malik asked Musa bin Nusayr when he arrived from Andalusia: "Which horses did you see in those lands to be most enduring?" He said: "The *Shuqr* (Sorrels/Chestnuts)."
From Uqbah bin Amir, he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "If you intend to raid, buy a horse with a blaze and white legs, free on the right foreleg; you will be safe and gain spoils."

Section
Any horse that possesses these qualities is absolutely noble. It becomes authentic in lineage if it is also productive (*Munjib*). That is, it should be: Far, Near, Wide, Long, Short, Sharp, Spacious, Bare, Huge, Thin, Thick, Delicate, Narrow, Inserted.
Far between the lip and forelock. Far between the bases of the ears and their tips. Far between the ears and eyes. Far between the tops of the hip bones. Far between the forelock and the tail base (*Ukwah*). Far between the forelock and the withers hair (*Udhrah*). Far between the withers and the shoulder. Far between the upper arms and knees. Far between the armpits and groins. Far between the sides. Far between the hips and the flanks (*Ja'iratan*). Far between the hips and the stifles. Far between the hocks and the hips. Far between the false ribs.
Near between the nostrils. Near between the tips of the jawbones. Near between the shoulders and the hips. Near between the fetlock joints (*Jubab*). Near between the withers and the croup. Near between the *Ma'addan* (flesh behind shoulders) and the *Qusrayan* (rear ribs). Near between the flanks (*Ja'iratan*) and the tail base. Near between the stifles and the ankles. Near between the flanks and the hock tendons (*Ma'abid*). Near between the rear ribs and the hips. Near between the shoulder cartilages.
Wide forehead. Wide cheek. Wide neck base (*Qasarah*). Wide chest (*Barkah*). Wide cannon bones (*Awzifah*). Wide back (*Sahwah*). Wide side. Wide flank skin (*Sifaq*). Wide croup (*Qatah*). Wide hips. Wide thighs. Wide femoral grooves. Wide shoulders.

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
Long head profile. Long neck. Long forearms. Long shoulders. Long belly. Long hips. Long thighs. Long cannon bones of the hind legs.
Short upper arms. Short cannon bones of the forelegs. Short back. Short shanks. Short pasterns (all). Short flanks (*Janahayn*). Short joints (*Ma'aqim*). Short tail bone (*Asib*). Short hip edge (*Atrah*).
Sharp eyes. Sharp ears. Sharp shoulders. Sharp elbows. Sharp heart. Sharp hocks. Sharp ankle bones (*Manjiman*). Sharp withers. Sharp hip bones.
Spacious jaws. Spacious nostrils. Spacious throat (*Shajr*). Spacious hide. Spacious cavity (belly). Spacious chest (*Labban*). Spacious groin (*Ijan*); *Ijan* is the separation between the thighs.
Bare *Nawahiq* (nose sides). Bare forehead. Bare nose bridge. Bare chest (*Zawr*) at the girth place. Bare inside of shanks. Bare *Ghurab* (hip bone). Bare heads of stifles. Bare heads of hip bones. Bare withers. Bare *Sumum* (nose sides). Bare backs of ears. Bare soles of hooves.
Huge eyes. Huge thighs. Huge knees. Huge *Hamatan* (shank muscles). Huge hooves. Huge *Ma'addan* (sides). Huge *Nahidan* (upper arm muscles). Huge *Mardaghatan* (armpit flesh). Huge shoulders.
Thick (*Abl*) forearms. Thick cannon bones (all). Thick pasterns (all).
Thin nose tip (*Arnabah*). Thin nostril width. Thin eyelids. Thin eyebrows. Thin ears. Thin skin. Thin hair.
Thick flesh. Thick tail base (*Ukwah*). Thick milk veins (*Haliban*).
Delicate muzzle (*Mustat'am*). Delicate chest (*Zawr*) at the elbow place. Delicate joints (*Fusus*). Delicate frogs (*Nusur*). Delicate lips.
Narrow ear opening. Narrow between the jaw tips. Narrow armpits. Narrow heart. Narrow between the thigh muscles (*Rablatan*). Narrow groins (*Rafghayn*). Narrow frog placement.
Inserted stifles (*Muwallaj al-Thafinatan*), which are the insertion of the thighs into the top of the shanks, and the explanation of insertion has been given previously. With these qualities, generosity and nobility are found, and patience and winning usually follow.

Section
Al-Mahdi asked Matar bin Darraj: "Which horse is best?" He said: "The one that if you face it you say it is fleeing (*Nafir* - due to high head), if you view it from behind you say it is swelling (*Zakhir* - wide rump), and if you view it from the side you say it is carrying a load (*Zafir* - sturdy)." He said: "Which of these is best?" He said: "The one whose gaze is ahead of it, and whose whip is its rein (responsive)."
Someone asked: "Which horse is best?" He said: "The one that if you face it, it sits (looks low/crouched), if you follow it, it arrives (looks wide/ready), and if you view it from the side, it is straight/level."
An Arab asked two of his sons about which horse is best. One said: "The elegant steed, the noble stallion, the swift thoroughbred, the strong and reliable, that escapes if it flees and overtakes if it pursues." He said to the other: "What do you say?" He said: "Excellent describes the horse, by Allah! But another is dearer to me." He asked: "What is it?" He said: "The stallion racer, compliant to the lead, sharp-hearted, patient if restrained, a winner if it runs." *Hisan* is the male horse, *Kafit* is the swift.
Ibn al-Kalbi said: Five slave girls of the Arabs gathered and praised the horses of their fathers. One said: "My father's horse is *Wardah* (Rose), and what is *Wardah*! Possessor of a smooth croup, a smooth back, a hollow (capacious) belly, spirited breath, a casting eye, a kicking leg, and a swimming hand; her surprise is speed, and her consequence is victory." The second said: "My father's horse is *Al-La'ab* (The Player), and what is *Al-La'ab*! A pouring of a cloud, a burning of a forest, tightly jointed, high occiput, knit vertebrae, his rider is glorious, his game is ready; if he advances he is a swerving gazelle, if he retreats he is a waddling ostrich, and if he gallops he is a rushing wild ass." The third said: "My father's horse is *Hudhamah* (Cutter/Swift), and what is *Hudhamah*! If she advances she is a straight spear, if she retreats she is a round tripod stone, if she turns she is a leaping wolf; her pasterns are firm, her joints are dry; her run is pouring, her canter is swooping." The fourth said: "My father's horse is *Khayfaq* (Swift), and what is *Khayfaq*! Possessor of a lean cheekbone, a wide jaw, and smooth skin; she has a large build, a spacious neck base, and a sword-like neck; a leaping glider, a dusty shaker; her canter is rushing, her galloping is flashing." The fifth said: "My father's horse is *Hudhlul* (Light/Fast), and what is *Hudhlul*! His prey is trapped, his pursuer is hobbled, thin-lipped, secure-jointed, thick-girthed, ground-cleaving stone-thrower; high-withered, high-toed, braided muscles, smooth thigh-whorls, flexible neck, ringing neigh; his skin is pure, his forelock full, and his pardon is sufficient."
