text:
Interpretation of that: *Muzahlaq*: Smooth. *Akhlaq*: Smooth. *Akhwaq*: Wide. *Maruh*: Very spirited. *Taruh*: Far-sighted. *Dharuh*: Kicking/Pushing. *Sabuh*: As if swimming in its run. *Budahtuha*: Its sudden start. *Ihdhab*: Speed. *Aqb*: Run after run. *Ghilab*: Source of overcoming. *Ghabya*: A downpour of rain. *Ghab*: Forest. *Mutras*: Firm/Tight. *Ashamm*: High. *Mulahak*: Knit together; *Mulahaka* is fitting things together. *Mahal*: Back vertebrae, singular *Mahalah*. *Mujid*: Owner of a noble horse. *Atid*: Present/Ready. *Ma'aj*: Active, from Arab saying *Ma'aja al-faras* when it leans on the rein sides; also *Ma'aja* and *Amajah* meaning sped up. *Haddaj*: Active in *Hadaj* (swift/short steps). *Harraj*: Runs a lot. *Ilj*: Huge donkey. *Hudhama*: From *Hadhm* (speed). *Uthfiyyah*: Tripod stone for cooking. *Mulamlama*: Rounded. *Mu'ajrama*: Leaping; *Ajrama* is leaping like gazelles. *Mumahhasa*: Little flesh and hair. *Inthirar*: Pouring out profusely. *Khayfaq*: Fast. *Nahiqan*: Protruding cheekbones. *Mu'raq*: Lean. *Ashdaq*: Wide-mouthed. *Mumallaq*: Smoothed. *Ashdaf*: Huge bodied. *Dasi'*: Neck insertion into withers. *Munafnaf*: Wide. *Talil*: Neck. *Zaluj*: Fast. *Khayfanah*: Fast. *Rahuj*: Stirring much dust (*Rahaj*). *Ihmaj*: Exaggeration in running. *Irti'aj*: Frequent lightning (flashing). *Mahbul*: In a trap. *Mashkul*: In hobbles. *Malaghim*: Area around mouth (referring to lips). *Ma'aqim*: Joints. *Abl*: Thick. *Mikhadd*: Furrows the earth. *Mirjam*: Stones the earth with hooves. *Munif*: High. *Majdul*: Twisted/Braided. *Sabib*: Forelock hair. *Dafin*: Full/Complete. *Falil*: Gathered complete hair; a piece is *Falilah*. The noun *Faras* (Horse) applies to both male and female; you say "This is a Faras" (masculine) for a male, and "This is a Faras" (feminine) for a female.

Section
The Arabs established names for noble horses indicating their nobility and generosity in specific descriptions. Among them: *Al-Tarf* (The Noble/Rare), which is the beautiful, long horse, noble from both parents, which looks good to the eye. *Al-Lahmum*: Good, beautiful build, patient in running; nothing it chases outruns it, and nothing chasing it catches it. *Al-Unjuj*: Good build, beautiful form in length. *Al-Hudhlul*: Long, strong, large. *Al-Dhayyal*: Long-tailed. *Al-Haykal*: Huge build, beautiful appearance. *Al-Nahd*: Noble, huge, strong-limbed. *Al-Jurshu'*: Huge build, wide belly, wide ribs. *Al-Salhab*: Long body, long legs, split lower flesh. *Al-Ghawj*: Flexible sides. *Al-Khindhidh*: The large horse; it is a contranym, used for stallions and geldings. *Al-Khariji*: The noble racer from two mixed-breed parents. *Al-Muqrab*: Honored by its family, mixing with the household, kept close due to its value. *Al-Bahr* (The Sea): The one that runs a lot without tiring. The first to use this term was the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace; he rode a horse belonging to Abu Talha and said: "We found it to be a sea." *Al-Musawwam*: Singled out with a mark distinguishing it from others. *Al-Ajrad*: Short-haired; female *Jarda'*, plural *Jurd*. *Al-Shatb*: Beautiful figure. *Al-Aqwd*: Long-necked. *Al-Dhabur*: The one that puts its forelegs together when running, which is one of the best horse gaits; this gait is called *Dhabr*. *Al-Darim*: The horse that does not care if it runs on rough or smooth ground, like a blazing fire.

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
*Al-Sabih*: The one that extends its forelegs forward when running. *Al-Munaqil*: Quick in moving its legs in its run. *Al-Mutahham*: Complete, beautiful build. *Al-Tamuh*: High-looking, sharp-sighted. *Al-Shayzam*: Beautiful, long. *Al-Aqabb*: Tucked-up flanks, lean. *Al-Mujannab*: Far between legs without being bow-legged. *Al-Tamm*: Complete build, ready to run. *Al-Rajil*: The one that does not go barefoot (tough hooves). *Al-Sarhub*: The one that seems to scoop from the ground. *Al-Hidabb*: Much sweating. *Al-Qa'ud*: Compliant to its rider and groom. *Al-Aqdar*: The one whose hind hooves pass its fore hooves due to their length. *Al-Jamuh*: Energetic, fast; this is what Imru' al-Qais praised saying: "Impulsive (*Jamuh*), spirited... its galloping is like the roaring of burning palm fronds." It also has another meaning opposite to the first, which is the one that rides its own head and nothing turns it, which is *Al-Sadud*. Mention of this will come later in its chapter, God willing. I think people called it *Jamuh* out of optimism, just as the bitten person is called *Salim* (Sound), and similar things.

Chapter Eight
Defects of Horses: Innate and Habitual
Horse defects are of two types: one type is innate (creation), and one type is habitual. Innate defects are all physical, and habitual defects are all behavioral. Among the defects of horses is *Al-Khadha*, which is a drooping of the ears from their base; the horse is *Akhdha*. If they incline towards its cheeks like donkey ears, that is *Al-Badad*, and the horse is *Abadd*. If the horse has little, short forelock hair, it is *Asfa*. If the top of the forelock is white, it is *As'af*. If the forelock hair is so abundant it covers its eyes, it is *Aghamm*. If it has a short neck, it is *Ahna'*. If the neck is low so that its chest almost nears the ground, it is *Adann*. If there is a gap between the shoulders, it is *Aktaf*. If the top ribs are sunken (*Hadim*), it is *Ahdam*. This is a defect that is harmful despite not being ugly to look at. Al-Asma'i said: No *Ahdam* horse ever won a race. If its spine dips and its croup rises, it is *Aq'as*. If both dip, it is *Abzakh*. If one hip is higher than the other, it is *Afraq*. If one chest muscle tucks in and the other protrudes, it is *Azwar*. If its flanks bulge out, it is *Athjal*. If its tail bone twists so the hairless underside is exposed, it is *A'sal*. If it increases, it is *Akshaf*. If it carries its tail to one side, it is *A'zal*. If the distance between its legs is excessively wide, it is *Afhaj*. If its knees and ankles knock together, it is *Asakk*. If its pastern is upright and it stands on the hoof, it is *Aqfad*. If its thighs are close and hooves far apart, it is *Asdaf*. If it has twisted pasterns, it is *Afda'*. If its legs are straight up without curve or tension, it is *Aqsat*. If its hind hooves fall short of its fore hooves (in tracking), it is *Sha'it*. If its hind hooves cover its fore hooves, it is *Ahaqq*. The poet denied this of his horse:
"And an *Aqdar* (over-tracker), high-backed, far-striding (*Sati*)... Dark bay, neither *Ahaqq* nor *Sha'it*."
*Sati*: Far-stepping. *Ahaqq* has been explained. If it has one testicle, it is *Ashraj*, and the name is *Sharj*. *Sharj* is counted among defects although it does not impair quality or decrease speed, because it is a deficiency in creation. If its hoof peels, it is *Naqad al-Hafir*, and the name is *Naqad*. If the head of its hock is large and not sharp, it is *Aqma'*, the name is *Qama'*. If it knocks one fore-hoof against the other, it is *Murtahish*. If swelling and puffiness of the nerve occur in its hock, it is *Jaradh* (Spavin), and the horse is *Ajradh*. If a tumor occurs in the rim of its hoof, it is *Adkhas*, the name is *Dakhas*. If something protrudes in its cannon bones having volume but not the hardness of bone, that is *Mashash* (Splints), and the horse is *Amash*.

Section

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
Among the disliked traits is *Al-Qazal*; the *Aqzal* is one whose one ear is longer than the other. Also *Al-Akhnas*, which is the recessed nose in the face; this is mostly found in Byzantine horses. Also *Al-Aftas*, which is the depressed nose bridge with a large tip. Also *Al-Muqantar*, which is the elevation of the middle of the neck excluding the rest. Also *Al-Khali*, which common people call empty-necked; Ibn Abi Hazim said: It is the worst defect. Also *Al-Tabarkun*, which is the sharp croup. Also *Al-Salud*, which is the one that does not sweat. Also *Al-Waqi'*, which is the one that goes footsore quickly. Also *Al-Arahh*, which is the flat-footed/splayed hoof, though width is okay unless it is cupped (*Muqa'ab*); if it is wide and cupped, it is praiseworthy. Also *Al-Mustarr*, which is the narrow hoof. Also *Al-Ikhtaf*, which is the tucking up of the belly behind the girth, so the girth always slides back towards the testicles. Also *Al-Ishgha'*, which is when the teeth differ and do not align, some long and some short; the name is *Shagha*. Also shortness of the tongue. Ibn Abi Hazim said: It is a defect in horses because it causes the horse's mouth to be dry and have no saliva. Also *Al-Akabb*, which is the one on which no saddle stays without sliding forward onto its shoulders and neck. Deep-set eyes are disliked in horses because they indicate cowardice/failure. Redness in eyes is disliked in black horses. Musa bin Nusayr said: If a black horse has red eyes, it is suspected of stubbornness (*Hiran*).

Section
Among the disliked conditions of horses requiring proof to identify is *Kharas* (Muteness), which is innate. Musa bin Nusayr said: It is tested by presenting the horse to mares; if it neighs, know it is not mute. Also *Asha* (Night blindness); a horse is *A'sha*, meaning it does not see at night. Musa bin Nusayr said: It is tested by walking it over a black cloth; if it walks on it, it is *A'sha*; if it avoids it, it is sound. The *A'sha* is also called *Shabkur*. Also *Jahar* (Day blindness); a horse is *Ajhar*, meaning weak-sighted and does not see in the sun. This is indicated by seeing it walk lifting its feet and raising its knees until it almost hits its lip. Also *Samam* (Deafness). Ibn Abi Hazim said: It is *Tarash*, a horse is *Tarush*. Among the signs of deafness in a beast is grazing with ears pointed back, not pointing them to look, and not hearing if shouted at. He said: I saw it mostly in Piebalds. Also *Asar* (Left-handedness). Al-Asma'i said: If a man works with his left hand, he is *A'sar*, and likewise the horse if it leads with its left in walking. Musa bin Nusayr said: *Asar* is tested by jumping the horse over a small ditch seven times; if it lifts its right leg before the left every time, know it is not *A'sar*. They said: An *A'sar* horse hardly swims in water. Also *Balid* (Dull/Stupid), which is the opposite of the keen-hearted, proud-souled. Musa bin Nusayr said: Dullness is tested by standing ten cubits from the horse and throwing a rag at it or throwing a pebble at its rein; if it stands still, suspect it of dullness. Likewise, if you sneeze while riding it, or shake some of your clothes. Then mount it and throw a white cloth on the ground and walk over it; if it is wary of it, know it is keen-souled; otherwise, know it is dull.

Section: On Habitual Defects
If the horse bites whoever approaches, it is *Adud*. If it does not stand for one wanting to approach, it is *Nafur*. If it drags the rope and does not obey its leader, it is *Jarur*. If the bit does not stop its running, it is *Jamuh*. If it refuses to walk and stops in one place, it is *Harun*. If it deviates from the direction its owner wants, it is *Hayus*. If it stumbles often, it is *Athur*. If it strikes with its hind legs, it is *Ramuh*. If it prevents its rider, it is *Shamus*. If it twists with its owner until he falls, it is *Qamus*. If it rears its forelegs and stands on hind legs, it is *Shabub*. If it walks a walk resembling a leap, it is *Qatuf*. Abu Mansur al-Tha'alibi put it well denying these defects in a horse gifted to him, saying:
"Not *Shamus*, nor *Qamus*... Nor *Qatuf*, nor *Shabub*."
An Arab asked two sons about which horse was most hateful to them. One said: "The *Jamuh* (runaway), *Tamuh* (high-headed), *Takul* (reliant), *Anuh* (moaning); which if you race it, you beat it, and if you chase it, you catch it." He said to the other: "What do you say?" He said: "A wretched description! But another is more hateful to me." He asked: "What is it?" He said: "The slow, heavy, the blunt *Harun* (stubborn), which if you hit it, it bucks (*Qamas*), and if you approach it, it resists (*Shamas*); the pursuer catches it, and the fleeing outruns it."

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
*Al-Takul*: The one that relies on its owner (rider) in running. *Al-Anuh*: The one that groans frequently, which is breathing out with a moan.

Section
As for established *Hiran* (Stubbornness), it is when the animal stops and plants itself like a stake, not moving; if hit, it kicks with its hind legs. This is the utmost stubbornness for which there is no trick and it never improves. As for non-established stubbornness, it comes from non-knights riding it, frequent dismounting in stables and among animals, and riders at gates, and the like. As for Biting, it comes from the groom hitting it often, and playing with the animal in the rolling area; some of it is rabidity from blood and agitated bile. As for Swerving (*Rawghan*), it comes from non-knights riding and letting the animal take whatever path it wants in its run, and persisting in hitting it from one side without correcting its head with the rein. As for Refusing Saddling and Stirrups and *Shamas* (Resistance), it happens due to boils appearing on the animal's withers, or sores in the puncture site, navel, or back, where it is saddled before healing or ridden without treatment, so it refuses and resists due to pain, then it heals but becomes a habit. As for Kicking with hind legs, it is bad character in the horse and vice (*Rawshanah*), done when cornered. Likewise, Slapping with the foreleg. Perhaps flies hurt it so it slaps with its leg; from that, it guards its lip, and perhaps refuses the bit because of it. As for Refusing Shoeing, it is difficulty remaining in the horse and vice; perhaps it experienced pain, so it refused afterwards even after healing. As for *Nafar* (Shying), it is weakness of heart, panic, and remaining difficulty, and wildness from lack of passing through markets and cities and such. As for Stumbling (*Ithar*), it is from weakness of legs, slackness, and collapsed spirit. As for stumbling in a hole or on a stone or slipping, that is an error, not a defect.

Section
Hannah the Indian claimed that no one should keep animals that have a whorl on the front of their forelegs. Or a whorl below the eyes, or two whorls at the base of the ears on both sides, or a whorl on the hock tendon (*Ma'bid*), or a whorl on the eye socket, or a whorl on the cheek or lower lip or the meeting of the jaws, or scattered hair on the belly, or a whorl on the navel, or teeth protruding over the lip, or two teeth growing like boar tusks, or black lines on the tongue. Or one that is *Adbas* (dark brown), white, yellow, or grey with redness, while the inside of its lips and palate and outside of jaws are black. Or one that is black (*Adham*) with white inside lips, or spots of black in its palate and inside cheeks, and the outside of its lip spotted like sesame seeds, or two whorls on its withers, or black fuzz on its testicles contrary to its color, or hairs in its forehead contrary to its color, or one whose testicles are visible when born.
In the narration of Abu Abdullah al-Tartushi: Among what is considered a bad omen: If a horse is born with teeth; likewise, the blue-eyed in one eye; the ash-colored; the *Aqrah* (star-faced) with no other white; this was mentioned before. The one with a white tuft in its tail; the *Arjal* which has no white except a patch on its leg not circling the coronet; the one that frequently paws with its foreleg without seeing anything at night to fear for itself or its owner. All these signs are disliked and avoided.

Chapter Nine
Selecting and Testing Horses and Physiognomy (Firasa) Regarding Them
Whoever wants to be good at selection and truthful in testing should look at the horse in all its states and conditions: in its stillness and movement, standing and lying down, walking and ambling, trotting and cantering, galloping and sprinting. If its qualities agree in beauty, and its movements and rests are proportionate in moderation, it is likely to be a noble steed. Physiognomy rarely holds true in one state without another. A non-expert might see a mixed-breed horse coming out of water, with its skin hair softened, its flanks raised, its joints enlarged, its face smoothed, its ears erect, looking beautiful in appearance but not in nature or substance, so physiognomy weakens regarding it. Likewise, the prancing horse (*Mustann*) cannot be judged accurately, as it looks around sharply, raising what was low, lifting its tail bone, exposing its groin, elevating its gaze, and pricking its ears; this is affectation. Also, a colt might look good but not run well as a *Jadha'* (young), but run well as a *Thaniy* or *Ruba'i* or *Qarih* (older ages) when its strength gathers and build solidifies, or perhaps it changed by being ridden before it could bear it due to weakness.

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
The closest physiognomy in a colt is when it becomes sturdy (*Ja'than*) and thick, nursing flesh leaves it, and fodder flesh builds up. What is observed then is the quality of its taking to running; at that time, it takes on the characteristics it was printed upon and the nature it will revert to. If its 'taking' (start) is good then, and it does not change afterwards by being ridden by one who cannot carry it or carrying what it cannot bear, and its descriptions are good, it is mostly a noble steed. If it is weak in carrying, this is known by its twisting under the rider, its unsteadiness, sinking of its back; judgment is rarely accurate in this state, so one should not rush against it, for opinion might err. If it carries the rider well and takes to its owner's choice and straightens in its training, then one should search for its build and inspect its caliber.

Section
Evidence of a horse's quality in a state of stillness includes the descriptions mentioned in previous chapters. Some experts in horse physiognomy gathered in brief words what is admired of its qualities, saying: If the horse is compact in build, proportionate in limbs, small-headed, long-necked, thick in the upper chest (*Labbah*), thin in the throat (*Madhbah*), fine-eared, long and upright ears that are firm and finely folded like basil leaves or pen tips; long smooth thin cheeks; moderate forelock hair; narrow occiput (*Qadhal* - seat of the headstall); wide forehead; black-eyed (*Akhal*); protruding pupil; sharp-sighted; wide black nostrils; long mouth slit; round thin lips, with the upper lip slightly longer; fine aligned teeth; long tongue; red palate; wide chest; large breast; full neck base (*Qasarah*); soft long neck; high withers; short level back; large sides and cavity; tucked flank (*Kashh*); long ribs; full loins; spacious belly; vaulted belly; protruding croup (*Qatah*); round buttocks, short and level; short tail bone; full tail; black penis sheath; wide gut (*Marath*); thick round thighs; thick shank bone; level knees; fine cannon bone (*Wazif*); short, thick, dry pasterns; dry nerve; sharp hocks; black or dark green hooves; round cupped heels; toe sticking to the ground; high hard frogs; soft hair—because soft hair in all animals and beasts and birds of prey is praiseworthy and indicates strength. Additionally, soft *Shakir* (fuzz around forelock and mane) is preferred, such that you find it to the touch like carded silk; if rough, the horse is not free from mixed breeding. Along with all this, it should be high-headed, sharp-hearted, energetic when ridden and moving, coquettish when walking, looking at the ground with its eyes while its head is high. If these qualities or most of them gather in a horse, physiognomy will not fail regarding it when tested.

Section
Evidence of a horse's quality while ambling (*Mu'niq*) includes: flexibility of its sides, elevation of its neck, steadiness of its back, intensity of its propulsion, and quick contraction of its hind legs; this is due to the tension of its sciatic nerve (*Nasa*) and the strength and placement of its ankles. Flexibility of sides is known by all its joints, knuckles, and back vertebrae being flexible in its twisting, ambling, and turning, except the ankles specifically; flexibility in ankles is not good, lest they twist in walking and running. If its sides are as described, its propulsion is faster and its command firmer. Its placement is known by the parts of hooves touching the ground being the strongest in grip (fronts and backs), and the soles of its pasterns not being hard convex nor too close to the ground so they bleed in galloping. The tension of its sciatic nerve and strength of ankles are known by the intense tucking of its legs when walking, and the strong impact of its hooves on the ground and kicking off. If it stands, it stands with legs apart (*Mujannab*); it is said of it *Muwattar al-Ansa* (Tensed sciatic nerves).

Section

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
Evidence of a horse's quality in sprinting (*Hahdr*) includes the elevation of its chest/neck (*Hadi*), steadiness of its head, not using them (head/neck) to assist in running, and the gathering of its legs so they do not scatter, as if its forelegs are in a rope and its hind legs likewise. It spreads its arms and extends its flank, such that it finds no more extension for forelegs nor contraction for hind legs. Contraction means not letting the hind legs settle on the ground but taking from them with the tips of the hooves, and due to the speed of contraction, it is as if its hooves are pushed into its groins. It pulls (*Yamlikh*) with forelegs and kicks (*Yadhrah*) with hind legs in unison, as if lifting one leg. It pants (*Yadhbah*) with its chest, and does not become disorganized or distracted from its sprinting. That is the superior steed. Jarir said about such:
"They were yoked when the betting became serious... With one rising to the furthest land.
Cutting the breaths of others with his run... With the bending of the rein, and he has not strived yet."
You look at the placement of its legs on the ground when it sprints; if the distance between its hoof prints is twelve feet, it is the *Dhari' Kamil* (Complete Strider). If more, it is unsurpassed. If seven feet, it is slow. Between these is proportional. Excessive movement with scattered legs, shaking head, assisting with the head, and intense passing in the viewer's eye is not considered (quality), deceiving that it is fast. A noble horse might be seen passing casually without effort, seeming slower to the viewer, but if joined (by another), it wins. This is due to the long stride of the noble horse, gathering of legs, stillness of head, elevation of neck; versus the short stride of the disorganized one with scattered legs, head assistance, and slow return of legs.

Section
Horses are: Striders (*Dhari'*) and Patient (Enduring); Patient with no Stride; Strider with no Patience; and neither Patient nor Strider.
The *Dhari' Sabur* (Enduring Strider) is of complete build, beautiful qualities, strong spirit, wide breath. The Patient with no stride is not long-armed or long-necked, has no weakness betraying it, thighs not huge, forearms not thick, but is gathered in legs when sprinting, tense sciatics, wide breath, not scattered legs. If its sides become flexible, legs long, neck and forearms placed and long, and thighs huge, it becomes a Strider. Whatever increases of these praised qualities increases its quality and stride proportionally. The most essential thing in horses is Patience, and the best is the Enduring Strider. It wins by stride and is not caught due to patience.
As for the Strider with no patience, it is one with long legs and neck, flexible sides, huge thighs, but its other build does not help, not strong-spirited, nor wide-breathed; it is likely to pant due to narrow breath when breath returns to its body, or be not tense-sciatic nor strong-ankled; if the run prolongs, its legs relax and do not contract fast or strike hard, so its legs fail it and patience betrays it.
As for the one with neither patience nor stride, it is the loose-built (*Munshal*), ugly-qualified, dropped-spirit, narrow-breathed, lax-sciatic. These qualities do not exist singly in a horse without betraying its stride and patience.

Section
If the horse's breath is intense and its nostrils and cavity wide along with complete build, it is patient. If its build is strong, joints firm, and legs gathered in sprinting without scattering, this indicates strength. Amr bin Ma'd Yakrib tested his horse's strength on the day of Qadisiyah when he feared its weakness, by placing his hands on its tail base (*Ukwah*) and pressing down to the ground; it did not shake or collapse, so he knew its strength. If it is strong-bound, complete-built, wide-breathed, yet does not endure, that is due to a severance or ailment inside; known by the collapse of its breath, lethargy of movement, dullness of tooth, collapse of body, and disarray of legs in ambling and trotting. It might take to cantering (*Taqrib*) nicely, but if it sprints (*Ahdar*), it reverts to this run. If bad build dominates, it might canter nicely with gathered legs, spreading arms, high neck, and tucked hind legs, but if it wants to sprint, its bad build betrays it and hinders much speed. Sprinting (*Ihdhar*) is the testing ground for this type of horse. The Arabs say: "Quality is in every form," or perhaps it takes to running well but is not well-built, except it is strong-spirited and wide-breathed.

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
If it is loose-built (*Munshal*) and ugly, it takes badly to cantering and sprinting; if it ambles, its head extends and hind legs relax, due to the relaxation of its cords (*Hibal*) and sciatics and its bad build. A horse is only judged in Cantering (*Taqrib*) and Sprinting (*Hudr*). As for others, it confuses the observer and no quality is deduced from it.

Section
The best horse is complete-built, strong-bound, sharp-spirited, wide-breathed, tense-sciatic (*Shanij al-Ansa*), long-necked, strongly inserted in withers, strong-loined (*Haqw*), wide-mouthed (*Harit al-Shidq*), huge-thighed, dry-jointed, firmly-hooved, hard, solid, and cupped. As for the strength of bind and sharpness of spirit, they are concomitant qualities, each aiding the other, just as a man's strength aids his courage and courage aids strength, completing him. A brave non-strong one is overpowered, and a strong non-brave one is defeated. As for the width of breath (nostrils and cavity), by their width, the return of breath is faster and relief for heart and lungs easier. If narrow, breath returns (badly), suppressing panting, distressing and stopping it. As for the width of jaw-splits, it eases breath exit and keeps the bit from the front teeth, so it finds comfort and reliance on it. Width of nostrils is likewise for quick relief and breath return. As for neck length, to elevate it, making breathing easier and relief greater. As for the strength of insertion in withers, because it leans on that in running, finding aid in its strength. As for huge thighs, to rely on them in movement, as they bear the burden of running. As for strong loins, because they suspend the hips and legs from the spine. As for tense sciatics, for faster leg contraction and stronger kicking and pushing. As for dry joints, because they are its ground that supports it and steeds that carry it. As for their hardness and solidity, because they are its hoes fixing it to the earth. As for their cupping, to protect the sole from stones and be firmer when striking hard ground (*Rahs*). These qualities cannot dispense with one another.

Section
If it is not very long-necked without being short, it is forgiven if the neck is wide, high-tendoned, high-withered set back towards the back, wide long shoulders with concealed tops, strong chest, fine *Zawr* (brisket), strongly curved shanks, long forearms. Shortness of forearms is forgiven with strong nerves, firm pasterns, and good upper arms, shoulders, and withers. Thinness of forearms is forgiven with length and full upper arms. If not long-thighed, providing they don't reach deficiency from extreme shortness, it is forgiven for their straightness and fleshiness. Likewise, short shanks are forgiven if wide and tense-sciatic. Width of shanks is prioritized over shortness. Disconnection of the loin is not forgiven, unless the flesh is good and not excessive; then it is forgiven for a short back, wide vertebrae, close neck base, strong joints, high spine in rump, protruding croup, and strength of what is below it to the legs. Large joints are not forgiven with looseness, nor thin hooves without hardness, even if strongly built. Weak fallen spirit is not forgiven with loose cords and narrow breath. If the horse is perfect as mentioned regarding what is forgivable, with perfection of what substitutes it, it joins the excellent ones. If something forgivable is perfect, it is better accordingly.

Section
If the horse is strongly built but not sharp-spirited (*Hadid al-Nafas*), it does not benefit. If sharp-spirited but not strongly built, it does not endure running. If build is perfect and spirit sharp, but not wide-breathed, it will not endure panting and breath will return (badly). If the cavity is wide but nostrils narrow, it suppresses panting and quiets breath. If it is wide-nostriled, good-cavity, neither wide nor extremely tucked-up (*Mahdum*), and is also *Hashsh* (sweats easily/fragile), it bears what the wide-cavity bears. For with quick sweating, breath exits to relieve it. If along with that it has wide skin (*Ihab*), it is stronger for comfort. But if with tucking-up it has tight dry skin, it is faster in exhaustion and weaker on breath.

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
If, along with that, it has narrow nostrils and is pushed until its breath returns (reverses), it is likely to die quickly and be extinguished, unless it is *Hashsh* (quick to sweat), so it finds relief through the speed of its sweat. But if, along with strong build and complete body, it has delicate, thin, soft hooves, they will soon crack and go footsore, cutting it off from what is desired of it.

Section
Know that everything desirable in a male for quality is desirable in a female, except long standing (*Siyam*), little lying down (*Rubud*), little flesh on the cheeks (*Lahzimatan*), and stiffness (*Jus'ah*) in the back. Closeness of ankles (*Qiran*) in movement and otherwise is desirable. In the male, boldness (*Shahamah*), sharpness, and *Shawas* (looking with one eye/boldness) are desirable. This is tolerable in the female. Horse boldness means its sharpness, high gaze, and far sight. *Ashwas* is one that seems startled due to intense looking around and sharp sight. The Arabs used to say: "A startled sleeper male, and a fasting (standing) female." *Siyam* means long standing. There is no good in stiffness of legs for male or female, though the female tolerates it better in front, due to what is disliked in the front of a male horse. Neither can do without good legs, for they are their wings. Short thighs and closeness between ankles are desirable in the female. Separation between her legs is disliked, because if her groin (*Ijan*) widens and her birth canal (*Mahbil*)—which is her *Zabyah*—widens, her legs relax, wind enters her, her hips become weak, and she weakens in running; perhaps if mounted, she stumbles. *Afr* and *Nafz* (leaping/bounding) are desirable in her. That means gathering her legs and not separating them. Her sprinting should be an upward leap with elevation. Gathering of legs is evidence of strong build in male and female. It was narrated that they preferred female horses for raids and night attacks and covert war matters, and preferred male horses for ranks, fortresses, marching, camps, and overt war matters, and preferred geldings for ambushes and vanguards because they are more patient and enduring in exertion.

Chapter Ten
Teaching Horse Riding in Various Situations
Anyone wishing to handle animals should learn what is indispensable, such as riding well bareback and with a saddle, and holding the reins, and learning principles of horsemanship to aid in riding and controlling them. Know—may Allah guide you—that the root of horsemanship is stability (*Thabat*), and its beginning is riding horses bareback. Whoever does not train first on bareback will usually not have established stability, but will always be anxious in his saddle, especially when trotting and galloping, so his fall is not secure if his horse shakes or a mishap occurs. Whoever wants to learn bareback should wear light, well-known clothes, bridle his horse, and tie a wool or hair cloth (*Jull*) on it with a secure girth and breastplate, for the rider on a cloth is more stable than on a bare back. He should stand on the left of his horse at its shoulder, hold the rein of its bridle with his left hand. If he grabs the mane with the rein, there is no harm. He should leap with speed and lightness; when he settles on its back, he gathers his hands on the rein at the horse's withers, straightens his back, sticks his thighs to the place of the saddle panels on the horse's back, and advances slightly—advancing is better bareback than retreating. He extends his knees, shanks, and feet towards the horse's shoulders until he can look at his big toes. His reliance should be on gripping with his thighs; by that, he achieves stability. Anyone whose riding relies on other than that has neither riding nor stability.

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
Adjusting the rein is fundamental to proficiency and mastery. Then he moves his horse from standing to walking by squeezing lightly with his heels gently, then walks it at an amble (*Anaq*) gently, then expands the amble slightly. During this, he must check himself in sitting in the mentioned posture, and holding and adjusting the rein, until he knows he is stable and it becomes a habit and second nature. Then he moves his horse from the amble to the trot (*Khabb*) by increasing the squeeze with his heels slightly; it should trot gently. Let him catch himself, for the trot almost uproots the rider from his saddle, especially at its start and at the pull and end, so beware of that in both cases. Then increase gradually until approaching the canter (*Taqrib*). If stable on that, move to the canter with calmness and levelness, until moving like the walking of a pedestrian. Let him assist with his legs and stick to the horse, or put his feet under the horse's armpits or between its forelegs if he is one who reaches that in trotting and cantering. If stable on that and independent of leg assistance, and settled on the horse's back, and the horse settles under him completely, let him then run his horse between the two runs. If stable and the matter becomes light, let him run his horse at full speed (*Mil'a Furujihi*). Let him be cautious then for himself in both cases: when leaping and when pulling (stopping). Let his pulling be moderate, not prolonged in the run (*Talq*), for prolonging it spoils horses, especially those worked with the spear. If the horse is soft and he knows it stops with one pull, do not stop it except with three pulls, stopping it in the fourth with a halt. Each pull should be softer than the one before. Do not grab its head when pulling, but let it be a gentle, successive restraining. Do not release the rein between two pulls lest the horse returns to running. Let him level his hand with the rein then, and his restraining be balanced. Let him beware of length on one side and shortness on another, for the balance of the rein between rider and horse is like a scale. Good estimation in that is the title of reason and witness of nobility. Adjusting it by the horse's front and rear is the most confirmed thing to care for first and last. Beware of tilting from one side of balance. Many horses, if restrained by a non-expert, throw him from the saddle then. Let him also guard when pulling against making the horse's mouth bleed with the bit; rarely does it bleed except by one with no knowledge of holding it or estimation of his rein. Let the bit be *Naziki*, known now as *Lazmah* or similar, for it is of the bits of knights. Its weight and lightness should be according to the horse's tolerance. Test bits on it; whichever is lighter and better in its mouth and with which it behaves better is its bit. Upon looking at it, what suits it appears. That the horse chews its bit and finds it pleasant is better than fearing it and rearing or lowering its head. It should not be so light that the horse scorns it and the rider cannot control its head. Moderation between that is the goal. Let its cheekpiece (*Idhar*) be short, for length reduces the horse's run, especially the weak-jawed. Necessarily, if the bit hits its teeth, it hurts and distracts it from much running. If the rein is short, it takes the bit with its canine teeth, relies on it, and finds relief. Let the rein also be short, not exceeding the pommel except slightly, for length distracts the rider and confuses the horse. If he masters all this, gets used to riding bareback, and it becomes like nature, he has possessed the root of riding and acquired the bulk of it. Let him then transfer himself to the saddle, with the help of Allah Almighty.

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text: Whoever wishes to practice horsemanship on a saddle, it is recommended to choose a spacious saddle to move in as he pleases, especially for a learner; spacious is more suitable than tight. It should have sturdy wood, a wide seat, low pommel (*Qarbus*) and cantle (*Mu'akhkhara*), and its breastplate (*Labab*) should be sturdy of well-tanned leather circling the saddle, and a girth (*Hizam*) likewise sturdy. Ibn Hizam said: Two girths are better than one, and I prefer that. Also two stirrups (*Rikab*) of moderate weight, size, and ring, neither wide nor tight; heavy is better than light. Secure with stirrup leathers and buckles, and check their length and shortness to be equal; according to need in length and shortness. Being slightly long is better than being short, for if stirrups are short, the rider might be cut off from his saddle when the horse leaps or is pulled in a run, so he is not safe from falling, especially if the horse swerves or rears. Each leg has a limit in them to be measured, like clothes and boots; whoever exceeds his limit and departs from his size, his clothing becomes heavy, and standing and sitting difficult. What is correct is to rely on his seat in the saddle, with shanks extended, relying on stirrups so he is like one standing possessing his entire body, acting with moderation in every limb. He should use two round or square pads (*Bidad*), especially for long travel and much running, as protection for the horse's withers; if a saddle attachment breaks, the pad protects it, and guards the horse's back from pommel and cantle. Use a sweat cloth (*Mirshahah*) of two layers as protection under the pads. The sweat cloth also dries sweat from the pads. If he wants to ride, he tightens with his own hands and handles his affair himself; not relying on others. If another handles it, let him test it upon mounting as a precaution by moving and dismounting. If the girth is loose, the saddle waves with its rider, especially if holding weapons, which is not good. Also, if weapons are tight, they don't wave on the horse's back and hardly cause sores or galling. With looseness and slackness, sores and galling often occur. Let him hold his whip or rod when mounting in his left hand, tuck his clothes, and stand on the left of his horse opposite the left stirrup, slightly behind. Do not stand forward, for it is a defect, but his left side should face the horse's shoulder. He takes the rein in his left hand with the pommel arch from inside or with the mane, if he sees that more helpful. Let him shorten his rein in his hand so the horse's head is full. If the horse doesn't feel the bit then, it might move and it wouldn't be from his mounting. Do not curb it excessively so it spins, but moderately. Then twist the left stirrup forward one twist, place the ball of the left foot in it and extend it to the horse's shoulder, not under its belly. Then take with the right hand the pommel or the saddle cantle, whichever he wishes, both are correct. Taking the pommel with the right is preferred by knights. Then lift himself up gently with power and stillness to mount quickly. If someone holds the right stirrup for him, that is good. When settled sitting in the saddle, place the ball of the right foot in the right stirrup, rely on the stirrups slightly to straighten clothes. If he wants to straighten clothes with his right hand before sitting in the saddle and after lifting, let him do so, for knights have done it. I do not see that (as best), since the horse might move preventing settling. But hold the rein during all that, then straighten the rein with both hands, adjust the horse's head, then move the horse from standing to walking by squeezing lightly with heels, not moving the body, nor hitting the horse's belly with leg movement, for that is ugly and knights don't do it. Look for the most pleasant walk of his horse, the best to him, lightest on himself and the horse, and most still, and carry it on that. Check what suits the horse with care.

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
Good riding and horsemanship lie in good sitting in the saddle, stability, adjusting the rein, equal squeezing, and using it in its place by measure where needed and compelled. Let his sitting be level, back straight, shoulders even, not bent, reclining, chest out, or hunched, but moderate. If he perfects sitting thus, let him stick his thighs to the saddle panels, lengthen his thighs, fence his legs in the stirrups and stick the balls of feet to them, not opening or delaying them. Nothing is uglier for a knight than delaying his legs; let him advance them but not excessively. The amount admired is that the rider can almost see the tips of his toes when settled. The root of riding is positioning, spreading thighs and lengthening them, sticking with them and relaxing them on the saddle. Most knights view good riding as being on the thighs, and relying on stirrups; this is more stable, making the rider like one standing. Let him care for positioning the balls of feet in stirrups, relying on the right one slightly more when working with the spear. For the archer, rely on the left slightly more. Mention of adjusting the rein has passed; let him check it with sure, intense care, for it is the soul of horsemanship, its essence, root, and branches. Be guarded with it, for it is the scale bearing no imbalance, having a calculation only the skilled nature understands. Its weight lies in balancing the horse's head with it. Let the horse always feel the touch and taste of the bit, so he knows his rider is never absent or heedless of him. Even if only for fear of stumbling if a mishap occurs, he holds it by the bridle. Also, excessive loosening of the rein accustoms the horse to ride its own head and govern itself, so riding it doesn't straighten. One should not push the horse to run while holding and pulling the rein, for the horse won't know running is desired. Nor release excessively, confusing the matter and making it anxious. But between that, a moderate hold. For the rider to control his horse's head is more suitable and better. Gradation of movement from walking, to trotting, to cantering, to galloping has passed. Terms will be explained in their chapter in order, God willing. Whoever is forced to ride on a saddle without a girth, take the right stirrup with left hand, pull it across the breastplate path strongly, place left foot in left stirrup, take pommel with right hand along with rein, then mount. Whoever is forced to ride with a pillion rider, hold rein as mentioned, place left foot in left stirrup, take pommel arch with right hand, lift self and split the saddle with right leg to mount. If taking rein with right hand and pommel arch, there is no harm if needed; necessities have rules according to present conditions; let the man take the best possible and capable way, with Allah's help.

Chapter Eleven
Horse Racing, the Racecourse, and Betting
The Arabs used to wager on their horse races, calling what they set for winners *Khasl* and *Rihan* (bets), placing it at the end of the goal line, on the top of a spear shaft. Hence their proverb: "He won the cane of the race" (*Haza Qasab al-Sabq*), meaning this. They called the goal *Al-Mada* and *Al-Amad*. They called the running place *Al-Midmar*. Then Islam came and kept of their actions what alerted the Ummah and aided high ambition. The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, raced and ran horses that were slimmed down (*Dummirat*) from Al-Hafya' to Thaniyat al-Wada', six miles apart. And ran horses not slimmed down from Al-Thaniyah to the Mosque of Banu Zurayq, one mile apart. He, peace be upon him, said: "Angels do not attend any of your amusements except betting (on races) and archery." From Abu Hurairah, he, peace be upon him, said: "There is no prize (*Sabaq*) except in a hoof (camel), a hoof (horse), or a blade (arrow)." It was said to Anas bin Malik: "Did the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, bet on horses?" He said: "Yes, by Allah! He bet on a horse of his called *Sabha*, and it won, so he was delighted and pleased."

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
From Makhul: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, raced horses, and his black horse came in first. When he saw that, he knelt on his knees and said: "It is indeed a sea (of speed)." Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "Al-Hutay'ah lied! If anyone could escape this, the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, would have escaped." Abu Ali said: Umar meant by this saying the verse: 'Indeed, swift horses do not provoke us... Nor those placing ivory upon wrists!'
From Yaqub bin Zaid bin Talha from his father, he said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, set a prize between horses of twelve ounces (of silver). A horse of Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him, won, so he took four hundred and eighty dirhams.
From Al-Sha'bi that Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, wrote to Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas: "Run horses and set prizes." He said: So I ran horses in Kufa. Two horses came rubbing against each other until they entered the enclosure (*Hujrah*). They disputed over them. So he wrote to Umar, and Umar wrote: "If it wins by the head, it has won."
From Harun bin Abi Ziyad, he said: Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "Go early to this honor!" meaning betting on horses. He said: People went early, and Salman went among those who went. Some people said: "Let's beat him today!" They met him and said: "O Abu Abdullah! Who won today?" He said: "The winners won?"
The origin of *Rihan* (betting) is from *Rahn* (pledge). A man would bet his companion on a race: this one puts a pledge, and that one puts a pledge; whichever horse wins takes his pledge and his companion's pledge. This was from the Pre-Islamic period, and it is the gambling prohibited. If the bet is from one of them named, such that if he wins he gets nothing (extra) but if his companion wins he takes the pledge, this is Halal. Because the pledge is from one, not the other. Likewise, if each puts a pledge and they enter a "legalizer" (*Muhallil*) between them, a third horse between the first two, also called *Dakhil*. The owner of the third puts nothing. Then they release the three horses. If one of the first two wins, he takes his pledge and his companion's pledge, and it is lawful for him. If the *Dakhil* wins, he takes both pledges. If he is beaten, he owes nothing. The *Dakhil* must be a winning racer whom they fear might beat them and take the pledges; this is permissible betting. If the *Muhallil* is not fast and they are sure they will beat him, this is gambling, because it is as if they didn't enter anything between them. The basis of this is the Hadith of Sa'id bin al-Musayyib: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever enters a horse between two horses and is not sure he will be beaten, there is no harm in it. Whoever enters a horse between two horses and is sure he will be beaten, it is gambling."
Al-Waqidi narrated from Musa bin Muhammad from his father: "The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to give prizes to ten horses; whatever was more he gave nothing."
The Arabs in the Pre-Islamic period used to set only seven canes (prizes) in their time, and only eight horses entered the enclosure (*Hujrah*). They sent their horses ten by ten. They named the first *Al-Sabiq* (The Winner), *Al-Mubarriz* (The Outstanding), and *Al-Mujalli* (The Clearer). It was their custom to wipe the face of the winner, as Jarir said:
"If you wish to wipe the face of a winner... A steed, then lengthen the reins in betting."
They name the second *Al-Musalli* because it places its lip on the *Sala* of the winner, which is a vein on the outside of the thigh sides. The animal has two *Sala*, the sides of the tail base. The third is *Al-Musalli* (The Consoler), derived from *Suluww* (forgetting/consolation), as if it consoled its companion when it came third. The fourth is *Al-Tali* (The Follower) because it follows the *Musalli*. The fifth is *Al-Murtah* (The Relaxed/Joyful), from *Rawah*. Meaning it came at the end of the first group, for being fifth, it halved the number of winners; it is the first of the *Rawah* (late) and last of the *Ghuduw* (early). Thus, the fifth of winners is the last of the firsts and first of the lasts. The sixth is *Al-Atif* (The Turner), from *Atf* (bending), as if this horse turns the lasts onto the firsts, so a name was derived from its action. The seventh is *Al-Haziy* (The Fortunate); it was fortunate because it took the place in the lasts that the *Musalli* took in the firsts, gaining a share missed by those after it, as it missed being the *Atif*. The eighth is *Al-Mu'ammal* (The Hoped For), because it is awaited by the three differing ones, as one must win usually; when identified, it was named by what hope was attached to it.

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
The ninth is *Al-Latim* (The Slapped); it was made slapped because the *Mu'ammal* won before it, so its face was slapped away from entering the enclosure. The tenth is *Al-Sukayt* (The Silent); called *Sukayt* because humiliation and silence overcome its owner. It must be so, because the one before it was *Latim*, so what can he say? Excuse benefits him. Kilab bin Hamzah said: We know of no one among the Arabs in Jahiliyyah or Islam who described race horses by their names and mentioned them in their ranks other than Muhammad bin Yazid bin Maslamah bin Abdul Malik bin Marwan. He was in Al-Jazirah, in the village known as Hisn Maslamah, in the district of Raqqa of Diyar Mudar. He recited a beautiful poem about it beginning:
"We attended the betting on the morning of betting... In a gathering brought together by the season.
We lead to it the leading of the multitude... And we are most upright in its craft."
He says regarding the racehorses:
"So the *Agharr* cleared (won) and the *Kumait* prayed (came second)... And the *Adham* consoled and was not blamed.
The fourth followed them trailing... And where is the Highland from the Lowland?
Its *Murtah* was not blamed as fifth... Coming advancing what advances.
Its sixth is the confused *Atif*... Almost deprived due to its confusion.
Its *Haziy* came seventh... So its fortunate share gave it a share.
The *Mu'ammal* came in it failing... And the most ominous bird sang for it.
Its *Latim* came ninth... Slapped from every side.
The *Sukayt* trots on its trace... And its *Dhifra* (behind ear) is larger than a dome."
The poem is long, fulfilling the purposes of its meaning. Abu al-Hasan al-Mas'udi mentioned it in his book 'Muruj al-Dhahab'. We only brought the verses containing the mention of racehorses. *Halbah* is the gathering of horses, and it is said the gathering of people for betting; from saying: Banu Fulan gathered (*Halabu*) against Banu Fulan, and *Ahlabu* meaning gathered.

Section
Description of the horse that can attend the goal and race with the group without slimming down (*Tadmir*), bearing burden, or tucking up: To be wide-breathed (cavity and nostrils), wide-skinned, wide-backed, wide-crouped, away from its kidneys (long-flanked?), wide-jawed, abundant saliva, wide-chested, tucked-flank skin (*Sifaq*), and along with that *Hashsh* (sweats easily), its sweat heats the asthma of its body. If it has these qualities, it is better and safer for it not to be sent to the track after ease/rest, until it has been worked for days so its belly catches up (lightens) and it bows for the gallop (strengthens). Also, after rest, its belly is mostly full and flank skin stretched; perhaps it hits it with its stifles and cuts it or hinders and shortens it. The rested horse never leaps (*Yadbir*) like the leaping of horses treated with exercise and work. We see wild animals and dogs, which are not slimmed or manufactured, if tasked with running while resting, they pant, gasp, and stop what they could do when not resting. Every animal, if rested, relaxes. There is no good in storming the track except after work and slimming. Even if it has the praised description and abundant build. Desirable in slimming (*Tadmir*), rather indispensable, is: good management in policy, lack of boredom in observation and service, continuity of riding as needed, reducing fodder at times, entering it into a covered house and covering it to sweat and dry its sweat. Thus its flesh firms, lightens, and strengthens. Slimming is not emaciating the horse, humiliating it, or cheating its right; it is done to tighten its flesh, squeeze its body, remove excess, and keep it on its original nature. Ibn Banin mentioned that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, used to order slimming his horses with dry grass, bit by bit, phase by phase. He would say: "Quench them with water, water them morning and evening, and keep covers on them, for they meet water with sweat under covers, so their colors clear and skins widen." He, peace be upon him, ordered leading them twice every day, taking a run or two from them, not galloping them until they become lean. Horses differ in conditions and vary in forms; each has its specific slimming and is treated according to its limit and measure. So take each according to its state and activity, and measure of its laziness or energy, with Allah's help.

Chapter Twelve
Names of the Horses of the Messenger of Allah

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
May Allah bless him and grant him peace, and Names of the Stallions and Famous Horses of the Arabs
The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, had a number of horses. Among them was *Al-Sakb* (The Pouring), which he rode on the day of Uhud; Ibn Qutaybah recounted this. Among them was *Al-Murtajiz* (The Thunderer), named so for the beauty of its neighing. He had a horse called *Lizaz* (Close/Adhering). And a horse called *Al-Zarib* (The Firm). And a horse called *Al-Lahif* (Covering with tail/mane). And a horse called *Al-Ward* (The Bay). Someone other than Ibn Qutaybah added a horse called *Mulawih* and a horse called *Al-Ya'sub* (The Bee Leader/Chief). *Al-Ward* is the one Tamim al-Dari gifted to him. These are the horses of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, as mentioned by Ibn Qutaybah and others.
As for the horses of the Arabs, the oldest of them is *Zad al-Rakib* (Provision of the Rider), which Solomon son of David, peace be upon them, gave to a group of Azd who were his in-laws; it was the first horse to spread among Arabs from his horses. It was said: When Taghlib heard of that, they came to them and bred from it, producing a horse better than Zad al-Rakib, which they named *Al-Hujays*. When Bakr bin Wa'il heard of that, they came to Banu Taghlib and bred from it, producing a horse better than Al-Hujays which they named *Al-Dinari*. Muhammad bin Al-Sa'ib and other scholars mentioned the names of famous horses in Arab poetry. Among them in Quraysh were the horses of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, mentioned before. Among them was the horse of Hamza bin Abdul Muttalib, *Al-Ward*, a daughter of *Dhu al-Uqqal* from the daughters of *Awaj*. Hamza, may Allah be pleased with him, said regarding that:
"I have nothing but a weapon and a Bay (*Ward*)... A full-grown from the daughters of Dhu al-Uqqal
I shield it from death with my own soul... While it shields me, facing the chests of spears."
Al-Kalbi narrated from Abu Salih from Ibn Abbas that *Awaj* was the master of David's famous horses, and it belonged to a king of Kinda. He raided Banu Sulaym on the day of 'Ilaf', they defeated him and took *Awaj*. It then went to Banu Hilal of Banu Amir and produced excellent offspring. Then noble horses spread among the Arabs. Among their named stallions and mares were:
*Al-Ghurab*, *Al-Wajih*, *Lahiq*, *Al-Mudhhab*, and *Maktum*; these belonged to Ghani bin A'sur. *Dhu al-Uqqal* belonged to Banu Riyah bin Yarbu'. *Dahis* was the son of Dhu al-Uqqal. *Al-Hanfa*, sister of *Dahis*, belonged to Hudhayfah bin Badr al-Fazari. *Al-Ghabra* belonged to Hamal bin Badr al-Fazari. *Qasam* belonged to Banu Ja'dah. *Fayyad* and *Sabal* also belonged to Banu Ja'dah. *Al-Himalah* and *Al-Qurayz* belonged to Banu Sulaym.
As for *Dahis*, it belonged to Qais bin Zuhair bin Jadhimah al-Absi. Hudhayfah bin Badr al-Fazari bet against it, leading to the war of Ghatafan, which lasted between them, as they mentioned, for forty years. The Arabs considered it and its offspring an ill omen. Bashir bin Abi al-Absi said regarding that:
"Indeed, the wretched horses from the family of Dahis... Refused, so they never succeeded on a betting day
They brought, by Allah's leave, the killing of Malik... and cast Qais beyond Oman."
Among them in Kinanah was *Al-Latim*, the horse of Rabi'ah bin Mukaddam, and *Masad*, a horse of Ibn Ghadiyah al-Khuza'i. *Al-Ajdal* was the horse of Abu Dharr al-Ghifari, companion of the Prophet. *Al-Ya'sub* was the horse of Al-Zubayr bin Al-Awwam. *Dhu al-Limmah* was the horse of Ukasha bin Mihsan. *Rirrah* was the horse of Al-Jami' bin Munqidh al-Asadi. *Hazmah* was the horse of Hanzalah bin Fatik al-Asadi. *Zabyah* was the horse of Al-Harras al-Asadi. *Al-Himalah* was the horse of Tulayhah bin Khuwaylid al-Asadi, to whom he said:
"I set up for them the chest of *Al-Himalah*... She is accustomed to the warriors' saying: Dismount!
One day you see her protected in covers... And another day you see her without covers."
*Ma'ruf* was the horse of Salamah bin Hind al-Ghadiri. *Al-Maniha* was the horse of Dithar bin Faq'as al-Asadi. *Nasih* was the horse of Fadalah bin Hind bin Sharik al-Asadi, to whom he said:
"O Nasih! Tuck up for the race for it is... A morning of defense gathered by the milkers
Do you remember my clothing you every winter... My cloak, and feeding you while my belly was hungry?"
*Al-Latim* was also a horse of the mentioned Fadalah. Among Banu Tamim bin Murr was *Al-Shawha*, the horse of Hajib bin Zurarah al-Tamimi. *Al-Raqib* was the horse of Al-Zibriqan bin Badr al-Tamimi.

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
From the offspring of *Awaj* belonging to Banu Asad was *Al-Asjadi*. *Athal* was the horse of Damrah bin Damrah bin Darim. *Al-Khadhwa'* was the horse of Shaytan bin al-Hakam bin Yarbu'. *Al-Shayyit* was the horse of Labid bin Jabalah al-Dabbi. *Al-Aradah* was the horse of Kalahbah al-Yarbu'i. *Al-Ahwa* was the horse of Uwayd bin Salma bin Rabi'ah al-Dabbi. *Al-Agharr* was the horse of Tarif bin Tamim. *Kamil* was the horse of Zaid al-Fawaris al-Dabbi. *Dhu al-Wushum* was the horse of Abdullah bin Adda'. *Wahfah* was the horse of Ulahthah bin al-Julas al-Tamimi. *Mabdu'* was the horse of Al-Harith bin Dirar al-Dabbi. *Al-Gharraf* was the horse of Al-Bara' bin Qais bin Attab. *Al-Shaqra'* was the horse of Al-Ruqad bin al-Mundhir al-Dabbi. *Al-Mukassar* was the horse of Utaybah bin al-Harith bin Shihab. *Shawlah* was the horse of Zaid al-Fawaris al-Dabbi. *Al-Nahham* was the horse of Sulayk, about which he says:
'Bring forward Al-Nahham and hurry, O boy... And throw the saddle upon him and the bridle.'
*Al-Ward* and *Al-Jumanah* were the two horses of Amir bin al-Tufayl. *Hadhfah* was the horse of Khalid bin Ja'far bin Kilab. *Jirwah* was the horse of Shaddad bin Muawiyah al-Absi. *Al-Abjar* was the horse of Antarah bin Shaddad bin Muawiyah al-Absi. About it he says:
'Do not hurry; tighten the girth of Al-Abjar... For if death calls, I do not anguish
Nor do I promise my soul delay.'
*Wajzah* was the horse of Yazid bin Abi Sinan al-Murri, the knight of Ghatafan. *Mihaj* was the horse of Malik bin Awf. About it he says on the day of Hunayn:
'Advance, Mihaj! It is a grievous day... The likes of me protects and attacks upon the likes of you
If the rank is lost one day, and the rear.'
*Al-Ubayd* was the horse of Al-Abbas bin Mirdas al-Sulami. He is the one who reproached the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, when he gave (gifts) to Uyaynah bin Hisn al-Fazari and Al-Aqra' bin Habis al-Tamimi a hundred camels each, but gave him only a few camels. He said regarding that:
'Do you make my spoil and the spoil of Al-Ubayd... between Uyaynah and Al-Aqra'?
Neither Hisn nor Habis... were ever above Mirdas in an assembly.
And I am not below either of them... And he whom you lower today will not be raised.'
Ibn Ishaq said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: 'Go with him and cut off his tongue from me (silence him).' So they gave to him until he was satisfied; that was the 'cutting of his tongue' ordered by the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. *Al-Bayda'* was the horse of Bujayr bin Abdullah bin Qushayr. *Al-Musabbih* was the horse of Awf bin al-Kahin al-Sulami. *Al-Sayud* was a famous mare attributed to the noble horses of the Arabs. *Al-Dakhm* was the horse of Rahdah bin Mu'ammil al-Sulami, about which he says:
'Is not the one most deserving to witness the war... And kill heroes, a huge man upon a huge horse (*Dakhm*)?'
*Qurzul* was the horse of Al-Tufayl bin Malik al-Amiri. *Al-Quways* was the horse of Salamah bin al-Harith al-Absi. *Sullam* was the horse of Zabban bin Sayyar al-Fazari. *Mayyas* was the horse of Shamir bin Rabi'ah al-Bahili. *Al-Na'amah* was a mare among Rabi'ah belonging to Al-Harith bin Ubad. *Ziyam* was the horse of Al-Akhnas bin Shihab al-Taghlibi, who was among the famous knights of the Arabs. About it he says:
'This is the time for charging, so charge, O Ziyam... There is no life but thrusting on the day of obscure dangers.'
*Khumayrah* was the horse of Shaytan bin Mudlij al-Jushami. *Al-Nubak* was the horse of Al-Sabah bin Khalid al-Taghlibi. *Al-Shamus* was the horse of Yazid bin Khadhaq. *Al-Anz* was the horse of Abu Afra' bin Sinan al-Muharibi. *Al-Jawn*: among them in Yemen was the horse of Imru' al-Qais bin Hujr al-Kindi. *Al-Attaf* was the horse of Amr bin Ma'd Yakrib al-Zubaydi. *Al-Hattal* was the horse of Zaid al-Khayl bin Muhalhil al-Ta'i, surnamed Abu Miknaf. About it he says:
'I bring close the tether of Al-Hattal, for I... See a war being conceived from barrenness.
I equate him with Miknaf when we winter... And I prefer him over most of the family.'
He was named *Zaid al-Khayl* (Zaid of the Horses) due to the abundance of his horses. Among his noble ones were: *Al-Hattal* (mentioned), *Al-Kamil*, *Al-Kumait*, *Al-Ward*, *Lahiq*, and *Dha'ul*. Ibn Ishaq said: He came to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, with the Tayy tribe, and Zaid al-Khayl was their leader. When they reached him and spoke to him, the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, presented Islam to them, so they accepted Islam and their Islam was good. Then the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, named him *Zaid al-Khayr* (Zaid of Goodness).

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
*Al-Attas* was the horse of Abdullah bin Abdul Madan. *Al-Asa* (The Staff) was the horse of Jadhimah bin Malik al-Azdi, the King of Al-Hirah in ancient times, ages before the Munthirids; he is Jadhimah the Leper (Al-Abrash) whom Al-Zabba' killed, and Qasir escaped on his horse *Al-Asa*, then took revenge later and killed Al-Zabba' in a long story. *Al-Dhubayb* was the horse of Hassan bin Hanzalah al-Kindi; he witnessed the Day of Nahrawan with Chosroes (Kisra), and the day Chosroes met Bahram and was defeated. Chosroes fled, and Hassan bin Hanzalah caught up with him while Chosroes's workhorse had stopped. Hassan dismounted from his horse *Al-Dhubayb*, and Chosroes rode it and escaped. Hassan said regarding that:
'I rectified Chosroes lest he be harmed, and I was not... One to leave him stumbling on horses while on foot.
I offered him the chest of Al-Dhubayb when there appeared... Branded horses from the cavalry of Turks and Kabul.'
Then Chosroes prevailed and killed Bahram. When his kingdom was established, Hassan bin Hanzalah came to him but stayed at his door unable to reach him. When the matter dragged on, he came to the chamberlain and said: "You have prolonged my exclusion, and I have the greatest hand (favor) upon Chosroes, so inform him of my place." He informed him, and he gave him permission. He said: "Who are you? And what is this hand of yours?" He said: "I am the one who carried you on my horse on the Day of Nahrawan when your workhorse stopped." Chosroes said: "Ugh to you! You have reminded me of the most malicious day that ever passed me! Take this dog out!" So they took him out... Until the worries cleared from Chosroes, he regretted and felt ashamed, so he honored him, gave him a good reward, and granted him *Tassuj*, which is parasangs away from Kufa. *Al-Burayt* was the horse of Ibn Qabisah al-Ta'i. *Hawmal* was the horse of Harithah bin Anas bin al-Harith. *Al-Yahmoum* was the horse of Al-Nu'man bin al-Mundhir, King of the Arabs; *Al-Yahmoum* was from the breeding stock of Ghatafan. *Al-Qurayt*, *Nahlah*, and *Shahir* were horses belonging to Kinda. *Khisaf* was the horse of Malik bin Amr bin al-Mundhir bin al-Harith bin Mariya (possessor of the two earrings hung on the Kaaba). Malik bin Amr was a coward; if he tasted war, he would be a bowshot away from it. An arrow came to him one day and fell near his horse's leg. He said: "This arrow almost hit me." The arrow shook, and he watched it shaking often. He dismounted and dug around it, and found the arrow had hit a jerboa in its burrow, not missing its skull, killing it. Malik bin Amr mounted and said: "Man is nothing, nor is the jerboa." This became a proverb. Then he said: "I see myself fleeing from my appointed time, yet the arrow entered upon the jerboa when its time was fulfilled, and its caution availed it nothing. I will not die nor be killed except by my appointed time." So he charged, piercing the rank back and forth, and was thereafter among the bravest of his people. A poet from Ghassan said about that:
'If Time directs arrows at a man... It hits and does not miss, aiming purposefully.
Many a *Khisaf* has missed its arrows... And which man remains eternally against Time?'
*Al-Dhubayh* was the horse of Khawwat bin Jubayr al-Ansari. *Al-Warha'* was the horse of Qatadah al-Kindi. *Kanzah* was the horse of Al-Mundhir bin Shammas al-Judhami. *Al-Yasir* was the horse of Abu al-Nadir al-Sa'di. *Al-Haddaj* was the horse of Al-Rayb bin al-Shariq al-Sa'di. *Al-Jawn* was the horse of Al-Harith bin Abi Shamir al-Ghassani. Alqamah said about it when he (Al-Harith) captured his brother Sha's, in his poem beginning: "Your heart is obsessed with beauties, enraptured..." He says later in it:
'I swear, were it not for the knight of Al-Jawn among them... They would have returned in disgrace, and the return is beloved.
You advance him until his white legs disappear... And you are a striker of the white forearms.'
*Al-Arim* was the horse of Al-Mundhir bin al-A'lam al-Khawlani. *Al-Arin* was the horse of Umayr bin Jabal al-Bajali. *Nisab* was the horse of Al-Ahwas bin Tha'labah al-Kalbi. Its daughter *Wari'ah* was gifted by Al-Ahwas to Malik bin Nuwayrah. *Muwakil* and *Al-Qarra'* were the two horses of Rabi'ah bin Ghazalah al-Yashkuri. *Al-Ghazalah* was the horse of Muhallim bin al-Arqam. *Sa'dah* was the horse of Dhu'ayb bin Hilal al-Khuza'i. *Al-Na'amah* was the horse of Qurras al-Azdi. *Dhu al-Rish* was the horse of Al-Samh bin Hind al-Khawlani. *Al-Tayyar* was the horse of Abu Raysan al-Khawlani. *Al-Janah* was the horse of Muhammad bin Maslamah al-Ansari, companion of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. *Al-Mu'alla* was the horse of Al-As'ar bin Abi Humran al-Ju'fi. *Bahram* was the horse of Al-Nu'man bin Uqbah al-Ataki. *Suhbya* was the horse of Al-Namir bin Tawlab al-Ukli. About it he says:
'Do the runs of Suhbya go in vain... And the galloping of horses trembling violently?
And my charging in the battle every day... When voices mix with the dust?'

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
*Al-Hulayl* was the horse of Miqsam bin Kathir al-Asbahi. *Atlal* was the horse of Bukayr al-Kinani. *Al-Ghamamah*, *Al-Sarih*, *Qayd*, and *Madiq* belonged to the kings of Banu Ma' al-Sama'. *Al-Sha'ur* was the horse of the Habitat clan of Banu Tamim. *Afiq*, *Al-Khubas*, and *Na'iq* belonged to Banu Fuqaym. *Ra'shan* belonged to Murad. *Al-Sagha* was the horse of Mujashi' bin Mas'ud al-Sulami, and it was from the offspring of *Al-Ghabra* (horse of Hamal bin Badr al-Fazari); Umar bin Al-Khattab bought it for ten thousand dirhams. Then Mujashi' went to raid, so Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "Shall this be kept in Medina while its owner is in the throats of the enemy, and he is more in need of it?!" So he returned it to him, and it produced offspring for his children until Al-Hajjaj bin Yusuf sent and took what remained of them. *Al-Qatadi* and *Al-Tiryaq* belonged to Al-Khazraj in Islam. *Al-Harun* was the horse of Muslim bin Amr, Abu Qutaybah bin Muslim al-Bahili; he bought it from a man—after it had been stubborn with him—for a thousand dirhams. Then he saw in his dream that sparrows were coming out of its penis. He sent to Muhammad bin Sirin, and Ibn Sirin said to him: "If your vision is true, you will breed noble horses!" From it come the noble horses today. *Munahib* belonged to Banu Taghlib bin Yarbu'. *Al-Daif* belonged to Banu Taghlib. *Humayl* belonged to Banu Ijl. *Al-Butin*, *Al-Bawwab*, and *Al-Dha'id* (from the mentioned *Al-Harun*) belonged to Muslim bin Amr al-Bahili. *Al-Sahib* belonged to Ghani al-Bahili. Among them was *Ghutayf* from the horses of the people of Sham (Levant). *Al-A'rabi* belonged to Abbad bin Ziyad from the horses of the people of Al-Aliyah. *Al-Qatarani* belonged to Al-Salami. *Al-Dha'id* belonged to Al-Abbas bin Al-Walid bin Abdul Malik bin Marwan. Most winners are attributed to *Al-Butin* and *Al-Dha'id*.

Chapter Thirteen
Mentioning Various Terms and Naming Things Specific to Horses
From that is the age of the horse. When its mother gives birth to it, it is *Muhr*, then *Faluw*. If it completes a year, it is *Hawli*. Then in the second, *Jadha'*. Then in the third, *Thaniy*. Then in the fourth, *Ruba'i*. Then in the fifth, *Qarih*. Then after that, until its age is forgotten, *Mudhaki*.

Section: On its sounds and types of striking attributed to it
*Al-Sahil* (Neighing) is its voice in most conditions. *Al-Dhabh* (Panting) is the sound of its breath when it runs; the Quran has mentioned it. *Al-Qab'* is a sound it repeats from its throat to its nostrils if it shy away from something or dislikes it. *Al-Hamhamah* (Nickering) is its sound if it asks for fodder or sees its owner and seeks familiarity. *Al-Nathir* (Snorting) is like sneezing for a human. *Al-Khadi'ah* and *Al-Waqib* are the sounds of its belly. Likewise *Al-Baqbaqah* and *Al-Qabqabah*. *Al-Ra'iq* and *Al-Ru'aq* is a sound heard from its sheath, just as *Al-Wa'iq* is heard from the mare's vulva. As for types of striking, it is said: The animal *Nafahat* (struck) with its foreleg, *Ramahat* (kicked) with its hind leg, *Natahat* (butted) with its head, *Sadamat* (bumped) with its chest, and *Khatarat* (swished/struck) with its tail.

Section: On descriptions of its walking and running in detail
*Al-Dhayr*: When it stands firm with gathered legs. *Al-Anaq*: When it spaces its steps and expands in its walk. *Al-Hamlajah*: When it brings its steps close with speed; this is the pace/amble (*Sayr*) for people. *Al-Irtijal*: Mixing *Hamlajah* with *Anaq*. *Al-Khabb* and *Al-Khabab* (Trotting): When it straightens its neck in running, alternates its forelegs, and tucks its hind legs. *Al-Dhab'*: When it twists its fore-hooves towards its upper arms. *Al-Ujayla*: Between trot (*Khabb*) and canter (*Taqrib*). *Al-Taqrib* (Canter): When it lifts its forelegs together. *Al-Radayan*: When it stones the ground with its hooves. *Al-Dahw*: When it throws itself (extends) without lifting its toe much from the ground. *Al-Imjaj*: When it starts running before heating up. *Al-Ihdar* (Galloping): When it runs a continuous run. *Al-Ihdhab* and *Al-Ilhab*: When it blazes in its run. *Al-Irkha'*: More intense than *Ihdar*, likewise *Al-Ibtirak*. *Al-Ihmaj*: When it strives to give its utmost and exhausts its effort. Their order of running is: *Al-Khabb* first, then *Al-Taqrib*, then *Al-Imjaj*, then *Al-Ihdar*, then *Al-Irkha'*, then *Al-Ihdhab*, then *Al-Ihmaj*.

Section: On urging and inciting it
The Arabs say: *Awshaytu* the horse, and *Alhabtu* (inflamed) it with the whip, and *Maraytu* (extracted speed from) it with the heel. The poet said:
'They urge them (*Yushunahunna*) when they sense fear... Under the armor, with heels and crop handles.'
Meaning they extract their running by kicking with feet (heels) and hitting with whips (*Jidham*). Imru' al-Qais said describing his horse in a state of running:

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
'For the whip there is a blazing speed (*Ulhub*), and for the leg a flow (*Dirrah*)... And for the scolding there is the reaction of a wild, long-necked one.'
He says: If I move him with my leg, he blazes in running, meaning he comes with a run like the burning of fire; and if I hit him with the whip, he flows with speed. And if scolded, that affects him like it affects a wild one with no reason. The *Min'ab* is the one that stretches its neck in running. *Hamz* (pricking) and *Ghamz* (pressing) with the heel are well known.

Section
As for scolding (urging with voice), it uses words the horses are accustomed to and whose languages they are familiar with. Among what the Arabs used were: *Yahyuh* and *Hal*. The poet said:
'So we thought he was overcoming him... So we urged him with Yahyuh and Hal.'
Also *Arhib*, *Arhi*, *Aqdim*, *Hab*, and *Habi*. Used for calming it and stopping its movement and playfulness was their saying *Hala*. The poet said:
'If the grooms lead him, they do not control him... Even if those trying say to him "Hala".'
Tufayl al-Ghanawi gathered horse commands in one verse, saying:
'It was said: *Aqdimi* (Advance f.), *Aqdim* (Advance m.), *Akh* (Whoa), *Akhkhiri* (Back up)... And *Ha* and *Hala* and *Isbir* (Patience) and checking her with *Habi*.'
Among them is *Al-Naqr* (Clicking/Clucking), which is making a sound with the mouth by placing the tip of the tongue on the front of the upper palate and pulling it after tightening, producing a sound upon release. Horses understood this as calming by habit, just as they understood whistling when drinking water. Until the poet said:
'And do not drink without delight, for I... Have seen horses drink to whistling.'
Imru' al-Qais said about *Naqr*:
'I lower him with the click (*Naqr*) when I mount him... And he raises a glance that is not dry or lowered.'
Every people has a custom, and in every time there is decrease and increase.

Section: On descriptions specific to it
A horse is called *Dali'* (Strong-ribbed) if its ribs are strong. *Mishyat*: Fast to fatten. *Salud*: Does not sweat. *Asim*: Its sweat when dried on it. *Khawwar al-Inan*: If it has a flexible neck/turning. *Qalahdham*: If generally short in build. *Kaham*: Dull/slow towards the goal. *Ajiz* in horses: Like impotent (*Innin*) in men. It is said regarding the mare's pregnancy: *Aquq*. Regarding birthing: *Natuj*.

Section: On descriptions of its action and behavior
*Al-Qadm*: Nibbling pasture with lips and front teeth. *Al-Khadm*: Taking with the whole mouth. *Al-Azm*: Clamping on the bit with the mouth. Among what is done to it: *Al-Taswim*: Sending it to pasture and leaving it alone. You say: *Sawwamtuhu* and *Ahmaltuhu*. *Al-Tandiyah*: Watering it until it drinks, then returning it to pasture to take a little, then returning it to water. You say: *Nadaytuhu Tandiyah*. The name of the place where this is done is *Al-Munadda*. *Al-Tamrigh*: Making a sound for it until it lies down and rolls in the dust. This is relief for it from exhaustion and a cure for fatigue and sweat; perhaps the horse does it itself and finds rest. The name of the place where it does this is *Al-Maraghah*.

Section: On terms specific to groups of horses
*Al-Tali'ah* (Vanguard): The first of the army. *Sar'an* of horses: Their leaders/first ones. *Al-Musabbaqat* of horses: The advancing ones, which are *Al-Bawadi*. *Saqah* of the army: Its rear. *Al-Kayyul*: The last ranks in war. *Andalafat* (Poured out) the horses: When they exit at the very beginning quickly. The first of their groups is: *Miqnab*, then *Minsar*, then *Ra'il* and *Ra'lah*, then *Kardus*, then *Qunbulah*.

Section: On names of armies
The first is *Jaridah* (Detachment), which is stripped for a specific purpose. Then *Sariyah* (Company), from fifty to four hundred. Then *Katibah* (Battalion), from five hundred to a thousand. Then *Jaysh* (Army), from one thousand to four thousand. Likewise *Faylaq* and *Jahfal*. Then *Khamis*, from four thousand to twelve thousand. *Askar* collects them all.

Section: On describing them by multitude and intensity of power (Thorns)
*Katibah Rajrajah* (Shaking battalion). *Jaysh Lajib* (Clamorous army). *Askar Jarrar* (Dragging/Huge army). *Jahfal Luham* (Great army). *Khamis Aramram* (Numerous army). The battalion of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was called *Al-Khadra'* (The Green), named so for the abundance of iron (armor/weapons) in it. Every battalion with much iron is *Khadra'*.

Section: On places specific to horses, groups and individuals
*Al-Mu'askar*: Place of the army (Camp). *Al-Ma'rakah*: Place of fighting. *Al-Malhamah*: Place of intense killing. *Al-Ma'ziq* and *Al-Ma'qit*: Narrow places of war. *Al-Istabl*: The house where they are kept (Stable). *Marbit*: Place of tying them therein. *Al-Ari*: Place of their feeding.

Section: On names of things specific to horses and not others
