book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
*Al-Miqbas* and *Al-Miqwas*: A rope horses line up against during a race. *Al-Wahaq*: A rope thrown with a loop (lasso) to catch a beast if it bolts. *Al-Rasan*, *Al-Qiyad*, and *Al-Miqwad*: What is placed on its head to lead it. *Al-Shakimah*: The bar of the bit. *Al-Hakamah*: Less than the bit (curb chain area?). *Al-Withaq*: What ties the horse entirely. *Al-Tawal* and *Al-Til*: A rope with which the horse is tied and sent to pasture, its owner holding the end, or tied to the ground with a stake etc. *Al-Qayd*: For its forelegs (hobble). *Al-Shikal*: A rope with loops placed on a hand and a leg, sometimes diagonally. *Al-Akhiyah*: A rope with one loop placed on the horse's leg, its end secured to the ground. It is *Al-Ribqah*. *Al-Ribat*: A rope to confine the animal specifically. You say: I tied the horse with the *Ribat* (single rope), and secured it with the *Withaq* (general binding). You say: I bled (*Wadajtu*) the horse; *Widaj* is specific to animals, like *Fisad* (phlebotomy) for humans. And I shod it (*Samartuhu*) if I put iron shoes on it; this is also specific to animals.

Chapter Fourteen
Mention of a Selection of Poetry: The Arabs' Preference for Horses Over Others, Their Honoring of Them, and Their Pride in That
The Arabs never ceased preferring noble horses over children, and honoring them for adornment and hunting. To the extent that they would go hungry while the horses were full, go thirsty while they were quenched, and prefer them over themselves and their families when crises and hardships struck, and during drought years. Their reports indicate this and their poetry bears witness to it. We will mention a selection of that, God willing.
From what was narrated of one of the Banu Amir bin Sa'sa'ah:
'O Banu Amir! Why do I see the horses have become... Hungry? And some slimming is better for horses.
O Banu Amir! Horses are a protection... For yourselves, and death is a deferred time.
Humiliate yourselves for them, you will be honored, and undertake... Their maintenance, for maintaining horses is more beautiful.
Whenever you honor them, a man honors himself... And every man is positioned where his people are.'
From the speech of Al-As'ar bin Humran al-Ju'fi:
'I have known, regarding avoiding death... That fortresses are horses, not the mud-bricks of villages.
I found horses to be a manifest glory... Saving from distress and revealing blindness.
They spend the night as vanguards for the fearful frontier... And they spend the night as the wealth of the wealthy for the poor.'
Tufayl al-Ghanawi said:
'Even if my wealth is little, I am not separated from... One like an ostrich, tall in his limbs.
Or a grim-faced one whose veins are not cut... He is protected, yet on the day of terror, he is offered (in battle).'
Ismail bin Ajlan said:
'I have no wealth but horses I prepare... Even if I were wealthy with red dinars.
I share my wealth with them and feed their surplus... To my family, hoping to be aided and rewarded.
If I did not have a steed, I would see myself... Even if I had the treasure of Korah, as destitute.'
Ka'b bin Malik said:
'We prepare for the enemies every slimmed horse... Bay, white-legged, and piebald.
The King ordered tying them against His enemy... In war. Indeed, Allah is the best granter of success.
So they become a rage to the enemy and a wall... For the home if the horses of the renegades approach.'
Alqamah bin Amr al-Mazini said:
'I would not make my wealth the bucket of an irrigator... On top of a trunk pouring water into mud.
Horses are of my equipment; God advised regarding them... And He did not advise planting in orchards.
How many a tyrant's city have they circled... Until they left the high parts like flat plains.'
Qais bin al-Harith said:
'Do not place the tether of *Al-Shaqra'* far away... For the uncertainty of time is dreaded.
How many a poor person, by Allah's leave, has she revived... And a luxurious person she left drought-stricken.'
Antarah al-Fawaris said about his father Shaddad's horse:
'Whoever asks about me, then I... And *Jirwah* do not graze freely nor are lent out.
Kept close in winter, so you do not see her... Behind the tribe followed by foals.'
Dabi'ah al-Qaysi said:
'May Allah reward *Al-Agharr* a truthful reward... When the fire of wars is kindled.
He protects me with the breast and shoulders... And I protect him with spear-joints.
I keep him warm if a north wind blows... Damp, cold, after the south wind.
I show him as family when the shepherds... Strive to gather the milking camels!'
Al-A'raj al-Ma'ni said:

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
'I see the mother of Amr (his wife) ceaselessly complaining... Blaming, and I do not know for what she grieves.
She blames that I grant *Al-Ward* (the horse) a milk-camel... While she and Al-Ward are not equal in the hour of panic.
If she stands bare-headed, brisk... With a terrified heart, her head uncovered.
And I stood by him with the bridle and his saddle... There he rewards me for what I used to do.'
Makhul bin Abdullah al-Sa'di said:
'You blame for tying steeds and confining them... While Allah advised the Prophet Muhammad regarding them.
Leave me be, and count among your dependents a shapely mare... Dark bay, wind-swept in the flanks, long-necked.
When it is said "Hold him" while his water (energy/sweat) overflows... He refuses, and throws the boy far away.'
Al-Quhayf bin Humayr al-Uqayli said:
'We allied with swords and standing horses... They and the family are equal among us.
Barley is her provision, and a little dried clover... And from the water of iron she has shoes.'
A man from Banu Tamim said, when the King asked him for a mare named *Sakab* and he refused him:
'May you avoid the curse! Indeed *Sakab* is a precious object... Neither lent nor sold.
Ransomed and honored among us... The family goes hungry for her, and she does not starve.
Daughter of two winners who produced her... If their lineage is traced, the cannon bone joins them.
So do not covet... May you avoid the curse, in her, for withholding her is a thing possible.'
Al-Akhnas bin Shihab al-Taghlibi said:
'You see the tethered horses around our tents... Like the goats of Hijaz surrendered to the pens.
They are given evening drinks of milk and morning drinks like it... While they are lean from running, tucked up.'
Ja'far bin Abi Kilab said:
'Seek from me what you wish, for I... And *Hadhfah* are like the bone stuck in the jugular vein.
I tend to her myself or with a portion... And I cover her with my cloak in the frost.
I ordered the two shepherds to prefer her... With the milk of the free camel and the rising one.'
Malik bin Nuwayrah said:
'If scoundrels waste their horses in drought... And do not ride until the summer grazing grows.
My medicine for the hangover and my craft suffice me... At a time when a feeder cannot afford horses.
I distract my family from their little belongings... And give her pure milk of camels while the tribe calls out.'
Abu Duwad al-Iyadi said:
'The love of horses attached to my heart while poor... And when abundance returned to me.
My ambition attached to them, so poverty... Does not prevent the reins from me.
A shield for me in every day of betting... I gathered the nails/armor in its betting.
And my stripping with them towards my enemy... And traveling the lands and journeying.'
Al-Akhtal said, and it is attributed to Abdullah bin Abbas:
'Love horses and be patient regarding them... For in them is glory and beauty.
If people waste horses... We gather them so they share with the children.
We share living with them every day... And we dress them in veils and covers.'
Among the single verses on this are what will be mentioned by Allah's power:
Amr bin Malik said:
'And a winner like the eagle of darkness, I place him... Before the family; he has preference and kindness.'
Amir bin al-Tufayl said:
'Horses have days, so whoever is patient for them... And knows their days, goodness will follow.'
Al-Rab'i said:
'I said to my people: Honor horses, for I... See horses have gathered the distant ones to us.'
Tarafa said:
'We hold horses against what is disliked... When none holds them but the patient.'
Labid said:
'Our sanctuaries to which we seek refuge... Are the daughters of Awaj (horses) and swords.'
Some said, which is a versification of a Hadith of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace:
'Goodness, as long as a sun rises and sets... Is suspended, tied to the forelocks of horses.'
Poetry in this meaning is abundant. As for what is composed describing them, their traits, and similes, it is countless for Arabs and others. With the completion of this chapter, the discussion on horses is done. Let us speak on what we stipulated regarding weapons, by Allah's power.

Chapter Fifteen
Mentioning Swords
The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever girds a sword in the path of Allah, Allah clothes him with the scarf of dignity." Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "I heard the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, say: Indeed, Allah boasts to His angels of the girded one (with a sword). And they pray for him as long as he remains girded with his sword."

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
Al-Ahnaf bin Qais said: "The Arabs will remain Arabs as long as they wear turbans, gird swords, and do not consider forbearance a disgrace."
The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, had a number of swords. Among them was *Dhu al-Faqar* (The Vertebrate/Cleaver), which he took as spoil on the day of Badr; it belonged to Munabbih bin al-Hajjaj. Among them was *Al-Adb* (The Sharp), which he had given to Sa'd bin Ubadah. Among them were *Al-Battar* (The Severing), *Al-Mikhdham* (The Cutting), *Al-Rasub* (The Sinking), and *Al-Hatf* (Death). He had a *Qala'i* sword he acquired from the weapons of Banu Qaynuqa'. He had another sword inherited from his father. These are a collection of his swords, peace be upon him, as mentioned.
It was narrated that Ukasha bin Mihsan fought with his sword on the day of Badr until it broke in his hand. He came to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, who gave him a tree stump/root and said to him: "Fight with this, O Ukasha!" When he took it from the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, he shook it, and it returned as a sword in his hand, long in stature, strong in blade, white in iron. He fought with it until Allah granted victory to the Muslims. That sword was called *Al-Awn* (The Aid). It remained with him witnessing battles with the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, until he was killed in the caliphate of Abu Bakr, may Allah be pleased with him.
It was narrated that Abdullah bin Jahsh's sword broke on the day of Uhud, so the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, gave him a palm branch (*Urjun*); it became a sword in his hand with the hilt made of it. It was called *Al-Urjun*. It continued to be passed down until it was sold to Bugha the Turk.
The Arabs used to say: "The sword is the shadow of death and the saliva of doom." They used to nickname it *Abu al-Wajal* (Father of Dread). Among their proverbs regarding it is their saying: "The sword preceded the censure." And their saying: "The sword erased all that Ibn Darah said."
Some said: The sword is the protecting companion, the loyal friend, and the swift messenger. Abu Tammam al-Ta'i said:
"The sword is more truthful in tidings than books... In its edge is the boundary between seriousness and play.
White pages (blades), not black pages (books)... In their texts is the clearing of doubt and suspicion."
The sword suffices for others, but others mostly do not suffice for it. It performs the work of all weapons. Jami' al-Muharibi said: "If sword meets sword, choice is removed." Abu al-Tayyib (Al-Mutanabbi) said:
"I belittled the Rudayni (spears) until I abandoned them... Until it was as if the sword was reviling the spear."
It is said that the Arabs used to thrust with it like a spear, strike with it like a club, cut with it like a knife, make it a whip and a goad, take it as beauty in company, a lamp in darkness, comfort in loneliness, a companion in the void, a bedfellow for the sleeper, and a friend for the traveler. They name it a cloak (*Itaf*), a sash (*Wishah*), a staff, a robe, and a garment. It is the judge of combat and the decisive arbiter between men. With all that, poems were written, and proverbs and stories came to be.
Utbah bin Abd al-Sulami said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, gave me a short sword and said: "If you cannot strike with it, then thrust with it."
An Bedouin asked two of his sons which swords were most beloved to them. One said: "The polished *Husam* (sharp), the severing *Mikhdham* (cutter), the piercing *Sitam* (blade), the slender *Simsam* (unbending), which if you shake it does not dim, and if you strike with it does not bounce back." He said to the other: "What do you say?" He said: "Excellent sword he described! But another is more beloved to me." He asked: "What is it?" He said: "The sharp *Husam*, the shining *Rawnaq* (luster), the thirsty, hungry one! Which if you shake it tears, and if you strike with it kills!" He said to them: "Tell me about the most hated swords to you?" One said: "The blunt *Futar* (dull), the one bouncing off flesh and bone, which if struck with does not cut, and if slaughtered with does not avail." He said to the other: "What do you say?" He said: "Wretched sword he described! But another is more hated to me." He asked: "What is it?" He said: "The filthy *Dadan* (blunt), the despised wood-cutter (*Mi'dad*), which if struck with does not spill blood, even if you force it." *Al-Sitam*: The edge of the sword or other. *Al-Futar*: The one that does not cut.
It is narrated that Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, said one day: "Who is the most generous of the Arabs?" It was said: Hatim al-Ta'i. He asked: "Who is their poet?" It was said: Imru' al-Qais. He asked: "Which of their swords is sharpest?" It was said: The *Samsamah* of Amr bin Ma'd Yakrib al-Zubaydi. He said: So Umar sent to Amr to send him his sword known as *Al-Samsamah*. He sent it to him. When he struck with it, he found it less than what was reported to him; so he wrote to him about that. He replied: "I only sent the sword to the Commander of the Faithful; I did not send him the forearm that strikes with it."

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
Al-Haytham bin Adi said: When the sword of Amr bin Ma'd Yakrib, called Al-Samsamah, came into the possession of Musa al-Hadi, he called for it. It was placed before him and unsheathed. Then he said to his chamberlain: "Permit the poets to enter." When they entered, he ordered them to compose poetry about it. Anas began saying:
"The Samsamah of Al-Zubaydi was possessed... To the exclusion of all people, by Musa the Trustworthy.
The sword of Amr, and it was in what we heard... The best upon which scabbards were ever sheathed.
Green of blade, between its edges is light... From a wavy pattern (*Firind*) in which eyes extend.
Thunderbolts were kindled upon it as fire... Then sudden death was mixed with it.
When you unsheathe it, it dazzles the sun... With light, so it can hardly be seen.
As if the pattern (*Firind*) and luster flowing... On its two flat sides is flowing water.
As if death is suspended from it... So it is death from all its sides.
Yes, the miracle of the angry one in war... When he assaults with it, and what an excellent companion.
It does not care who unsheathes it for a strike... Whether a left hand assaulted with it or a right."
He said: So he ordered a purse of gold for him. It was said: He gave him the sword, then bought it back later for fifty thousand dirhams.
It is narrated that Urwah bin Al-Zubayr asked Abdul Malik bin Marwan to return the sword of his brother Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr. He brought it out to him among a collection of unsheathed swords. Urwah took it from among them. Abdul Malik said to him: "How did you recognize it among these swords?" He said: "By the saying of Al-Nabigha:
'There is no fault in them other than that their swords... Have notches in them from clashing with battalions.
They were inherited from the times of the Day of Halimah... To this day, they have been tested with every trial.'"
The King of the Romans sent three swords to Harun al-Rashid with great gifts. On each sword was an inscription. The first: "O Fighter! Charge and you will gain spoils; do not think of the consequence or you will be defeated." On the second: "If the blow of your sword does not reach, extend it by casting fear." On the third: "Deliberation in what is feared to be missed is better than haste to achieve hope."

Section
The sword has many names and descriptions in the Arabic language. From its names: *Al-Junthi*. Abu Ubaidah said: The *Junthi* is of the finest iron. It is said: The *Junthi* is the blacksmith who made them, so they were attributed to him. That which was forged in the land of India is attributed to it, so it is said: *Hindi*, *Muhannad*, and *Hunduwan*. Likewise, *Yamani* is attributed to Yemen. *Al-Qala'i* is attributed to Al-Qalah (a place), and it is said it means the white one, making it a descriptive name. *Al-Qasusi* is attributed to Qasus: a mountain containing an iron mine. *Al-Mashrafi* is attributed to Al-Masharif, which are villages in the land of the Arabs near the countryside. *Al-Surayji* is attributed to Surayj: a blacksmith who used to make them. From names of its qualities: If it is wide, it is *Safihah* (Plate). If it is slender and refined, it is *Qadib* (Rod). If it is polished, it is *Khashib*; it is said: the one that has not been polished; it is also said: the one whose making was not perfected despite hardness and effectiveness. If it is thin, it is *Mahw*. If it has grooves recessed in its blade, it is *Mushattab* and *Mufaqqar*. Its grooves are its *Shutab* and *Fiqar*. By that, the sword of the Prophet, peace be upon him, and the sword of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, were named. It is said that *Dhu al-Faqar* is what has an edge on one side, and its other side is blunt, not cutting. By that, the sword of Amr bin Ma'd Yakrib, Al-Samsamah, was known. If its two edges are male iron (steel) and its core is female (soft iron), it is *Mudhakkir*; this is the description of the Frankish sword. The Arabs claim it is the work of the Jinn; it is more durable for striking at the start, whereas the Indian sword might break at the start, though it is better for the edge. If it has a sparkle, it is *Ibriq*. If, due to its hardness, clarity, and good polish, the blood of the struck does not stick to it, it is *Islit*. If time has been long on it and its edge is chipped, it is *Qadim*. If it is dull in cutting, it is *Kaham* and *Dadan*. If there is a mark in its blade, it is *Ma'thur*. If it is for menial tasks like cutting trees, it is *Mi'dad*. If it is for flesh and bones, it is *Mi'dad*. From names describing its edge: If it is a cutter, it is *Miqsal*, *Mikhdal*, *Mikhdham*, *Juraz*, *Batir*, *Adb*, *Husam*, *Qadib*, and *Hudham*. All these names are taken from the speed of cutting. If it penetrates bones, it is *Musammim*. If it is stern and nothing bends it, it is *Samsam*.

Section: On names of its parts

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
*Jawharuhu* and *Athruhu*: Its pattern (*Firind*) that appears like water in it, imagined by the viewer to be flowing when shaken. *Dhubabuhu*: The tip of its blade. *Dhubatah*: Above the tip. *Ghirarahu*: Its two edges, which are its *Shafratan*. *Amuduhu*: Its middle. *Matnuhu*: Its entire blade. *Ri'asuhu*: What is other than its blade (hilt assembly). *Qabiduhu*: The handle for the striker's hand, which is its *Qa'im*. *Al-Sunbulah*: What enters from the blade into the hilt, also called *Al-Sinkh*. *Al-Saylan*: Flank the *Sinkh*. *Al-Qabi'ah*: The head of its hilt (pommel). *Al-Sha'irah*: What holds it. regarding names of scabbard parts: It is *Jafnuhu*, *Khillatuhu*, and *Khilaluhu*. It is said: *Khilal* are leathers inside the scabbard. *Hama'iluhu*: What it is suspended by, singular *Hamalah*, also called *Nijaduhu*. *Kalbuhu*: A ring containing its straps. The poet said in a riddle about this:
'Many a walker (*Sayr* - strap) I saw in a dog's (*Kalb*) mouth... The dog was made a beauty for the Emir.'
*Al-Siyah*: The ends of the *Hama'il* straps. *Sarabuhu*: Protection for the blade entry into the scabbard made of silver, iron, or otherwise. *Tha'latuhu*: Protection for its tip and edges (chape). *Al-Qirab*: A pouch (*Jirab*) like a sheath in which the sword with its scabbard is placed.
From the poetry about the sword: Tarafa said:
'I swore my flank would not cease to be a lining... For a sharp, polished, double-edged Indian sword.
A trustworthy brother who does not turn away from a strike... If it is said: "Gently," its restrainer says: "Done!"
A sharp sword (*Husam*); if I stand victorious with it... The first blow suffices, no need to return; it is not a wood-cutter (*Mi'dad*).
If people rush for weapons, you find me... Protected, if my hand is wet with its hilt.'
Ibn al-Mu'tazz said:
'I have a sharp sword in which deaths are hidden... Not unsheathed except to spill blood.
You see upon its flat sides the pattern (*Firind*) as if... It is the remnant of a cloud thinning below the sky.'
Al-Alawi said:
'As if on its pattern (*Firind*) are waves of a deep sea... Shortening at its edges and lengthening.
As if ants' eyes were broken around it... Eyes of locusts among them are vengeances.
A sharp sword (*Husam*) on the morning of terror, until it is... A messenger from Allah seizing souls.
It does not care who unsheathes it for a strike... Whether a left hand assaulted with it or a right.'
Ibn Abd Rabbih said:
'Possessor of grooves (*Shutab*), death decrees by its ruling... And there is no repelling what death decrees.
A pattern (*Firind*); if it appears to the eye it is stagnant... And lightning if it shakes in the palm, shining.
Its drawing pulls out the souls of warriors... Death is terrified of it, yet Death is terrifying.
If its likes meet in a battle... There, the soul's suspicion of the soul becomes reality.'
Ibn al-Zaqqaq said:
'Thirsty, drinking the water of necks... Yet what it drinks does not quench it.
You imagine it unsheathed lightning... And a star or a torch blazing.
He sent in war a flame of it... The war-hardened hero burns in its blaze.
A flat side vies with water... And a cutting edge kindles fire for it.
Crowned with its pattern as jewels... Plundering souls and not plundered.
Its scabbard smiles from its flat side... As moss clears from its water.'
Another said:
'And an Indian sword, the pattern (*Firind*) roamed in its blade... So the fire of death ignited in its edge.
It almost drowns its bearers with its water... And almost burns its wielder with its fire.'
Abu al-Ala al-Ma'arri said:
'Were it not for the thinness in your sword... We would have said it feigned grief falsely.
Descendant of fire, it thinned and refined until... As if its father bequeathed it tuberculosis (wasting).
Adorned in cloak (scabbard), you think it wearing... The stars of the night and shod with the crescent moon.
Residing in the blade are two contradictory extremes... Their contrast is a confusion.
You see upon it shallow water... And you see in it fire igniting.
When the Emir sees it and has unsheathed it... In the high air, he thinks it a mirage.
Red deaths crept upon it... But then were transformed into ants.
The terror of it melts every sharp sword... Were it not for the scabbard holding it, it would flow.
Whoever has a friend other than a sword... Will find imbalance in his friendship.'
Abu al-Abbas al-Tutayli said about swords:
'Thirsty (*Him*), arriving to drink (*Wirad*); if water shook hands with them... It would slip or move away from them while it is thirsty.
The spilled blood almost creates them... So do not say they are idols and statues.
Dead! If they take off their eyelids (scabbards) you know... That armor on heroes are shrouds.'
One of the best things said describing a sword is the saying of Habib bin Aws (Abu Tammam):

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
'They (swords) were alert like the sword; if two hands did not unsheathe it... Its edges would have unsheathed it from the scabbard.'
From exaggeration in describing it is the saying of Al-Nabigha:
'It cuts through the double-woven Saluqi (armor)... And strikes sparks of fire from the stones.'
The sayings of poets about the sword are very numerous, and what we have mentioned is sufficient.

Section
A condition of the sword is that it should not be unsheathed except when striking with it; if unsheathed before that, it causes cowardice. No weapon requires caution when working with it like the sword. Many who worked with it without caution or training were found to hit their horse's ear or upper arm, or perhaps hit their own ear or leg, cutting it or injuring it. If the knight wants to work with it, he should tip his foot in his stirrup so nothing appears of it beyond the front of the stirrup, according to what allows him to rely on it. He strikes with the sword outwardly (*Nafhan*) and crosswise (*Shazran*). Except what is directly in front of his face; then he must be most cautious for himself and his horse. Let him raise his hand when striking as much as possible to the outside; thereby he is safe. Let him cast his opponent to his right always in every case, especially the lancer. Whoever wants to learn it and train in striking should take a wet reed or wet rod, fix its base in the ground, secure it, then move away from it, place it on his right, and run his horse at full speed. When he approaches it, he unsheathes his sword with speed, caution, and lightness, and strikes (*Nafh*) what aligns with his head of that rod or reed, or strikes it crosswise (*Shazr*) with finesse and lightness. He does this repeatedly, cutting in every run as much as he can, until about a cubit remains. He persists in the work until it becomes a habit for him and working with it becomes light, God willing. *Shazr* is striking with it right and left, and *Nafh* is to the outside right.

Chapter Sixteen
Mentioning Spears
The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Stick to spears (*Qana*) and bows, for with them your Prophet was aided and conquests were made for you in the lands." *Qana* means spears. The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, had four spears: a spear called *Al-Muthanni*, and three he acquired from the weapons of Banu Qaynuqa'. The Arabs used to say: "The spear is the rope of death." Among their proverbs regarding it: "You reminded me of thrusting while I was forgetting." An Bedouin asked two of his sons which spears were most beloved to them. One said: "The flexible straightened (*Muthaqqaf*), the straight lean (*Mukhattaf*), which if you shake it does not bend, and if you thrust with it does not break." He said to the other: "What do you say?" He said: "Excellent spear he described! But another is more beloved to me." He asked: "What is it?" He said: "The dried vibrating (*Assal*), the straight quiverer (*Nassal*), the penetrator if you shake it, the effective if you spur it." He said: "Tell me about the most hated spears to you?" One said: "The crooked (*A'sal*) in thrusting, the notched at the spearhead, which if you shake it bends, and if you strike with it breaks." He said to the other: "What do you say?" He said: "Wretched spear he described! But another is more hated to me." He asked: "What is it?" He said: "The weak to shake, the dry rigid (*Kazz*), which if you force it shatters, and if you thrust with it snaps." *Al-A'sal*: The twisted/crooked one. Some said: Spears are the high ones (*Awali*), the brown ones (*Sumr*), the busy ones (*Hawali*), the horns of horses, the ropes of hearts and livers; by them souls are sought (*Tustamah*), and private parts and gaps are violated. They were created like vipers, for the gaps of throats; the one safe from them is excused, and the wounded by them is terrified. From their saying regarding that:
'How many a virgin have our spears married to us... And how many a previously married woman have become lawful to us without being divorced.'

Section
From their names in order: *Al-Anazah*, which is a staff larger than a club (*Hirawah*) having a ferrule (*Zujj*); it is a weapon because one can thrust with it, and the ferrule in it resembles a spearhead even if it isn't one. Then *Al-Nayzak*, which is longer than the *Anazah* and has a thin spearhead; plural *Nayazik*; similar is *Al-Mitrad*. *Al-Mizraq* is likewise because it is thrown due to the fineness of its shaft; its head might be square and fine for piercing armor and the like. If its length increases and it has a wide head, it is *Harbah* and *Allah*; plural *Hirab* and *Ilal*. *Al-Khurs* is among the short spears, plural *Khursan*. If it is solid, it is *Mid'as* used for thrusting (*Da's*), plural *Mada'is*. The longest is *Al-Rumh* and *Al-Qanah*.

Section: On names of their qualities and lineages

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
If the shaft grew straight and did not need straightening (*Tathqif*), it is *Sa'dah*. If it needed straightening, it is *Muthaqqaf*. If the spear is agitated, it is *Asil*. If intensely agitated, it is *Assal* and *Arras*. If it is soft/flexible, it is *Ladn*, *Dhabil* (dried/tough), and *Marin*. If it is strong, it is *Samhari*. If it is solid and does not bend, it is *Sadq*. If it is notched, it is *Thalib*. *Al-Khatti* is from Persian reeds, attributed to *Al-Khatt*: a land in Persia where they grow. *Al-Yazani* is attributed to Dhu Yazan: one of the kings of Yemen. *Al-Rudayni* is attributed to Rudaynah: a woman who used to make them, or it is said they were sold at her place. *Al-Asmar* (The Brown) is *Al-Azma* (The Thirsty), taken from thirst. *Al-Lahdham* is the penetrating spearhead. The wide spearhead is *Al-Minjal*, from *Najal*, which is widening; a *Najla* wound means wide. *Al-Washij* is the place where spears grow; it is said: they are the spears themselves. *Al-Murran* are spears, singular *Murranah*; it is said: *Murran* is where they grow.

Section: On detailing the parts of the spear
*Sinanuhu* (head), *Nasluhu* (blade), *Qurunuhu* (horns/edges). *Shafratuhu* (blade). Its tip is *Sa'ibatuhu*. *Dhubatahu* and *Shafratahu*: its two edges; likewise *Ghirarahu*. *Ayruhu*: The ridge in its middle. *Al-Jubbah*: The socket of the tang into the blade. *Al-Tha'lab* (The Fox/Tang): What enters from the shaft into the socket. *Al-Mihwar*: Its rivet/nail. *Zafiratuhu*: Its top. *Sadruhu* (Chest), *Aliyatuhu* (High part), *Amiluhu* (Working part): that is up to a third of it. Then *A'iduhu*, and *Amuduhu* (Pole): Its middle. Then *Saquhu* (Shank), *Safilatuhu* (Lower part), *Aqibuhu* (Heel), *Ka'buhu* (Ankle). Then *Zujjuhu* (Ferrule) and *Markazuhu* (Center/Base), which is the iron at its bottom if sharp; otherwise it is its *Halqah* (Ring). *Anabib* (Tubes) of Indian spears and their *Ku'ub* (Nodes): What is between their knots, which are their grooves (*Huruz*) and sections (*Fusul*). *Qisad* of spears: Their broken pieces and fragments, singular *Qisdah*.

Section: On the manner of riding with a spear
That is for the man to take his spear in his right hand, his rein in his left with the pommel of his saddle, place the butt (*Zujj*) of his spear on the ground—let him distance it slightly—place the ball of his left foot in his left stirrup, then rely on the spear, lift himself onto his horse, rising while rotating the spear over the horse's croup to the right side until he is upright quickly; then place the spear in his left hand with the rein, straighten his clothes and equipment with his right, then move the spear to his right. If he is in a desert and no person is near whom he fears the spear might hit, nor a tree it might get stuck in, let him take, if he wishes, the middle of the spear with his left hand along with the rein and mane if he sees that, or the pommel if he took the mane with his left or there is no mane, and take the cantle with his right, or the pommel if he took the mane with his left, and mount. A man should not attempt to pick up his spear from the ground while riding, for the horse might step on it and break it, or hit it and push it away; rather, let him dismount, take his spear, and mount as I described. As for dismounting with the spear, it is to take it in his left hand, place its butt on the ground near his horse's left leg, take the pommel with his right hand, then dismount. When he reaches the ground, he takes his spear with his right hand quickly, lest the horse turns on him and smashes it, or hits the ground with its head, or wounds someone. Let him pay attention to all this.

Section
Whoever wants to learn working with the spear and training in that should set up a *Dari'ah* (quintain/target), which is a stick or similar standing in the ground the height of a rider, secured at the bottom, with a ring or twisted rope resembling a ring tied at its top. Then move away from it, run his horse at full speed. When near that *Dari'ah*, tuck the spear under the armpit, extending from the armpit as much as is light to carry and his strength allows, then catch that hanging object with his spearhead. Then twist the spear quickly to free the head from the ring. He might need to flip his spear behind him, or penetrate the ring and catch his spear (*Laqfan*) from behind it. Perhaps the ring rotates wherever he turns it. Persist in practicing this however possible, until the work becomes light. He will not miss the mark, God willing. As for how to hold it during an encounter, thrusting with it, and disengaging after that, that requires explanation, length, and visual observation too, due to its many conditions and differing modes and ways. The knight should lighten his spear as much as he can, for he is stronger, more controlling, and more precise with a light one, according to his strength and tolerance. The spears of knights were ten cubits; less than that is permissible.

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
It should be between thin and thick, an amount the hand is not incapable of nor fingers meet over (too thin). Medium is praiseworthy, according to hand size and capability. Among the poetry about the spear is the saying of Al-Ma'arri:
'Possessor of thirst though it has no life... Certain of its bearer's length, so it grew tall.
It imagined every coat of mail a pool... So it dipped seeking to enter the rings.
You filled chests of people with it... So they found distraction from their grudges.'
Among the most creative sayings about it is the saying of our Sheikh, the Judge and Sharif Abu al-Qasim al-Hasani, may Allah have mercy on him:
'Deaf, extended in nodes, if it demands... The souls of warriors, its debt is not delayed.
Burning, until I say: Is it withering... In my hands, or is it a lit wick?
Were it not for the inflammation of the blade, its wood would ripen... From what it drinks of blood and sips.
So wonder at it, for the blood on its tip... Is ash (*Ramad*), yet a killing place is not hidden from it.'
Poetry about it is abundant.

Chapter Seventeen
Mentioning Bows and Arrows
Allah Almighty preferred the bow over all weapons, and made engaging in its matters a profitable trade and successful opinion. From the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, that he said: "People have not extended their hands to any weapon but that the bow has superiority over it." He, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever keeps a bow in his house, Allah banishes poverty from him as long as it is in his house." He, peace be upon him, used to give sermons during war leaning on his bow. He, peace be upon him, said: "The ultimate for the believer is the bow and arrow."

Section
Encouragement for archery is abundant. From Uqbah bin Amir, he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, while on the pulpit saying: "{And prepare against them whatever you are able of power}, Beware! Indeed, power is shooting (archery)." He, peace be upon him, liked a man to be an archer, a knight, and a swimmer. He, peace be upon him, said: "Teach your sons shooting, for it is damage to the enemy." He, peace be upon him, said to a group of Ansar he saw shooting: "Shoot, O sons of Ishmael! For your father was an archer." He, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever shoots an arrow in the path of Allah, missing or hitting, has a reward like freeing a slave from the children of Ishmael." He, peace be upon him, said: "Allah enters three people into Paradise by one arrow: its maker seeking good in its making, the one shooting it, and the one handling it to him." From Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, he said: I never heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, ransom anyone except Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas; he said to him on the day of Uhud: "May my father and mother be your ransom." On that day, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said to Sa'd, Abu Talha, Qatadah and others of the archers: "Stand firm! Victory will not cease to be with us as long as you stand firm." The number of archers that day was fifteen. Hadiths in this meaning are too many to count. How excellent is the poet when he says:
'Whoever wishes to walk the paths of care... And obtain glory at the end
And gain every abundant reward... Let him not bypass the path of archery
For in it is elevation in the worlds... And victory for the religion of the Prophet of Guidance.'

Section
The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, had a bow made of *Nab'* wood called *Al-Safra'* (The Yellow), a bow of *Shawhat* called *Al-Rawha'* (The Pleasant/Wide), another bow of *Shawhat* called *Al-Bayda'* (The White), and another bow called *Al-Katum* (The Silent). Bows are of two genera: Hand Bow, which is the Arab bow, divided into types; and Foot Bow, which is the Frankish bow (Crossbow), likewise divided into types. The Arab bow is more suitable for the knight, because it is faster and less burdensome; the Frankish bow is more suitable for the foot soldier, because it is more effective and offers more aid, especially in sieges, naval ships, and the like. It is specific to the people of Andalusia; with it they hunt, from it they shoot, in it they compete, and on it they rely, knights and men. It is the one we describe here, God Almighty willing.

Section

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
This bow—meaning the Frankish one (Crossbow)—is composed of a Stock (*Amud*), a Lath/Prod (*Qadib*), a Nut (*Jawzah*), and a Trigger (*Miftah* - Key). The stock was previously called the Runner (*Majra*), named so because arrows run on it. Its trigger used to protrude from the nut side, shooting several arrows, inclusive. Then this wood (design) was extracted in the time of Nimrod, and named *Amud* (Column/Stock) because it was relied upon. It has six holes: the hole of the *Mashrab*, the hole of the *Halq* (Throat) which is for loosening and binding; loosening and binding are for seven things: rubbing, washing, sawing, twisting, injecting, lifting, and descending. The third hole is for six, which is the hole of trust and deposit. The fourth hole is for the *Jawzah* (Nut), which is the hole of the lock, drinking, and leadership. The fifth hole is for the nail, which is the hole of assignment, bearing, and equipment. The sixth hole is for the *Miftah* (Key/Trigger), which is the hole of movement, form, and secrets. From it the craft opens, and it is its spirit and meaning. The *Qadib* (Prod) was named *Qadib* because it joins/marries in five places: a place in its middle, and four places at its ends. It has two strings: war string, and practice string (*Uwayr*?). The *Jawzah* was named nut for the passage of the mover, speaker, and silent over it. The name of the Nut is: The Heart, because the head of the Key turns in it. In it is a secret and in the Nut another; if they gather, wisdom appears. The Key was named Key because it opens the secrets of all we mentioned.

Section
The secrets of the bow are in seven things: an animal that reasons, which is the Archer; and disconnected from an animal that does not reason, which are the Fletching, Wax, Nut, Prod, and Arrow. These four attack when shooting, and one does not attack alone. It is said: The bow is taken from the circle, which is the perfection of craft; that is because when geometers looked at the sun, moon, and stars, they extracted it from them. The bow speaks with the tongue of condition, breathes like the breath of dawn, and is called a King because it possesses (dominates); when the archer puts it down, he fears it like the fear of a king when entering upon him, and others fear him likewise because of it.

Section
Bows are selected from ten woods: five wild and five orchard. The wild: *Takhsh*, which is *Nab'* in Arabic, *Zanbuj* (Wild Olive), *Dardal* (Ash/Elm?), *Katam* (Privet/Boxwood), and *Shabar*. The orchard: Bitter Orange (*Naranj*), *Nisman* (?), Apple, Pomegranate, and Quince. Regarding that, some said:
'Wonder at the noble bow, for it... Did not observe the right of the doves of the branches.
It became death for them having been a gathering place... And such is the ruling of the turning of times.'
Ibn al-Zaqqaq said:
'My soul is ransom for a crooked *Nab'* bow... Enamored with the killing of enemies.
It was familiar with the pigeons of the thicket while fresh... And today it familiarizes them with the breaking of the "Ha" (death/Hammam?).'
These woods from which the bow is selected have sources in the North, South (Qibla), East, and West. For cutting them, there are two seasons: cut in the season of winter poisons (*Samum*), which is the chosen one, likened to a child whose breastfeeding is complete; and cut in the season of summer poisons out of necessity. The original is the best of rods, and what is cut in a season (other than winter?) is a deficiency in its right.

Section
Know that the bow is strung/bound in two ways: by sight, which is the root, and by measurement, which is the branch. As for the people of knowledge in this, they are three: The *Arif* (Knower), the *Mu'allim* (Teacher), and the *Rami* (Archer). Each has a degree exceeding his companion. The Teacher exceeds the Archer in the flexibility of hands, and the Knower exceeds the Teacher in the light of the heart. They bind the bow by sight; if obscured, they measure with the *Dabit* (Caliper/Gauge). The description of measuring with it: Open the *Dabit*, open its tip into the lower edge of the Throat hole, then place the other tip at the edge of the end of the Breast (*Sadr*) of the Prod, then seek the other side with it. If the measurement is equal, it is the goal. If the tip of the *Dabit* exceeds the Breast edge, it is low, so raise it. If it falls short, it is raised, so lower it, until the measurement straightens for you. For binding it, two *Lazaz* (wedges/ties?) are necessary, of one measure of good young wood, with which the Prod is tightened after binding with a thong (*Samah*) of male deer skin, cut along the length of the skin, with an iron ring in which the left foot is placed when drawing (spanning), called for that reason a stirrup (*Rikab*).

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
If the Prod descends naturally into the Throat, turn your hand with it rising until it is at the beginning of the Rubbing (*Hakk*) and end of the Washing (*Ghasl*). Begin binding it and striking the two *Lazaz* (wedges): the rights before the lefts, lest there be a fault. Then string it and place the spanning belt (*Jabbad*) on your thin flank (waist), take the claw (*Mikhtaf*) with your left hand after saturating your right hand under the Trigger (*Miftah*), place it in the string, pull up with it, then drop it with the blessing of Allah. If the thumb exits from it, your exit is safe. Then turn the bow, transfer it to your left hand, mount the arrow, and shoot whatever you like.

Section
Some scholars of this affair said: Drop (the sear?) with forbearance, look with knowledge, and pinch (the trigger) with anger. It was said: Tighten the left, sharpen the gaze, and the effect of the matter has become valid for you. It was said: If the archer hits the target with his arrow, he kills a man in the enemy's land. If you shoot, accustom yourself to haste. It was recounted about a man of the Arabs that he stood over an advancing archer who was drawing his bow while looking! He said to him: "What are you looking at?" He said: "Perhaps I will expose someone!" He said to him: "Shoot the arrow; it seeks its owner." The superior archer is the drawer (*Jarrar*), steady of gaze, quick in shooting. It was said: Height in archery is: Drawing, Shooting, and Boldness. These traits do not gather except in a few archers. Know that drawing the bow is dangerous in winter time, out of caution for the archer due to the stiffness of the bow, and caution for the Prod due to its brittleness. The Eastern Prod is suitable for winter, and the Western Prod is suitable for summer. If you are in winter time, place your bow in the sun until it becomes moist and flexible, then shoot with it. If it is a cold day, there is no way to do that except in war specifically. If you are in summer time, place it in a cool place until it cools, then shoot with it. The whole matter and blessing is in the pinching (*Qars*) of the Key (Trigger). Pinching has three modes: Some people's control is smooth, so their pinch is soft; some have a control in between, so their pinch is gradual. They are not equal in that. The conclusion is only the Pinch.

Section
Know that the bow's ends do not equalize until the description is complete upon it. Beware of six qualities, for they are the head of error in this craft: The Rough String, for it decreases the shot and breaks the Prod. In the Prod: Emptiness, Fullness, Stopping, Wood under the Breast, and Thinning of the Tips. Among what is an obligatory duty for archers is the flax string for the bowstring. If you see a strong bow, do not draw it at all. If you walk in a raid, make the provisions heavy and weapons light, and increase the bow over all weapons. The light bow is the useful one in shooting. If you see people in the first clash, stand your ground until you see what happens; perhaps you will disperse those who reach the people with intensity. Let your arrows be of even workmanship, Gazelle-like assembly (*Ghazaliyah* - elegant?), thin feather housings, singular nocks. Beware of seven qualities. As for causes of the arrow returning to the archer, two are in the arrow: shortness of the nock, and warping forward. Two in the Nut: width of the groove, and height of the threshold. Three in the Prod: Emptiness, Fullness - mentioned before - and Washing (*Ghasl*).

Section
Know that Archery is a craft, the Target is a fortune (*Sa'd*), so hitting the target is of fortunes. Know that the first of arrows is called *Dalil* (Guide), the second *Bani* (Builder), the third *Zahur* (Backer/Helper), the fourth *Talib* (Seeker), the fifth *Darib* (Striker), and the sixth *Sadd Dhari'ah* (Blocking the Means/Sealing). If you shoot the Guide and it comes above the mark, and you shoot the Builder and it comes below it, and you shoot the Helper and it comes right, and you shoot the Seeker and it comes left, then shoot the fifth, for it is the Striker as its name implies, as we mentioned. The sixth is the verified one, which is the Sealing of the Breach. Whoever shoots the six and does not hit with one of them, his shooting is premature/defective (*Khidaj*), so let him not undertake shooting ever. Whoever hits with two, his work is eased. Whoever hits with four has acquired much of the craft. Whoever hits the six has attained the degree of perfection, and entered into the invocation of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, for Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas, may Allah be pleased with him. The first arrow he shot in the raid of Badr al-Abwa'. These verses are from his saying regarding that:
'Has it reached the Messenger of Allah that I... Protected my companions with the chests of my arrows?
No archer against an enemy counts... With an arrow, O Messenger of Allah, before me.
I defend with them their first ones, a defense... In every rugged ground and every plain.
That is because your religion is a religion of truth... And Possessor of Right, you brought it with justice.

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
'The believers are saved by it and disgraced... By it are the disbelievers at a place of respite.
So gently! You have erred, so do not blame me... O seducer of the tribe, woe to you, O Ibn Jahl!'
In the perfect arrow are praised qualities that adorn archery and strengthen the Rubbing, Washing, and Moving. The Sheikhs of this method said: The short is contemptible, the prominent is a knight, and everything has a beloved, and the beloved of the bow is the Just Arrow.

Section
Know that the iron (arrowheads) are of seventeen types. Four are for hunting: *Zujj*, *Shilyat*, *Murjafli*, and *Mujannah*. Three for armor: *Sabt* (Smooth?), *Murabba' Tawil* (Long Square), and *Muthallath* (Triangular). Four for the shield (*Turs*): *Murabba' Qasir* (Short Square), *Qitral*, *Balluta* (Acorn), and *Shabri*. Four for the leather shield (*Daraq*): *Shilyat* (smaller than hunting), *Tamuh*, *Mijwaf*, and *Milhani*. Two for other meanings: *Bajuq* for cutting the rigging (*Bisht*?), and *Sahm al-Huma* (Arrow of Fever/Heat?) for piercing ships and wooden towers. Do not be without these mentioned types, and mark their nocks so they are known to you when you extend your hand to your quiver at the time of need to extract the one you want. It has been said: "Before shooting, arrows are fletched." Speech in this chapter is long; if we followed the talk on bows, arrows, and shooting, we would exit the intended purpose of the authorship.

Section
From the poetry about the Bow:
'I am the Bow, there is no doubt that I... Destroy lions in the pushing war.
I decree upon heroes from of old... And in my liver (grip) are arrows of death.
Arrows nocked for me from an ambush... So woe to the warriors from the ambush.
If I nock my arrow, it is not met... By a shield, nor by a strong coat of mail.'
Also from that:
'Ask the rings of the white armor (*Madhi*) about the edge of arrows... For they have notched the edge of spears and swords.
They inform you that when horses rush... I am the partner of deaths in the souls of battalions.
If the heroes hear my vibration in terror... You see them fall under the noble lean horses.
As if my vibration is the blowing of the Trumpet whenever... They listen to it, they fall prostrate on every side.
If the *Khatti* (spear) boasts that it resembles... The beauties bending in the figures of damsels,
Then in the arrows of glances is a field for boasting... If you sought it, or in the bows of eyebrows!'
Also from that:
'My arrows are penetrating into enemies... If the archer masters archery with me.
I stand in his palm and my arrow goes... To a distance and reaches every limit.
The spear does not do like my deed... Nor the Indian sword in protection.
I boasted over weapons with this. And my merit... If you think, has no end.'
Also from that:
'Leave the *Khatti* (spear) bending its sides... For my arrows have a merit over it.
If high status is killing enemies... Is any better than the fastest of us to it?'
Poetry about the bow is too abundant to mention. As for types of bows, they are different, their conditions varied, and working with them requires elaboration this summary cannot bear. Archery has well-known books and a famous craft; so let one look into them according to what suits him and is light for him. However, the pillar of the archer knight is: The well-trained horse, and the bow suitable for drawing on the horse. And success is by Allah.

Chapter Eighteen
Mentioning Armor
Allah Almighty counted armor among the blessings He bestowed upon people. The commentators said regarding His saying Almighty {And garments to protect you from your violence}: They are coats of mail. Indeed, they repel dread as long as the appointed time is delayed. That is why Abbad bin al-Husayn said, when a man asked him: "In which armor would you like to meet your enemy?" He replied: "In a delayed appointed time."
The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, had armor called *Dhat al-Fudul* (Possessor of Excess/Length). He had another armor which, if hung by its rings (*Zarafin*), did not touch the ground, and if released, touched the ground. He, peace be upon him, did not witness war except with it. He had two coats of mail he acquired from Banu Qaynuqa'. One was called *Al-Sughdiyah*. It is said he had the armor of David, peace be upon him, which he wore on the day of killing Goliath. It is narrated that Luqman the Wise used to sit with David, peace be upon him, while David was making armor. Luqman did not know what it was and did not ask him about it. When he finished it, he wore it and said: "It is indeed a fortress for a day of violence." Luqman then knew its purpose.

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
Section: On its names and descriptions
Among them are *Al-Junan* (Shields/Protections), and everything one protects oneself with is a *Junnah*. *Al-La'mah*: The complete armor that has excess length. If it is wide, it is *Za'fah*, then *Nathrah*, and *Nathlah*. Then *Fadfadah* if along with width it is long/full. If it is tight, it is *Sukk*. If it is soft, it is *Khadba'* and *Dilas*. If it is tightly woven and solid, it is *Qada'* and *Hasda'*. If it has a long tail, it is *Dha'il*. If it is white, it is *Madhiyah*; it is said *Madhiyah* means flowing like water, or easy and soft. Its nails are *Harabi*, singular *Hirba'*. The heads of its nails are *Qatir*, singular *Qatirah*, likened to the eyes of locusts. *Al-Muda'afah* (Doubled) is woven ring into ring two by two. Its rings are *Zarad*. If made of perforated plates, it is *Masrudah*. If woven/interlaced, it is *Jadla'*. If short, it is *Shalil* and *Badan*. If it is a breastplate without a back, it is *Jawshan*. *Al-Saluqiyah* is attributed to Saluq, a village in Yemen where it is made. *Al-Hutamiyah* is attributed to Hutamah; it is said he was a man from Abdul Qais bin Afsa. *Al-Fir'awniyah* is attributed to Pharaoh. *Al-Dawudiyah* is attributed to David, peace be upon him.
From the poetry about armor, Al-Ma'arri said:
'A pool (of mail) which the wind embroidered, an embroidery of a maker... It did not change when its stillness lasted.
As if young locusts drowned in it, without eyes... If a looker returns his gaze to distinguish it.
No land animal is safe in it... If its sword or ship does not aid him.
If a knight did not put it off for peace... Its folds would remain on him forever.
If the soul of the young man knew the day of his death... And met it in armor, its doom would not assassinate him.
Trustworthy; if you entrust your body to it... And meet war, its trustee will not betray you.'
Abdul Qais bin Khufaf said:
'And a long coat of excellent armor... You hear a ringing from the sword on it.
Like a pool the west wind drove... The heavily armed man drags its excess.'
Abu Ishaq bin Khafajah said describing a man wearing armor:
'Iron buttoned the pocket of a dove upon him... A grey one in the gloom of dark dust.
As if the skin of a snake was shed upon him... On the day of distress, over the sides of a speckled snake.'

Section
Some Arabs boast and praise wearing armor in war. Antarah al-Fawaris said:
'Ubaylah wondered at a disheveled youth... Bare-knuckled, pale like a blade.
Disheveled hair, his shirt worn out... He has not oiled himself for a year, nor dismounted.
He does not wear anything but iron... When he dresses; and such is every desperate warrior.
He has worn iron for so long that... The rust of iron on his skin is not washed off.'
Others praise the opposite, viewing armor as tiresome and distracting, and that storming war without armor is braver and faster in fighting. Al-A'sha said:
'And when a gathered battalion comes... Silent, whose voracity the defenders fear.
Its sides seek refuge in a praised (or dispraised?)... Hated (war) whose combat the heroes fear.
You were the leader, not wearing protection... Striking its heroes with the sword, making marks.
And I knew that the soul meets its death... Whatever its Creator decreed for it.'
Muhammad bin Muslim said praising a man:
'He meets swords with his face and throat... And sets up his head in place of a helmet.
And says to the side: Be patient for the points of spears... For I have wounded the corner of glory if you are not wounded!'

Section
From armor is *Al-Mighfar* (Coif), which is woven like the weaving of armor to cover the head and face. Ibn al-Mu'tazz said addressing a boy:
'And when you stormed the war wearing armor... And masked your face with the Mighfar.
We considered your face the morning sun... Upon it a veil of amber.'
What is made for the head from hollowed iron is *Baydah* (Egg/Helm). Its *Qawnas* is the protrusion of its front. Its *Da'irah* is its rear. Among names of the Helm are *Khudhah*, *Tarkah*, *Tarikah*, *Rabi'ah*, and *Khayda'ah*. Plural is *Khuwadh* and *Tara'ik*.

Chapter Nineteen
Mentioning Shields and Similar Items

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
*Al-Turs*: It is the round shield (*Mijann*), and upon it circles revolve. From Anas bin Malik, he said: Abu Talha used to shield himself with the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, with one shield.

Section
Among its names collectively: *Al-Tiras*, *Al-Jawb*, *Al-Fard*, *Al-Junan*, and *Al-Majann*. Singular: *Turs*, *Jawb*, *Fard*, *Mijann*, and *Mujna'*. If made of leather, they are *Daraq*, *Hajaf*, and *Yalab*. Singular: *Daraqah*, *Hajafah*, and *Yalabaha*. It is said *Yalab* are armor made of skin. It is said they are like the *Baydah* (helm) for the head specifically. It is said *Jahaf* are of wood. *Al-Daraq* are made of cowhide, wild animal hides, and *Lamt* hide; these are the best and most protective. *Al-Lamt* is an animal from the wonders of the Maghreb inhabiting deserts; shields are made from its skin. The property of the *Lamt* shield is that if hit by a sword or spear blow, the blow closes up and heals immediately and disappears, leaving no mark.

Section
The shield bearer in combat must shield himself with the middle of his shield from sword, javelin, and stones, rotating it right and left outside his alignment, not sticking it to his body when he fears something hitting it. He defends himself and his horse by rotating it. Meeting a stone with the chest of the shield is better, and he should angle it so what hits it slides off. He shields from a spear with its entirety and bulk; if he feels the spearhead hit it, he angles it and deflects it from his body. Let him beware of relying on it with his body then lest it throws him down. Also beware when deflecting with it that the spearhead slips and catches his clothes. This amount is what should be maintained. Working with the *Daraqah* is exactly like working with the *Turs*. But the *Daraqah* catches the spear due to its humidity and level texture, so one must steal it (deflect quickly) and angle with it, lest it becomes heavy in the hand and impossible to work with. Riding with the shield has two cases regarding its length and shortness: If long, remove hand from its handle, take rein with left hand and ride; beware of it hitting the chin if it reaches it. If short, take it under the armpit and ride. Al-As'ad bin Balit said about a shield:
'A shield whose makers imitated the sky... So that tall spears fall short of it.
They fashioned the likeness of Pleiades on it... Stars decreeing success for us.
They collared it with a collar of silver... Just as the light of morning clothed the horizon.'

Chapter Twenty
Weapons and Equipment in General
Acquiring weapons is an obligation of Jihad, due to the saying of Allah Almighty: {And prepare against them whatever you are able of power.} Ibn Abbas said: Power is weapons and equipment in the path of Allah. Acquiring that is for the capable according to his ambition and dignity of soul, in addition to the reward and recompense involved. Narrated from Abdullah bin Zajr that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Whoever acquires equipment in the path of Allah, it is placed in his scale every morning." From Abdullah bin Shawdhab that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "The deeds of the son of Adam are displayed every Monday and Thursday; whoever increased in his weapons, increased in his good deeds, and whoever decreased his weapons, decreased in his good deeds." Equipment is among the causes of Decree (*Qadar*), and aids to Victory. As long as time permits... It was said to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace: "Do you see medicine we take and incantations we recite, do they repel anything of Allah's decree?" He said: "They are from the decree of Allah."

Section
The Arabs used to say: The sword is the shadow of death, the spear is the rope of doom, arrows do not consult the one who sent them, armor is tiresome but a fortress, and the shield is a protection. Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, asked Amr bin Ma'd Yakrib about weapons, saying: "The Commander of the Faithful asks you about what appears to him!" He said: "What do you say about the spear?" He said: "Your brother, but perhaps he betrays you and breaks." He said: "What do you say about arrows?" He said: "Deaths that miss and hit." He said: "What do you say about the shield?" He said: "It is the circling protector, upon it circles revolve." He said: "What do you say about armor?" He said: "Burden for the foot soldier, distraction for the knight, but it is a fortified fortress." He said: "What do you say about the sword?" He said: "There your mother bereaves you! No mother for you!" Umar hit him with the pearl (whip) and said: "Nay, no mother for you!" He said: "The fever humbled me to you." Al-Alawi gathered the description of horses and weapons, doing well where he says:
'Sufficient for me of wealth is a long-necked horse... Sound of shanks, bare of cheekbones, smooth-skinned.

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text:
And a sword (*Muhannad*) whiter than iron water... And a brown spear (*Samhari*) vibrating, tall.
And white armor like shallow water, loose, flowing... A striped baldric holds it to me.
And a bow with bent tips, thick-handled, generous... Wide-sided, yellow *Shawhat* wood.
O would that my wealth, other than what I gathered... Were on a deep sea whose waves crash.
O would that I spend the night in time... With no commanding ruler over me.'
Al-Ayyar al-Dabbi said in its meaning:
'I prepared a white armor for wars and a polished... Double-edged sword that breaks rings.
And a wide *Nab'* bow and a full quiver... Of arrowheads you would think were leaves.
And a spirited sharp sword and a horse with a blaze... Smooth-backed, swimming (in speed), eager.
Filling your eyes with space and pleasing... You as an eagle if you wish, or impulsive.'

Section
If a knight is singled out with a specific weapon, he is described by it. With a sword: *Musif* and *Sayyaf*. Striking with it: *Sa'if*. With a spear: *Ramih*. With arrows: *Nabil* and *Nabbal*. With crossbow/arrows: *Nashib*. With armor: *Dari'*. With a helmet: *Muqanna'*. With a shield: *Tarras*. If he combines sword and arrows, he is *Qarin*. If he gathers weapons, he is *Salih*. *Al-Shakkah*: Complete weapons. You say: A knight *Shaki al-Silah* (fully armed), lightened form. It is said it is from *Shawkat al-Silah* (thorn/power of weapon); if so, it is inverted from *Sha'ik*. A knight *Mu'ammal*: Fully armed with tools. Likewise *Mudajjaj*. *Al-Sannawr*: Weapons with armor. *Al-Bazz* and *Al-Bizzah*: Weapons without armor. If the knight has no sword, he is *Amyal*. If without a spear, *Ajam*. If without armor, *Hasir*. If without a shield, *Akshaf*. If no weapons at all, *A'zal*. If he puts on armor, you say *Istala'ma*: meaning he wore the *La'mah*. *Sanna* the armor on him: poured it on him. *Nathalaha*: wore it also. *Taqanna'a*: wore the helmet (*Mighfar*). *Ijtanna*: wore the shield (*Junnah*). *Jallala* with the sword: if he attacks his opponent with it and urges against him. *Jallalahu* with it: covered him (struck him from above). *Safahu*: struck him with it and wounded him. *Tabbaqa*: if he hit the joint. *Bara*: if he cut flesh and bone and severed the limb. *Al-Misa'* and *Al-Mumas'ah*: Fighting with swords. *Al-Muta'anah* and *Al-Muda'asah*: Fighting with spears. You say: *Ramaha* and *Da'asa* and *Nadasa*: if he thrust with the spear. *Nabala* and *Rashaqa*: if he shot with arrows.
I say: Mastery of working with weapons is not equal among people; rather, the disparity between them in that is severe, and the difference great. It is obligatory upon the intelligent person to witness the actions of the experts, attend with men, and take a share of training in it with whom he sees fit and chooses. Until he knows the method of thrusting, striking, and drilling with weapons in war, and the modes of action in attacking and retreating, defense, entering upon duelists, and exiting from them in lance-fighting and sword-fighting. And observing the fall of arrows, times of advance and retreat, stealing ground in dueling, hiding from the sun during the encounter, engagement and evasion, turning in fighting, the subtleties of that, and its consequences during combat. And watching for the enemy's inadvertence in movement and calm, and trickery in disabling the spear by striking it or controlling it against its owner, or returning it to him, or removing the horse's cheekpiece, or cutting its rein, so the knight becomes busy with his horse's affair, enabling him (the opponent) to overpower him instantly; physiognomy appears in this and becomes clear. Whoever does not train in that, let not his soul deceive him to walk these paths. In knowing all that and looking deeply into it, knights excel over one another, along with steadfastness, boldness of heart, intense caution when disputing with peers, and descending to the field. Allah, Majestic and Exalted, is the One sought for help in every condition. Abu al-Tayyib said:
'Weapons are carried by all people... But not every possessor of a claw is a Lion.'

book_title: The Ornament of Knights and the Emblem of the Brave
text: Here, by the praise of Allah, I have reached what I intended, and finished summarizing what I presented, completed the purpose, and performed the imposed duty, when I brought... to his distinctiveness, and ran the steed in the field of his passage. He whose courtyard the armies of Islam have stepped into, and desired the overflow of dew (generosity) from his palm. The lands of the enemy have given him the hand of submission, to attain from him the request and obtain every desire. They have yearned for him like the yearning of the sick for doctors, and the scarred for consolation. It envies its likes that they took refuge with him in residence, and wishes if it could shake his hand in meeting, gaining from him the healing cure, sufficient support, and sincere beloved. Then he—may Allah Almighty support him—releases it from the shackle of obscurity, encompasses it with fertility after drought, saves it from the hand of humiliation with his protectors and delegations, and places it after the nadir in the station of Saturn with his heroes and soldiers. He possesses determinations that terrify the days, and wake the grave matter if it sleeps. Bravery and Generosity are allies to his nature, and companions to his character. Distresses are relieved by his spearhead, news of his praise is fragrant, voices rise calling variously, and hands extend pleading in unison, that Allah may humble the noses of idols by the truth of his seriousness, and execute the resolves of Islam by the sharpness of his edge. O Allah, establish him in Your land with the widest establishment, intensify his tread upon the aggressors, support through him the parties of the believers, scatter by his soldiers the mixed crowds of the disbelievers, and make them a harvested field, extinct, for his sharp swords. O Allah, protect him from his sides and directions, and revive the landmarks of faith by his life. Guard him in his wakefulness and sleep from... the high and his self, and spread the tassels of his banners and flags with the wind of victory. O Allah, show him hope in his family and children, his protectors and soldiers, land the saddles of joy with him, and spread his hands with good things. Indeed, You are capable of all things, and worthy of answering. Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds, and blessings and peace upon our Master and Lord Muhammad, Seal of the Prophets and Imam of the Messengers, and upon his family, companions, and his righteous, most noble helpers. And grant abundant peace.
